('57', 0, 1, 2, 48) 1. LETTER TO PADMAJA NAIDU
('57', 0, 2, 3, 75) September 5, 1932
('57', 0, 3, 4, 93) MY DEAR PADMAJA, Your basket of oranges again!
('57', 0, 3, 5, 140) Seeing that you will insist on sending them no matter what I say.
('57', 0, 3, 6, 206) let me tell you that they are really a good variety—very juicy.
('57', 0, 3, 7, 270) You have responded to the gentle driving by the poor little slave driver.
('57', 0, 3, 8, 344) Even I could decipher your letter without difficulty.
('57', 0, 3, 9, 398) But I do not want you, please, to exert yourself when you are lying flat on your back.
('57', 0, 3, 10, 485) Any abomination will do.
('57', 0, 3, 11, 510) Even the abominations of loved ones are preferable to their silence.
('57', 0, 3, 12, 579) But when you are really ill, why not get some willing assistance?
('57', 0, 3, 13, 645) Anybody will gladly write to your dictation.
('57', 0, 3, 14, 690) Your mention of that magnificent story of the Buddha brings to mind many sacred things.
('57', 0, 3, 15, 778) Yes, I do dream many dreams.
('57', 0, 3, 16, 807) All may not be airy nothings or I would be crushed under the weight of the love I appropriate from people of all sorts and conditions—men, women, boys and girls.
('57', 0, 3, 17, 969) 1 Sardar and Mahadev have more books than they can cope with.
('57', 0, 3, 18, 1031) The former is absorbed like a diligent student in his Sanskrit studies; the latter in his French and Urdu thanks all the same on their behalf for your offer.
('57', 0, 3, 19, 1189) It is no use, I fear, your wanting to see them.
('57', 0, 3, 20, 1237) I wish it was possible.
('57', 0, 3, 21, 1261) Love from us all.
('57', 0, 4, 22, 1279) Yours, SLAVE DRIVER
('57', 0, 5, 23, 1299) SHRIMATI PADMAJA NAIDU C/O SERVANTS OF INDIA SOCIETY POONA CITY
('57', 0, 6, 24, 1363) From the origin al: Padmaj a Naidu Papers .
('57', 0, 6, 25, 1407) Courte sy: Nehru Memori al Museum and Librar y
('57', 0, 7, 26, 1454) 1 This paragraph has already been reproduced in “Letter to Padmaja Naidu”, 5 9 1932.

('57', 1, 1, 2, 1579) 2. LETTER TO NANALAL K. JASANI
('57', 1, 2, 3, 1610) September 5, 1932
('57', 1, 3, 4, 1628) BHAI NANALAL, I had been awaiting your letter and was relieved when it came.
('57', 1, 3, 5, 1705) I have already written to Mayashankar 1 ; I hope he got the letter.
('57', 1, 3, 6, 1773) I have been restraining Champa.
('57', 1, 3, 7, 1805) I had also dissuaded Manjula 2. I think Maganlal would welcome this.
('57', 1, 3, 8, 1874) She seems to me a very wise girl.
('57', 1, 3, 9, 1908) Do you find any difficulty in selling the emeralds?
('57', 1, 3, 10, 1960) Or is it because of obstruction by somebody that you have not been able to sell them?
('57', 1, 3, 11, 2046) It is certainly worthy of you not to wish to withdraw the money deposited in your name by the Doctor.
('57', 1, 3, 12, 2148) The daughters, however, should get the money set apart for them, but at present I see no possibility of their being able to withdraw any part of it.
('57', 1, 3, 13, 2297) Hence, the time has not yet come for thinking about your share.
('57', 1, 3, 14, 2361) Everything can be settled if the train gets on the rails.
('57', 1, 3, 15, 2419) We will see about it provided the family does not break up and the bitterness disappears.
('57', 1, 3, 16, 2509) Please write to me regularly.
('57', 1, 3, 17, 2539) If you act as Chhaganlal advises, everything will end well.
('57', 1, 3, 18, 2599) I know that you will go on doing your duty irrespective of whether they love you or slight you and, therefore, I do not worry.
('57', 1, 4, 19, 2726) Blessings from BAPU
('57', 1, 5, 20, 2746) From Gujarati: C.W. 9470a
('57', 1, 6, 21, 2772) 3. A LETTER
('57', 1, 7, 22, 2784) September 5, 1932 You are either cunning or foolish.
('57', 1, 7, 23, 2837) Do you really not know what ‘vikar’ means?
('57', 1, 7, 24, 2880) The vikar resulting from eating pulses and that resulting from physical touch, are both signs of something wrong in us.
('57', 1, 7, 25, 3000) Both disturb the equilibrium.
('57', 1, 7, 26, 3030) The first kind of vikar results from swallowing some external substance; the second is a change of mental state resulting from the sight of some external object.
('57', 1, 7, 27, 3192) A vikar that can shake one’s whole being may prove harmful.
('57', 1, 7, 28, 3252) If a woman feels vikar
('57', 1, 8, 29, 3275) 1 Mayashankar Vrajlal Desai, business partner of Dr. Pranjivan Mehta.
('57', 1, 8, 30, 3345) 2 Wife of Maganlal Mehta.
('57', 2, 0, 1, 3371) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 3
('57', 2, 1, 2, 3419) towards a man, society does not always hold her guilty; that is, when it springs from a desire to marry that person and such marriage is not forbidden, the matter is not kept secret from one’s people and one is free to marry.
('57', 2, 1, 3, 3645) According to me, you are not yet fit to marry, for you are studying and are still a minor.
('57', 2, 1, 4, 3736) Your having such relations with .
('57', 2, 2, 5, 3770) 1 is improper, as he was your teacher and was, moreover, like a brother to you.
('57', 2, 2, 6, 3850) Call your feeling what you like, whether vikar or desire for marriage, you kept it secret and, therefore, it is blameworthy.
('57', 2, 2, 7, 3975) You do not understand the meaning of independence also.
('57', 2, 2, 8, 4031) When you show the letters to your elders of your own free will, you do not lose your independence but seek your safety.
('57', 2, 2, 9, 4151) If somebody posts himself at our door step, he is like a Government bailiff depriving us of our freedom; but if we station a watchman at the gate, we do not lose our freedom but protect it.
('57', 2, 2, 10, 4341) In the same way, if you in your adolescent state regard your elders as guardians of your interests, open your heart to them and show your letters to them.
('57', 2, 2, 11, 4496) You do not lose your independence but seek protection for it.
('57', 2, 2, 12, 4558) I earnestly wish that you should become independent.
('57', 2, 2, 13, 4611) It was for protecting your independence that I advised you to show your letters, etc., to your parents.
('57', 2, 2, 14, 4715) If, however, you cannot reconcile yourself to this and feel it an irksome restraint, you may keep your letters private.
('57', 2, 2, 15, 4835) I do not want to put pressure on you in any way, as that would crush your individuality.
('57', 2, 2, 16, 4924) I only wish that you should become a brave girl and a spirited servant of the people.
('57', 2, 2, 17, 5010) And I shall be extremely pained if you stop writing to me.
('57', 2, 3, 18, 5069) [From Gujarati]
('57', 2, 4, 19, 5085) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.

('57', 3, 8, 13, 6238) September 7, 1932
('57', 3, 9, 14, 6256) BHAISHRI RATILAL, I have your letter.
('57', 3, 9, 15, 6294) Chhaganlal and Lilavati 2 write to me and I feel satisfied with their letters.
('57', 3, 9, 16, 6373) I also receive complaints against both of them which I immediately pass on to them.
('57', 3, 9, 17, 6457) Lilavati wrote about her health to me too.
('57', 3, 9, 18, 6500) If Chhaganlal willingly permits her to go, I think it would be good to call her there for some time.
('57', 3, 9, 19, 6601) Her health at any rate would improve.
('57', 3, 9, 20, 6639) Manekbehn 3 seems to be very much displeased with her.
('57', 3, 9, 21, 6694) Lilavati says that she has done nothing but I do not believe she is so completely innocent.
('57', 3, 9, 22, 6786) For one thing, her tongue is very sharp.
('57', 3, 9, 23, 6827) And, moreover, Manekbehn is a simple minded woman and anybody can easily deceive her.
('57', 3, 9, 24, 6913) I had observed in Rangoon and also when Lilavati was at Sabarmati, that she could not tolerate any criticism.
('57', 3, 9, 25, 7023) But how can even you change her nature?
('57', 3, 9, 26, 7063) You have been exercising upon her whatever good influence you can as her father.
('57', 3, 10, 27, 7144) 1 Of the Gita.
('57', 3, 10, 28, 7159) 2 Addressee’s daughter, and chhaganlal’s wife.

('57', 4, 4, 8, 7674) 7. LETTER TO PRABHUDAS GANDHI
('57', 4, 5, 9, 7704) September 7, 1932
('57', 4, 6, 10, 7722) PRABHUDAS, I have your letter.
('57', 4, 6, 11, 7753) What you want cannot be sent for Rentia Baras.
('57', 4, 6, 12, 7800) How do you forget that we are prisoners?
('57', 4, 6, 13, 7841) But you may imagine that our yarn is there.
('57', 4, 6, 14, 7885) Mahadev draws yarn of about hundred counts from Keshu’s slivers.
('57', 4, 6, 15, 7950) If there is a proper spindle, it would not take much to draw a thinner yarn.
('57', 4, 6, 16, 8027) I spin a yarn of 40 counts on Magan spinning wheel.
('57', 4, 6, 17, 8079) It takes about three hours to spin 250 rounds of yarn.
('57', 4, 6, 18, 8134) It takes much of my time.
('57', 4, 6, 19, 8160) But as long as my hand gives work, I will stick to it.
('57', 4, 6, 20, 8215) This time, I do not have with me the right mechanic.
('57', 4, 6, 21, 8268) Otherwise, I would have got the alterations made.
('57', 4, 6, 22, 8318) Whatever changes you make, do not sacrifice the simplicity of the spinning wheel.
('57', 4, 6, 23, 8400) In order to draw fine yarn, I feel the distance between the spindle and the tip should be reduced.
('57', 4, 6, 24, 8499) There are more chances of fine yarn gettingsnapped if drawn long.
('57', 4, 6, 25, 8565) The spindle should be shorter and thinner than it is.
('57', 4, 6, 26, 8619) This is only my thinking.
('57', 4, 6, 27, 8645) That you have set up a limit [of work] is more than enough.
('57', 4, 6, 28, 8705) Do not be impatient.
('57', 4, 6, 29, 8726) Do not build castles in the air.
('57', 4, 6, 30, 8759) Keep writing to me regularly.
('57', 4, 7, 31, 8789) Blessings from BAPU
('57', 4, 8, 32, 8809) From the Gujara ti origin al : S.N. 32940
('57', 5, 0, 1, 8851) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 5, 1, 2, 8891) 8. LETTER TO MATHURADAS TRIKUMJI
('57', 5, 2, 3, 8924) September 8, 1932 For exercise, pranayama done slowly and standing has wonderful effect.
('57', 5, 2, 4, 9013) It should be done slowly and methodically.
('57', 5, 2, 5, 9056) You have to keep time in pranayama as you have to in music.
('57', 5, 2, 6, 9116) The breathing must be rhythmic.
('57', 5, 2, 7, 9148) Once you have learnt to do this by practice, your lungs will have to do much less work and at the same time they will be able to inhale more oxygen.
('57', 5, 2, 8, 9297) As they inhale more oxygen, they exhale more carbon dioxide.
('57', 5, 2, 9, 9358) You can gradually increase the time of this exercise.
('57', 5, 2, 10, 9412) If it is done correctly, its beneficial effects will be felt immediately.
('57', 5, 2, 11, 9486) You will feel less tired, your appetite will improve, the mind will remain calm and, if the body is cold, it will become warm.
('57', 5, 2, 12, 9613) Yes, it is true that my reason does not accept the necessity of sex pleasure, and my view is confirmed by experience.
('57', 5, 2, 13, 9731) The dangerous thing about artificial means of birth control is that their acceptance implies the acceptance of the necessity of sex pleasure.
('57', 5, 2, 14, 9873) If the princ iple is universally adopted, that brahmacharya is desirable in all conditions, nobody would use artificial means of birth control.
('57', 5, 2, 15, 10017) As thefts will continue, though stealing is an anti social activity, so also it is likely that artifical means of birth control will continue to be used.
('57', 5, 2, 16, 10171) But it is necessary to create a climate of opinion in which they are regarded as undesirable.
('57', 5, 2, 17, 10265) Anybody who indulges in sex pleasure must accept the responsibility of progeny.
('57', 5, 2, 18, 10345) The hardships resulting from the birth of children must be borne.
('57', 5, 2, 19, 10411) It is only thus that one can learn the lesson of complete self control.
('57', 5, 2, 20, 10483) [From Gujarati]
('57', 5, 3, 21, 10499) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, p.

('57', 5, 8, 29, 10739) My time passes quite well.

('57', 5, 8, 31, 10835) Apart from the prescribed diet, I get one lb.
('57', 5, 8, 32, 10881) of milk.
('57', 5, 8, 33, 10890) I also get hot

('57', 6, 1, 2, 10953) water for both.

('57', 6, 1, 4, 11012) Hence, the weather will be less oppressive.
('57', 6, 1, 5, 11056) I have stopped taking rice and dal even after coming here.
('57', 6, 1, 6, 11115) Milk, wheat and vegetables are my chief food.
('57', 6, 1, 7, 11161) I sleep quite well.
('57', 6, 1, 8, 11181) I do not even spin at present because the Yeravda chakra is in disrepair.

('57', 7, 6, 7, 12571) 13. LETTER TO RAMSAY MACDONALD
('57', 7, 7, 8, 12602) September 9, 1932
('57', 7, 8, 9, 12620) DEAR FRIEND, I have to thank you for your frank and full letter telegraphed and received this day.
('57', 7, 8, 10, 12719) I am sorry, however, that you put upon the contemplated step 2 an interpretation that never crossed my mind.
('57', 7, 8, 11, 12828) I have claimed to speak on behalf of the very class to sacrifice whose interests you impute to me a desire to fast myself to death.
('57', 7, 8, 12, 12960) I had hoped that extreme step itself would effectively prevent any such selfish interpretation.
('57', 7, 8, 13, 13056) Without arguing I affirm that for me this matter is one of pure religion.
('57', 7, 8, 14, 13130) The mere fact of “Depressed” classes having double votes does not protect them or Hindu society in general from being disrupted.
('57', 7, 8, 15, 13259) In establishment of a separate electorate at all for “Depressed” classes I sense the injection of a poison that is calculated to destroy Hinduism and do no good whatsoever to “Depressed” classes.
('57', 7, 8, 16, 13455) You will please permit me to say that no matter how sympathetic you may be you cannot come to a correct decision on a matter of such vital and religious importance to the parties concerned.
('57', 7, 8, 17, 13645) I should not be against even over representation of “Depressed” Classes.
('57', 7, 8, 18, 13718) What I am against is their statutory separation, even in a limited form, from Hindu fold, so long as they choose to belong to it.
('57', 7, 8, 19, 13848) Do you not realize that if your decision stands and constitution comes into being, you arrest the marvellous growth of work of Hindu reformers who have dedicated themselves to the uplift of their suppressed brethren in every walk of life?
('57', 7, 9, 20, 14087) 1 Superintendent of the Yeravda Central Prison.
('57', 7, 9, 21, 14135) 2 Gandhiji had announced his intention to begin an indefinite fast from September 20 in protest against Government’s announcement providing for separate electorates for the Depressed Classes.
('57', 8, 0, 1, 14327) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 9
('57', 8, 1, 2, 14375) I have therefore been compelled reluctantly to adhere to the decision conveyed to you.
('57', 8, 1, 3, 14462) As your letter may give rise to a misunderstanding, I wish to state that the fact of my having isolated for special treatment the “Depressed” Classes question from other parts of your decision does not in any way mean I approve of or am reconciled to other parts of decision.
('57', 8, 1, 4, 14738) In my opinion many other parts are open to very grave objection.
('57', 8, 1, 5, 14803) Only I do not consider them to be any warrant for calling from me such self immolation as my conscience has prompted me to in the matter of “Deepressed” Classes.
('57', 8, 2, 6, 14965) I remain, Your faithful friend, M. K. GANDHI
('57', 8, 3, 7, 15010) Government of India, Home Department, Political, File No.
('57', 8, 3, 8, 15068) 31/113/32 Pol.
('57', 8, 3, 9, 15083) Courtesy: National Archives of India
('57', 8, 4, 10, 15120) 14. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('57', 8, 5, 11, 15150) September 9, 1932
('57', 8, 6, 12, 15168) NARANDAS, Please let me have the following information as soon as possible: 1. How much fuel is consumed in making rotlis and how much in making bread from the same quantity of flour?
('57', 8, 6, 13, 15352) 2. The method of making bread.
('57', 8, 6, 14, 15383) (a) How is the leaven prepared?
('57', 8, 6, 15, 15415) (b) In addition to leaven, do we mix salt, jaggery or sugar with the flour?
('57', 8, 6, 16, 15491) (c) The various steps of the process;
('57', 8, 7, 17, 15529) (d) How long is the dough left over?
('57', 8, 8, 18, 15566) (e) How long is the loaf kept in the oven?
('57', 8, 8, 19, 15609) In short, the description should be so written out that, after reading it, we can try the method here.
('57', 8, 8, 20, 15712) I want this information so that I may compare our method with the method followed here.
('57', 8, 8, 21, 15800) How much quantity of flour do you use these days for making bread?
('57', 8, 8, 22, 15867) What does the flour cost?
('57', 8, 8, 23, 15893) How many persons would have to work for making rotlis and for making bread from the same quantity of flour?

('57', 9, 4, 4, 16230) 15. LETTER TO BHAU PANSE September 9, 1932
('57', 9, 5, 5, 16273) BHAU, Do not brood over the deeper meaning of the Gita.
('57', 9, 5, 6, 16329) As you try to put into practice its teaching about non attachment, its deeper meaning will automatically reveal itself to you, and, when you understand it, you will be perfectly satisfied.
('57', 9, 5, 7, 16518) Meanwhile, you should have faith in the meaning explained by Vinoba.
('57', 9, 5, 8, 16587) Mostly my explanations are his.
('57', 9, 5, 9, 16619) Wherever you find a difference between us, you should tentatively accept the meaning which appeals to you.
('57', 9, 5, 10, 16726) There is no doubt at all that if you can spin with ease with a bamboo takli.
('57', 9, 5, 11, 16803) it is most suitable for the purpose.
('57', 9, 5, 12, 16840) You should also learn how to make such a takli.
('57', 9, 5, 13, 16888) If you have not tried enema for constipation, you should do so.
('57', 9, 5, 14, 16952) Sometimes it seems to help very much.
('57', 9, 5, 15, 16990) I get a little news about Wardha, but you also should give me in your letters whatever news you get there.
('57', 9, 5, 16, 17097) Do not lose hope about overcoming your constipation.
('57', 9, 7, 17, 17150) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 6736. Also C.W. 4479. Courtesy: Bhau Panse
('57', 9, 8, 18, 17232) 16. LETTER TO GANGABEHN VAIDYA
('57', 9, 9, 19, 17263) September 9, 1932
('57', 9, 10, 20, 17281) GANGABEHN, This time you wrote to me a long and beautiful letter.
('57', 9, 10, 21, 17347) I know, of course, that to you Hakimji is not merely a physician but is a brother, one of your family, a friend, a counsellor and a respected elder too.
('57', 9, 10, 22, 17500) It is, therefore, quite right that you take as much help from him as he can give.

('57', 16, 1, 31, 28528) If I believed that what I was trying to inculcate in you would bear no fruit, do you think I would take the trouble to write these long letters?
('57', 16, 1, 32, 28673) I do not know any instance of the cause of an individual’s or society’s fall having been discovered.
('57', 16, 1, 33, 28774) Many guesses, of course, have been made.

('57', 16, 1, 36, 29000) Political subjection can never be the root cause, for it is itself the result of other causes, other weaknesses.

('57', 17, 0, 1, 29192) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 17, 1, 2, 29233) One’s duty as a neighbour is always to help a neighbour in a manner consistent with dharma.
('57', 17, 1, 3, 29325) The seed of ego is destroyed only when one feels oneself to be a cipher.
('57', 17, 1, 4, 29398) If anyone looks inward and ponders deeply over the matter, he cannot but realize his total insignificance.
('57', 17, 1, 5, 29505) As we count an insect insignificant relatively to the earth, so is man insignificant in relation to this universe which is millions of times vaster than the earth.
('57', 17, 1, 6, 29669) That he is endowed with reason makes no difference to this fact.
('57', 17, 1, 7, 29734) His greatness lies in realizing his insignificance, for simultaneously with such realization, he realizes that, insignificant in himself, he is an insignificant aspect of God and that, when he merges in Him, he becomes God, that this microscopic atom which he is contains the infinite power of God.
('57', 17, 1, 8, 30033) I believe in the theory of maya in my own way.
('57', 17, 1, 9, 30080) In the cycle of Time this universe is maya, but, during the moment of time it exists, it is real enough.
('57', 17, 1, 10, 30185) I believe in the theory of the many sidedness of truth.
('57', 17, 1, 11, 30241) If there is anything in this world which faces man as a certainty, it is death.
('57', 17, 1, 12, 30321) And yet we fear that inescapable certainty; that is the greatest wonder of life, that is real attachment and that is atheism.
('57', 17, 1, 13, 30447) It is possibe only for man to rise above it.
('57', 17, 1, 14, 30492) One’s good and evil deeds do accompany the soul after the death of the body.
('57', 17, 1, 15, 30569) The soul, as soul, suffers their consequences, whether in another physical body or in a subtle body.
('57', 17, 1, 16, 30670) Isn’t this enough?

('57', 18, 4, 5, 31244) 28. LETTER TO PUSHPA S. PATEL
('57', 18, 5, 6, 31274) YERAVDA MANDIR, September 71, 1932
('57', 18, 6, 7, 31309) PUSHPA, Should not people living together give presents to one another?
('57', 18, 6, 8, 31381) What about the presents given by parents to their children on their birthdays or on festivals?
('57', 18, 6, 9, 31476) Besides, in the Ashram all live together.
('57', 18, 6, 10, 31518) But no one can take something belonging to another without his permission.

('57', 18, 6, 15, 31879) Real love is not in giving the present.
('57', 18, 6, 16, 31919) Love expresses itself spontaneously when the moment comes.

('57', 19, 0, 1, 32403) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 19, 1, 2, 32444) 30. A LETTER
('57', 19, 2, 3, 32457) September 11, 1932 You say that you are mentally disturbed and that, therefore, you will not write to me.
('57', 19, 2, 4, 32563) This too is a sign of vikar.
('57', 19, 2, 5, 32592) It is necessary to understand the exact meaning of this word.
('57', 19, 2, 6, 32654) Even being angry is vikar.
('57', 19, 2, 7, 32681) To feel all kinds of desires is also vikar.
('57', 19, 2, 8, 32725) To think of wearing this or that, eating or not eating this or that is vikar.
('57', 19, 2, 9, 32803) Similarly to wish to marry, or, even without wishing to marry, to feel pleasure in the company of boys of one’s own age, in talking with a boy in private and in touching him, or in unbecoming joking with him, that also is vikar.
('57', 19, 2, 10, 33032) This last is looked upon as a very serious vikar.
('57', 19, 2, 11, 33082) So long as a woman is subject to any of these vikars, she will be subject to menstruation.
('57', 19, 2, 12, 33173) In the case of man it is not menstruation, but something else.
('57', 19, 2, 13, 33236) In this sense even Mirabehn cannot be considered to be free from vikar.
('57', 19, 2, 14, 33308) So she still has menstruation.
('57', 19, 2, 15, 33339) She does not sin in this.
('57', 19, 2, 16, 33365) She has indeed risen very high.
('57', 19, 2, 17, 33397) She is continually striving to overcome all her vikars.
('57', 19, 2, 18, 33453) The vikar of desire for man has completely disappeared from within her.
('57', 19, 2, 19, 33525) But she still has anger and attachment, and desires.
('57', 19, 2, 20, 33578) All these too she strives to control.
('57', 19, 2, 21, 33616) If a woman attains a state free from vikars,such as I have described, she will not get monthly periods.
('57', 19, 2, 22, 33720) I would be happy if all of you girls were to strive to attain such a state.
('57', 19, 2, 23, 33796) Even if you do not succeed in your present life, what does it matter?
('57', 19, 2, 24, 33866) The first lesson for you to learn is to keep nothing secret.

('57', 21, 4, 5, 37283) 32. WORKING AND THINKING 2
('57', 21, 5, 6, 37310) September 11, 1932 I wrote some time ago about fully using our power of thinking when doing any work.
('57', 21, 5, 7, 37412) 3 I said something towards the end in that article, which it is necessary to explain further.
('57', 21, 5, 8, 37506) I suggested there that our thinking may be either conducive to or destructive of the general good, that, in other words, it may be either divine or demoniac in nature.
('57', 21, 5, 9, 37674) One person, as he spins daily, may think and try to invent improvements which would benefit the millions of spinners and make their work easier.
('57', 21, 5, 10, 37819) Another person may think how fine it would be if he alone could spin on his wheel as much yarn as ten million persons and get rich.
('57', 21, 5, 11, 37951) The thinking of the former is divine in nature, it is conducive to the good of society.
('57', 21, 5, 12, 38039) The thinking of the second person is demoniac, it is opposed to the good of society.
('57', 21, 5, 13, 38124) Thus, it is not enough that we should think when doing any work.
('57', 21, 5, 14, 38189) Our thinking should aim at the good of all,and not at satisfying our own selfish desires.
('57', 21, 5, 15, 38279) Indeed he who tries to serve only his selfish interests not only harms the good of others but in the end does not serve even his own good.
('57', 21, 5, 16, 38418) If everybody keeps this point of view before him and thinks about the work he is doing, and so works intelligently, he would get the best education, would find his work interesting, develop his intellect, enlarge and purify his heart, acquire efficiency in his work and make inventions and improvements which would benefit the world.
('57', 21, 5, 17, 38752) As the work has become more interesting it gives him joy; he feels no fatigue in doing it and the work becomes artistic whether it is cleaning lavatories or roads, shredding vegetables, anything connected with the dairy, writing accounts or something else.
('57', 21, 5, 18, 39009) A person who
('57', 21, 6, 19, 39022) 1 A Political prisoner connected with terrorist activities incarcerated then in the Multan Jail.
('57', 21, 6, 20, 39119) 2 This was presumably sent along with “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, [7]/ 11 9 1932; vide the following item.
('57', 21, 6, 21, 39227) 3 Vide Action —Thoughtful and Thoughtless”, 28 8 1932.
('57', 22, 0, 1, 39282) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 23
('57', 22, 1, 2, 39331) learns to look at everything from the point of view of public good finds no work low or uninteresting.
('57', 22, 1, 3, 39434) He will see God in any work which comes to his share and feel that he was serving Him through it.
('57', 22, 1, 4, 39532) His interest in work does not depend on the nature or type of thework.
('57', 22, 1, 5, 39603) It springs from within, from his sense of devotion to duty.
('57', 22, 1, 6, 39663) Anybody who wants to understand and practice Anasaktiyoga should do all work in this spirit.

('57', 25, 4, 7, 46220) 34. A LETTER
('57', 25, 5, 8, 46233) September 11, 1932
('57', 25, 6, 9, 46252) God and Nature are one.
('57', 25, 6, 10, 46276) The various gods are the individual manifestations of God.
('57', 25, 6, 11, 46335) One can reach God worshipping Him.
('57', 25, 6, 12, 46370) In depicting the importance of action Tulsidasji has extolled Divine justice.
('57', 25, 6, 13, 46448) God condones the sins of the devotee.
('57', 25, 6, 14, 46486) In the language of the Shastra the devotee is purified when he becomes one with God.
('57', 25, 6, 15, 46571) Purificaton means removal of sins, like alloys from gold.
('57', 25, 6, 16, 46629) A saint living in seclusion can perform service by thought alone; there is only one such man in a million.
('57', 25, 6, 17, 46736) The very existence of body stands in the way of total ahimsa.
('57', 25, 6, 18, 46798) And without complete ahimsa one is unable to see Truth.
('57', 25, 6, 19, 46854) But one who has rid himself of passions comes very near to Truth.
('57', 25, 6, 20, 46920) We should be content with this.
('57', 25, 6, 21, 46952) Up to now by punishment I have understood corporal punishment.
('57', 25, 6, 22, 47015) Abstaining from food has not been beyond my thought.
('57', 25, 6, 23, 47068) I would not call that a punishment.
('57', 25, 6, 24, 47104) No one in any institution has an absolute right to food; it is a question of arriving at an arrangement.
('57', 25, 6, 25, 47209) There is on the one hand the condition that rules are to be observed and on the other hand that food is to be supplied.
('57', 25, 6, 26, 47329) Money is no payment for the food we receive in an institution.
('57', 25, 6, 27, 47392) Rules have to be observed in exchange.
('57', 25, 6, 28, 47431) Fear and truth are mutually contradictory terms.
('57', 25, 6, 29, 47480) But to conceal something which does not contain any element of fear may be not only in conformity with truth but also necessary.
('57', 25, 6, 30, 47609) A physician may certainly, in the interest of the patient’s health, conceal from him the gravity of his illness.
('57', 25, 6, 31, 47722) It may even be his duty.
('57', 25, 6, 32, 47747) A perfect brahmachari is one who has all the senses under his control.
('57', 25, 6, 33, 47818) This state is possible even in this body.
('57', 25, 6, 34, 47860) Regulating diet is
('57', 26, 0, 1, 47879) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 27

('57', 27, 12, 22, 50479) 38. LETTER TO MOHANLAL M. BHATT
('57', 27, 13, 23, 50511) September 13, 1932 I believe that that is my supreme dharma.
('57', 27, 13, 24, 50572) Hence, neither Ramdas nor any of you should feel unhappy.
('57', 27, 13, 25, 50630) On the contrary, you should rejoice and thank God for His kindness that one of your co workers has been inspired to take the ultimate step in dharma and has got an opportunity to do that.
('57', 27, 13, 26, 50818) I hope all of you understand that nobody should imitate me.
('57', 27, 13, 27, 50878) Everybody is not fit to undertake an indefinite fast.
('57', 27, 13, 28, 50932) And the tapas performed by a person who is not fit for it is not in accord with the Shastra and is therefore demoniac.
('57', 27, 13, 29, 51051) His only reward for such tapas is physical suffering.
('57', 27, 13, 30, 51105) Your duty, therefore, is to do your work with greater devotion, to become purer and to remain
('57', 27, 14, 31, 51199) 1 From Mahadevbhaini Diary.
('57', 27, 14, 32, 51227) 2 C.F. Andrews had cabled: “Please postpone fasting till I come.
('57', 27, 14, 33, 51292) Starting imme diately.”
('57', 28, 0, 1, 51316) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 29
('57', 28, 1, 2, 51365) more vigilant, without thinking or worrying about my fast.
('57', 28, 2, 3, 51424) Nobody should get excited there.
('57', 28, 2, 4, 51457) Have no doubt that, for those who live in the Ashram, there is no other duty but what I have explained.
('57', 28, 3, 5, 51561) Rebirth means transformation of the body—not of the atman which dwells in the body.
('57', 28, 3, 6, 51645) Hence belief in rebirth differs from a scientific concept.
('57', 28, 3, 7, 51704) The atman does not undergo transformation, it only changes its abode.
('57', 28, 3, 8, 51774) One who does not regard himself as the doer will never kill anybody.
('57', 28, 3, 9, 51843) This is not a matter of intellectual conviction, it concerns the heart.
('57', 28, 3, 10, 51915) It is, therefore, incorrect to speak of “without thinking of oneself as the doer” or “dedicating a thing to the Lord”.
('57', 28, 3, 11, 52034) These phrases signify intellectual attitudes whereas the advice in the Gita and other scriptures to dedicate everything to the Lord has no reference to the intellect.
('57', 28, 3, 12, 52201) Our activities are in perfect accord with Vedanta as I understand it.
('57', 28, 3, 13, 52271) [From Gujarati]
('57', 28, 4, 14, 52287) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.
('57', 28, 5, 15, 52321) 39. LETTER TO DEVDAS GANDHI
('57', 28, 6, 16, 52349) September 13, 1932 The country now knows about my intention to go on an indefinite fast.
('57', 28, 6, 17, 52438) I assume that the news has not upset you in the slightest degree.
('57', 28, 6, 18, 52504) One does not get such a unique opportunity by seeking it.
('57', 28, 6, 19, 52562) It comes rarely, and only to a fortunate man.
('57', 28, 6, 20, 52608) I believe that such an opportunity has come to me, and anybody who believes that he has got a unique opportunity would welcome it heartily.
('57', 28, 6, 21, 52748) Hence you need not feel agitated.
('57', 28, 6, 22, 52782) If you meet Ghanshyamdas in Calcutta, explain this to him.
('57', 28, 6, 23, 52841) It will not be necessary to explain to Malaviyaji.
('57', 28, 6, 24, 52892) I believe that he must be shedding tears of joy at the news and that every moment his heart must be blessing me.
('57', 28, 6, 25, 53005) Tell him this.
('57', 28, 6, 26, 53020) If other friends feel sad or depressed, you should show courage and persuade them not to give way to such thoughts.
('57', 28, 6, 27, 53136) It will be the duty of those who appreciate my step to address themselves more earnestly to the task, to awaken the people to the evil of untouchability and to organize public opinion.
('57', 28, 6, 28, 53321) If a strong public opinion is organized and expressed peacefully, I may

('57', 29, 3, 8, 54074) 40. LETTER TO KASTURBA GANDHI
('57', 29, 4, 9, 54104) September 13, 1932 I have your letter.
('57', 29, 4, 10, 54143) You have probably heard about my fast.
('57', 29, 4, 11, 54182) Do not get frightened in the slightest degree by the news and also do not let the other women get frightened.
('57', 29, 4, 12, 54292) Indeed, you should rejoice that God has granted me an opportunity to go through such an ordeal for the sake of dharma.
('57', 29, 4, 13, 54411) I also hope that you have understood the meaning of this fast.
('57', 29, 4, 14, 54474) I shall not have to start the fast if my demands regarding the Antyajas are accepted, and even if I have started it I can end it.
('57', 29, 4, 15, 54604) If, however, I have to carry it on till the end, you should indeed thank God.
('57', 29, 4, 16, 54682) Only one in millions meets death for which he has prayed.
('57', 29, 4, 17, 54740) What a good fortune it would be if I met such a death!
('57', 29, 4, 18, 54795) And if I do not die, it is clear as daylight that it would then be my moral duty to purify myself still further and to devote myself more to service.
('57', 29, 4, 19, 54945) I think that after having lived with me for fifty years you will be able clearly to understand this simple thing and willingly follow me.
('57', 29, 4, 20, 55083) [From Gujarati]

('57', 29, 6, 22, 55133) 41. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('57', 29, 7, 23, 55163) September 13, 1932
('57', 29, 8, 24, 55182) NARANDAS, You must have read in the papers the news about my indefinite fast.
('57', 29, 8, 25, 55260) I assume that it has not created a panic among the inmates of the Ashram.
('57', 29, 8, 26, 55334) If they see the matter in the proper light, this should be for them an occasion for rejoicing.
('57', 29, 8, 27, 55429) A total fast is the ultimate and the highest ideal of the Ashram, but very few persons ever become worthy of the privilege of undertaking it.
('57', 29, 8, 28, 55571) Such a fast is not an everyday
('57', 30, 0, 1, 55602) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 31
('57', 30, 1, 2, 55651) occurrence.
('57', 30, 1, 3, 55663) Only a rare person on a rare occasion is entitled to undertake it; I believe that I am on this occasion.
('57', 30, 1, 4, 55768) If I am wrong, people will judge my step as a sign of false pride and an instance of demoniac self mortification.
('57', 30, 1, 5, 55882) I claim nearly half a century of ceaseless effort to purify my mind completely so that I may be able to hear the voice within.
('57', 30, 1, 6, 56009) I believe that as a result I can now hear it with some distinctness.
('57', 30, 1, 7, 56078) I have taken the present step in obedience to that voice.
('57', 30, 1, 8, 56136) The 20th is still a little way away.
('57', 30, 1, 9, 56173) At present the decision to fast is only a resolve.
('57', 30, 1, 10, 56224) I am writing this letter to explain that resolve, and to tell all of you that nobody there should get panicky, but that the news should make everybody more devoted to his or her work, purer and more awake.
('57', 30, 1, 11, 56430) I am sure you yourself do realize that nobody should follow my example and undertake a similar fast.
('57', 30, 1, 12, 56531) Explain that to others, too.
('57', 30, 1, 13, 56560) I hope nobody there will wonder why I kept my intention to fast to myself and did not let it become known beyond our circle of three.
('57', 30, 1, 14, 56694) It is a rule for prisoners that they must not make public the fact of such correspondence.
('57', 30, 1, 15, 56785) If I even wish in my heart to make it public indirectly, I would disgrace my satyagraha and there would be a blot on the purity of my vow of truth.
('57', 30, 1, 16, 56933) The value of that vow lies in the perfect purity in its observance.
('57', 30, 1, 17, 57001) I got your weekly packet.
('57', 30, 1, 18, 57027) I believe that this time at least I shall be able to send the replies.
('57', 30, 1, 19, 57098) I am slightly doubtful because during the days which remain the work is likely to be heavier.
('57', 30, 1, 20, 57192) If there is any development about which I can write to you, I will do so.
('57', 30, 1, 21, 57266) You can show this letter to all persons who have connections with the Ashram.
('57', 30, 1, 22, 57344) Tell Anandi that I intend to write a long letter to her.
('57', 30, 1, 23, 57401) I liked hers very much.
('57', 30, 1, 24, 57425) She should have no fear.
('57', 30, 1, 25, 57450) You should teach all girls to be fearless.
('57', 30, 1, 26, 57493) If people there are in the habit of whispering among themselves about any girl, it is a bad habit.
('57', 30, 1, 27, 57592) What is fated to happen to us and the girls will happen.
('57', 30, 1, 28, 57649) We should not feel suspicious about them all the time and fill them with fear.
('57', 30, 1, 29, 57728) When we see cause for cautioning any of them, we may do so and then should not think about the matter further.
('57', 30, 1, 30, 57839) The girls should never feel that they are being suppressed in any way.
('57', 30, 1, 31, 57910) Any restraints which are put on them should be explained to them and should be imposed in such a manner that they willingly accept them.
('57', 30, 1, 32, 58047) Personally, I think you have done the right thing in permitting Hariyomal to return.
('57', 30, 1, 33, 58132) I hope Baba has completely recovered now.
('57', 30, 2, 34, 58174) Blessings from BAPU From a microfilm of the Gujarati: M.M.U./I. Also C.W. 8251. Courtesy: Narandas Gandhi

('57', 33, 1, 2, 61562) 47. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('57', 33, 2, 3, 61585) September 15, 1932 CHI.
('57', 33, 2, 4, 61609) MIRA, I had been waiting for your letter.
('57', 33, 2, 5, 61651) It arrived today.
('57', 33, 2, 6, 61669) I am glad you have understood the reason for the fast.
('57', 33, 2, 7, 61724) There was no escape from it.
('57', 33, 2, 8, 61753) It is both a privilege and a duty.
('57', 33, 2, 9, 61788) It comes rarely to someone in a generation or generations.
('57', 33, 2, 10, 61847) In non violence it is the crowning act, if it is saturated with that spirit and the cause has no trace of self.
('57', 33, 2, 11, 61959) I ask you, therefore, to rejoice with me that such an occasion seems to have come to me.
('57', 33, 2, 12, 62048) I say ‘seems’ for my faith has yet to be tried.
('57', 33, 2, 13, 62096) No one can dare talk of his own strength in a matter of life and death.The question, therefore, is whether I am found worthy of the needed strength and also whether the cause is of the required purity and thirdly, whether in truth I am free of every trace of violence in undertaking the vow.
('57', 33, 2, 14, 62388) When I say that I feel like all that, I merely statemy belief.
('57', 33, 2, 15, 62451) Judgment can be pronounced only upon the completed act.
('57', 33, 2, 16, 62507) I want you to watch the progress of the event without the slightest perturbation.
('57', 33, 2, 17, 62589) Nor may you at any stage fast in sympathy.
('57', 33, 2, 18, 62632) Yours is to be buried in your own task which is to go through your term in full resignation, making the best use possible of every moment at your disposal.
('57', 33, 2, 19, 62788) I do not mind the drop in your weight if you are otherwise well and fit.
('57', 33, 2, 20, 62861) The weight will come gradually as you become acclimatized there and the weather improves, which it will not do for yet another month.
('57', 33, 2, 21, 62995) For me, I am as fit as a fiddle.
('57', 33, 2, 22, 63028) Just now my food is brown bread, milk, a vegetable, local dates (not bad) and musambis.
('57', 33, 2, 23, 63116) I am glad Kisen is with you.
('57', 33, 2, 24, 63145) You must be a fair size family now.
('57', 33, 2, 25, 63181) I know that you had naturally the art of looking upon trees and animals as friends.
('57', 33, 2, 26, 63265) I wanted you to extend the idea so as not to feel the want of friends from outside.
('57', 33, 2, 27, 63349) Hence my mention of strangers in the same category.
('57', 33, 2, 28, 63401) That is to say, there should be a definite realization that personal friends and relations are no greater friends than strangers of the human family and bird, beast and plant.
('57', 33, 2, 29, 63577) They are all one, and they are all an expression of God if we would but realize the fact.
('57', 33, 2, 30, 63667) Such definite realization assuages all craving for seeing outside friends when we are inside prison walls.
('57', 33, 2, 31, 63774) The news you have from England about the family is cheering.
('57', 33, 2, 32, 63835) Send my love to them all when you write.

('57', 34, 4, 17, 64711) September 15, 1932 I think Satyavan’s 1 problem is simple.
('57', 34, 4, 18, 64770) No person can go beyond his or her limits.
('57', 34, 4, 19, 64813) You cannot force anyone to be chaste.
('57', 34, 4, 20, 64851) He or she must have the inner conviction.
('57', 34, 4, 21, 64893) You can give him the fullest freedom to separate himself from you and get a divorce decree if necessary.
('57', 34, 4, 22, 64998) He must be at liberty to marry some other woman of his choice.
('57', 34, 4, 23, 65061) It is most dangerous to have a carnal mind constantly brooding over satisfaction of animal passion.
('57', 34, 4, 24, 65161) You must surround him with all the affection you can give him and not judge him harshly.
('57', 34, 4, 25, 65250) It is to his credit that he has striven all these years to control himself.
('57', 34, 4, 26, 65326) Of course if you have the slightest desire to satisfy his craving, you should regard yourself at liberty to do so.
('57', 34, 4, 27, 65441) For you both came to a joint conclusion about self control.
('57', 34, 4, 28, 65501) If now one party wishes to revise the agreement, the other may also, if there is the desire.
('57', 34, 4, 29, 65594) Whereas if you are satisfied that you have no craving at all, you must resist every entreaty from Satyavan as lovingly as possible, but with the utmost firmness.
('57', 34, 4, 30, 65756) Let him read this letter.

('57', 38, 4, 13, 70584) 56. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('57', 38, 5, 14, 70611) September 16, 1932 1
('57', 38, 6, 15, 70632) The fast which I am approaching was resolved upon in the name of God for His work and, as I believed in all humility, at His call.
('57', 38, 6, 16, 70763) Friends have urged me to postpone the date for the sake of giving the public a chance to organize itself.
('57', 38, 6, 17, 70869) I am sorry it is not open to me to change even the hour, except for the reason stated in my letter to the Prime Minister.
('57', 38, 7, 18, 70991) The impending fast is against those who have faith in me, whether Indians or foreigners, and for those who have it not.
('57', 38, 7, 19, 71111) Therefore it is not against the English official world, but it is against those Englishmen and women who in spite of the contrary teaching of
('57', 38, 8, 20, 71253) 1 According to a report in The Bombay Chronicle, 22 9 1932, and The Epic Fast, the statement was sent to the Government of Bombay on September 15 for being released to the Press.
('57', 38, 8, 21, 71432) However, the statement signed by Gandhiji bears the date “16 9 32” in his own handwriting.
('57', 38, 8, 22, 71523) Vide also the following item.
('57', 38, 8, 23, 71553) 2 The reason stated was: “The fast will cease if during its progress, the British Government of its own motion or under pressure of public opinion revise their decision and withdraw their scheme of communal electorates for the ‘depressed’ classes, whose representatives should be elected by the general electorate under the common franchise no matter how wide it is.” Vide “Letter to Ramsay Macdonald”, 18 8 1932. For Gandhiji’s further views on the Communal Award and Untouchability, Vide Appendix “Discussion with Vallabhbhai Patel”, 6 9 1932.
('57', 39, 0, 1, 72099) 40 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 39, 1, 2, 72140) the official world, believe in me and the justice of the cause I represent.
('57', 39, 1, 3, 72216) Nor is it against those of my countrymen who have no faith in me, whether they be Hindus or others; but it is against those countless Indians (no matter to what persuasion they belong) who believe that I represent a just cause.
('57', 39, 1, 4, 72444) Above all, it is intended to sting the Hindu conscience into right religious action.
('57', 39, 1, 5, 72529) The contemplated fast is no appeal to mere emotion.
('57', 39, 1, 6, 72581) By the fast I want to throw the whole of my weight (such as it is) in the scales of justice pure and simple.
('57', 39, 1, 7, 72690) Therefore, there need be no undue haste or feverish anxiety to save my life.
('57', 39, 1, 8, 72767) I implicitly believe in the truth of the saying that not a blade of grass moves but by His will.
('57', 39, 1, 9, 72864) He will save it if He needs it for further service in this body.
('57', 39, 1, 10, 72929) None can save it against His will.
('57', 39, 1, 11, 72964) Humanly speaking, I believe it will stand the strain for some time.
('57', 39, 1, 12, 73032) The separate electorate is merely the last straw.
('57', 39, 1, 13, 73082) No patched up agreement between caste Hindu leaders and rival “depressed” class leaders will answer the purpose.
('57', 39, 1, 14, 73195) The agreement to be valid has got to be real.
('57', 39, 1, 15, 73241) If the Hindu mass mind is not yet prepared to banish untouchability root and branch, it must sacrifice me without the slightest hesitation.
('57', 39, 1, 16, 73381) There should be no coercion of those who are opposed to joint electorates.
('57', 39, 1, 17, 73456) I have no difficulty in understanding their bitter opposition.
('57', 39, 1, 18, 73519) They have every right to distrust me.
('57', 39, 1, 19, 73557) Do I not belong to that Hindu section miscalled a superior class, or caste Hindus, who have ground down to powder the so called untouchables?
('57', 39, 1, 20, 73699) The marvel is that the latter have remained nevertheless in the Hindu fold.
('57', 39, 1, 21, 73775) But whilst I can justify this opposition, I believe that they are in error.
('57', 39, 1, 22, 73851) They will, if they can, separate the “depressed” class entirely from the Hindu society and form them into a separate class—a standing and living reproach to Hinduism.
('57', 39, 1, 23, 74018) I should not mind if thereby their interests could be really served.
('57', 39, 1, 24, 74087) But my intimate acquaintance with every shade of untouch ability convinces me that their lives, such as they are, are so intimately mixed with those of the caste Hindus in whose midst and for whom they live, that it is impossible to separate them.
('57', 39, 1, 25, 74335) They are part of an indivisible family.
('57', 39, 1, 26, 74375) Their revolt against the Hindus with whom they live and their apostasy from Hinduism I should understand.
('57', 39, 1, 27, 74481) But this so far as I can see they will not do.
('57', 39, 1, 28, 74528) There is a subtle something—quite indefinable— in Hinduism which keeps them in it even in spite of themselves.
('57', 40, 0, 1, 74639) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 41
('57', 40, 1, 2, 74688) And this fact makes it imperative for a man like me, with a living experience of it, to resist the contemplated separation even though the effort should cost life itself.
('57', 40, 1, 3, 74859) The implications of this resistance are tremendous.
('57', 40, 1, 4, 74911) No comp romise which does not ensure the full freedom for the “depressed classes” inside the Hindu fold can be an adequate substitute for the contemplated separation.
('57', 40, 1, 5, 75078) Any betrayal of the trust can merely postpone the day of immolation for me and henceforth for those who think with me.
('57', 40, 1, 6, 75197) The problem before responsible Hindus is to consider whether in the event of social, civic or political persecution of the “depressed” classes they are prepared to face satyagraha in the shape of perpetual fast, not of one reformer like me, but an increasing army of reformers whom I believe to exist today in India and who will count their lives of no cost to achieve the liberation of these classes and therethrough [rid] Hinduism of an age long superstition.
('57', 40, 1, 7, 75659) Let fellow reformers who have worked with me also appreciate the implications of the fast.
('57', 40, 1, 8, 75750) It is either a hallucination of mine or an illumination.
('57', 40, 1, 9, 75807) If it is the former, I must be allowed to do my penance in peace.
('57', 40, 1, 10, 75873) It will be the lifting of a dead weight on Hinduism.
('57', 40, 1, 11, 75926) If it is an illumination, may my agony purify Hinduism and even melt the hearts of those who are at present disposed to distrust me.
('57', 40, 1, 12, 76059) Since there appears to be a misunderstanding as to the application of my fast, I may repeat that it is aimed at a statutory separate electorate, in any shape or form, for the “depressed” classes.
('57', 40, 1, 13, 76255) Immediately that threat is removed once for all, my fast will end.
('57', 40, 1, 14, 76322) I hold strong views about reservation of seats, as also about the most proper method of dealing with the whole question.
('57', 40, 1, 15, 76443) But I consider myself unfit as a prisoner to set forth my proposals.
('57', 40, 1, 16, 76512) I should however abide by an agreement on the basis of joint electorate that may be arrived at between the responsible leaders of caste Hindus and the “depressed” classes and which has been accepted by mass meetings of all Hindus.
('57', 40, 1, 17, 76743) One thing I must make clear.
('57', 40, 1, 18, 76772) The satisfactory ending to the “depressed” classes question, if it is to come, should in no way mean that I would be committed to the acceptance of His Majesty’s Government’s decision on the other parts of the communal question.
('57', 40, 1, 19, 77001) I am personally opposed to many other parts of it, which to my mind make the working of any free and democratic constitution well nigh impossible, nor would a satisfactory solution of this question in any
('57', 41, 0, 1, 77206) 42 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 41, 1, 2, 77247) way bind me to accept the constitution that may be framed.
('57', 41, 1, 3, 77306) These are political questions for the National Congress to consider and determine.
('57', 41, 1, 4, 77389) They are utterly outside my province in my individual capacity.
('57', 41, 1, 5, 77453) Nor may I as a prisoner air my individual views on these questions.
('57', 41, 1, 6, 77521) My fast has a narrow application.
('57', 41, 1, 7, 77555) The “depressed” classes question being predominantly a religious matter, I regard it as specially my own by reason of my lifelong concentration on it.
('57', 41, 1, 8, 77706) It is a sacred personal trust which I may not shirk.
('57', 41, 1, 9, 77759) The fasting for light and penance is a hoary institution.
('57', 41, 1, 10, 77817) I have observed it in Christianity and Islam.
('57', 41, 1, 11, 77863) Hinduism is replete with instances of fasting for purification and penance.
('57', 41, 1, 12, 77939) But it is a privilege, if it is also a duty.
('57', 41, 1, 13, 77984) Moreover, to the best of my light, I have reduced it to a science.
('57', 41, 1, 14, 78051) As an expert, therefore, I would warn friends and sympathizers against copying me blindly or out of false or hysterical sympathy.
('57', 41, 1, 15, 78181) Let all such qualify themselves by hard work and selfless service of the “untouchables” and they would have independent light if their time for fasting has come.
('57', 41, 1, 16, 78343) Lastly, in so far as I know myself this fast is being undertaken with the purest of motives and without malice or anger to any single soul.
('57', 41, 1, 17, 78483) For me it is an expression of, and the last seal on, non violence.
('57', 41, 1, 18, 78550) Those, therefore, who would use violence in this controversy against those whom they may consider to be inimical to me or the cause I represent will simply hasten my end.
('57', 41, 1, 19, 78721) Perfect courtesy and conside ration towards opponents is an absolute essential of success in this case 1 at least if not in all cases.
('57', 41, 1, 20, 78856) M. K. GANDHI

('57', 47, 0, 1, 86130) 48 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 47, 1, 2, 86171) You have every right to call upon me to revise my decisions and actions and it is my duty to respond, if I discover the error.
('57', 47, 1, 3, 86298) And I claim unquestioned ‘obedience’ if I cannot with all the prayerful effort discover any error.
('57', 47, 1, 4, 86397) You have ‘manfully’ asserted the right and woman like offered obedience.
('57', 47, 1, 5, 86470) The motherly affection has blinded the poetic vision and prom pted you to appeal to my pride to retrace my steps so as to make me cling to life.
('57', 47, 1, 6, 86615) But I know you have not missed the woman in me.
('57', 47, 1, 7, 86663) I have therefore chosen the way of life through suffering unto death.
('57', 47, 1, 8, 86733) I must therefore find my courage in my weakness.
('57', 47, 1, 9, 86782) This is how your vision has failed you.
('57', 47, 1, 10, 86822) The communal decision was the last straw.
('57', 47, 1, 11, 86864) The conception of giving my life for the untouchables is not of yesterday.
('57', 47, 1, 12, 86939) It is very old.
('57', 47, 1, 13, 86955) There was no call from within for years.
('57', 47, 1, 14, 86996) But the Cabinet’s decision came like a violent alarm waking me from my slumber and telling me this is the time.
('57', 47, 1, 15, 87108) It therefore provided the psychological moment and I instinctively seized it.
('57', 47, 1, 16, 87186) The necessarily restricted wording of my official letter covers in their implications the very things you would have me to die for and to live for—one and the same thing in essence.
('57', 47, 1, 17, 87368) She who sees life in death and death in life is the real Poetess and Seeress.
('57', 47, 1, 18, 87446) But the proof of the pudding is in the eating.
('57', 47, 1, 19, 87493) You will soon test it and prove it for yourself.
('57', 47, 1, 20, 87542) Meanwhile pray that God may give me strength enough to walk steadily through the vale.
('57', 47, 1, 21, 87629) If Hinduism is to live, untouchability must die.
('57', 47, 1, 22, 87678) It may be that this is my last letter to you.
('57', 47, 1, 23, 87724) I have always known and treasured your love.
('57', 47, 1, 24, 87769) I think that I understood you when I first saw you and heard you at the Criterion in 1914. If I die I shall die in the faith that comrades like you, with whom God has blessed me, will continue the work of the country which is also fully the work of humanity in the same spirit in which it was begun.
('57', 47, 1, 25, 88069) If the interests of the country are to be one with those of humanity, if the good of one faith is to be the good of all faiths, it will come only by the strictest adherence to truth and non violence in thought, word and deed.
('57', 47, 1, 26, 88295) And now for a little lesson in recognizing one’s limitations.
('57', 47, 1, 27, 88357) You may be a good confectioner, but you need not therefore presume to be a good baker or a judge of good bread.
('57', 47, 1, 28, 88469) Well, my brown bread is really superior to your ‘good white bread’.
('57', 47, 1, 29, 88537) And there is an interesting, instructive history behind it, which you should get Major
('57', 48, 0, 1, 88624) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 49
('57', 48, 1, 2, 88673) Bhandari to relate to you, if he will.
('57', 48, 1, 3, 88712) Anyway there was to be a choice between my delicious and digestible brown bread and leathery chapati.
('57', 48, 1, 4, 88814) Those who were doomed to these chapatis have chosen the brown loaf.
('57', 48, 1, 5, 88882) I accept your apology in anticipation.
('57', 48, 2, 6, 88921) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.
('57', 48, 3, 7, 88955) 73. LETTER TO NARAYANRAO DESAI

('57', 48, 8, 17, 89449) 74. LETTER TO BARJORJI F. BHARUCHA
('57', 48, 9, 18, 89484) September 17, 1932
('57', 48, 10, 19, 89503) BHAI BARJORJI, I was not surprised to get your wire.
('57', 48, 10, 20, 89556) But the truth is that no person can resolve on an indefinite fast relying on his own strength, and that if he does so he must be an ignorant man.
('57', 48, 10, 21, 89702) For myself at any rate I can say that I did not take the vow, but that God inspired me to take it.
('57', 48, 10, 22, 89801) The date too was fixed by Him, and so also the conditions under which the date could be changed.
('57', 48, 10, 23, 89898) Your appeal is not covered by those conditions.
('57', 48, 10, 24, 89946) What can I do now?
('57', 48, 10, 25, 89965) Another simple thing is this: a prisoner cannot himself comm unicate anything to the world outside.
('57', 48, 10, 26, 90065) Hence, it would have been a sin for me, a satyagrahi, to convey indirectly to the nation even the slightest hint of what I had in my mind.
('57', 48, 10, 27, 90204) A satyagrahi prisoner
('57', 48, 11, 28, 90226) 1Vide “Statement to the Press”, 16 9 1932.
('57', 49, 0, 1, 90269) 50 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 49, 1, 2, 90310) voluntarily obeys prison rules and, if it becomes necessary for him to disobey any of them, he can only do so openly.
('57', 49, 1, 3, 90428) Thus, the notice given by me as a prisoner to the Government should be regarded as a notice given to the people also.
('57', 49, 1, 4, 90546) That is, it was for the Government to decide whether it would inform the public about my intention.
('57', 49, 1, 5, 90646) If the people did not know of it earlier, we should interpret the fact only to mean that God did not intend the people to know it earlier.
('57', 49, 1, 6, 90785) How can I postpone the date of the fast in order to give time to the people?
('57', 49, 1, 7, 90862) Why should not those who have faith in God rather think that if it is His will that I should serve more yet, He would in spite of the fast spare my life for as long as may be necessary?
('57', 49, 1, 8, 91048) And you certainly have faith in God.
('57', 49, 1, 9, 91085) You should, therefore, try to understand what I have said in this letter and explain it to the men and women who get agitated over my decision and give them courage.
('57', 49, 1, 10, 91251) My co workers’ duty at present is to go on vigorously with the work that now faces us.
('57', 49, 1, 11, 91338) The result is in God’s hands.
('57', 49, 1, 12, 91368) Remember this, that my fast cannot be, and certainly is not, intended for putting pressure on any party.
('57', 49, 1, 13, 91473) Its purpose is only to see that what is in the best interests of the Antyajas themselves is done.
('57', 49, 1, 14, 91571) If what seems proper to me does not appear so to others, they should indeed continue their opposition.
('57', 49, 1, 15, 91674) Such pure fast for a public cause should aim at bringing about an awakening in the nation and should not, at any rate, be used ignorantly to lead the people on a wrong path.
('57', 49, 1, 16, 91848) If, in my ignorance, I try through a fast to make the nation agree to an improper demand, I am sure that the nation ought not to yield to such a demand merely for sparing my life, no matter how much it is convinced of my services to it in the past.
('57', 49, 1, 17, 92097) Not only the good of the nation, but my own good too, lies in its not yielding to an improper demand by me.
('57', 49, 1, 18, 92205) [From Gujarati]
('57', 49, 2, 19, 92221) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.

('57', 50, 4, 10, 93107) 76. LETTER TO DARBARI SADHU
('57', 50, 5, 11, 93135) September 17, 1932 I am afraid we shall not be able to meet now.
('57', 50, 5, 12, 93200) Still, do write to me and ask me if you can come.
('57', 50, 5, 13, 93250) I will see if I can let you.
('57', 50, 5, 14, 93279) If, however, that is not possible, then think that nothing is gained by meeting an image of clay.
('57', 50, 5, 15, 93377) It is the minds and the hearts that meet and they have the power to meet in a secend even when the bodies dwell farthest away from each other.
('57', 50, 5, 16, 93520) Even if the bodies are very close to each other, they are as distant from each other as the North Pole is from the South if the minds and the hearts do not meet.
('57', 50, 5, 17, 93682) Therefore the nearness of the bodies has little meaning.
('57', 50, 5, 18, 93739) It is only because there is a soul living in the body that we wish to meet each other.
('57', 50, 5, 19, 93826) This, indeed, is the strongest infatuation and till we are free from it we are held in chains even stronger than steel.
('57', 50, 5, 20, 93946) But it is not enough to understand this with our intellect.
('57', 50, 5, 21, 94006) The knowledge should sink into the heart.
('57', 50, 5, 22, 94048) If that happens, one has attained everything worth attaining.
('57', 50, 5, 23, 94110) But one has to struggle during many lives to acquire this knowledge, and even then only a few succeed in acquiring it.
('57', 50, 5, 24, 94229) Hence the Gita teaches, by implication, that one should wear away one’s body doing one’s duty.
('57', 50, 5, 25, 94324) It is only in this way that one can learn non attachment or become free from infatuation.
('57', 50, 5, 26, 94414) [From Gujarati]
('57', 50, 6, 27, 94430) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, p.35
('57', 50, 7, 28, 94465) 1Vide the preceding item.

('57', 51, 4, 12, 95026) 78. A LETTER
('57', 51, 5, 13, 95039) September 17, 1932
('57', 51, 6, 14, 95058) CHI., Your letter is absurd.
('57', 51, 6, 15, 95087) On the one hand, you talk about undertaking a fast and, on the other, about marrying.
('57', 51, 6, 16, 95173) You are too young, and not yet fit, to undertake a fast.
('57', 51, 6, 17, 95230) So long as you are not married you may certainly write innocent letters to the young man to whom you are betrothed, after obtaining your parents’ consent.
('57', 51, 6, 18, 95385) I have deliberately used the word ‘innocent’.
('57', 51, 6, 19, 95431) It is a sin to nurse a desire which is not going to be ful filled in the present.
('57', 51, 6, 20, 95513) One’s mental strength is unnecessarily wasted by doing that.
('57', 51, 6, 21, 95574) It is not at all wise to waste it in such a manner.
('57', 51, 6, 22, 95626) I do not know your age.
('57', 51, 6, 23, 95650) If you have really come of age, and if you are a prey to passion, I would prefer that you should get married immediately.
('57', 51, 6, 24, 95772) If you are not yet of marriageable age, then you should control your passion and should not be eager to write letters to your future husband.
('57', 51, 6, 25, 95914) I think this will solve all your problems.

('57', 57, 1, 2, 101505) 90. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI
('57', 57, 2, 3, 101536) September 18, 1932
('57', 57, 3, 4, 101555) CHHAGANLAL (JOSHI), I am certain that some of your letters have been held back.
('57', 57, 3, 5, 101635) I hope you have fully grasped the significance of my fast unto death.
('57', 57, 3, 6, 101705) Be brave and do not lose heart.
('57', 57, 3, 7, 101737) You must not slacken in your labour.
('57', 57, 3, 8, 101774) What do we gain by clinging to the body?
('57', 57, 3, 9, 101815) We daily recite in the Ashram verses which tell us to give up attachment to the body.
('57', 57, 3, 10, 101901) We have got this opportunity to demonstrate that we have assimilated the lesson of the verses which we daily recite.
('57', 57, 3, 11, 102018) All of you should pray that I may have the strength to go through the test.
('57', 57, 3, 12, 102094) It is easy (relatively) to jump into the water, but who can be sure that one will be able to reach the other shore?
('57', 57, 3, 13, 102210) Hence, people need not get elated till the test has ended.
('57', 57, 3, 14, 102269) But I have embarked on it with God’s name on my lips and I am confident, therefore, that He will help me to go through it.
('57', 57, 3, 15, 102392) Face the situation in a manner worthy of yourself and of the cause.
('57', 57, 4, 16, 102460) Blessings from BAPU From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 5509

('57', 58, 1, 2, 103346) 92. LETTER TO NANABHAI I. MASHRUWALA
('57', 58, 2, 3, 103383) September 18, 1932
('57', 58, 3, 4, 103402) BHAI NANABHAI, I got your letter.
('57', 58, 3, 5, 103436) I have undertaken the fast as sacrifice to the Lord and, therefore, He will protect the body if He wants it to be an instrument of further service; otherwise He will let it perish.

('57', 69, 6, 8, 122003) 112. LETTER TO NARAYAN M. KHARE
('57', 69, 7, 9, 122035) September 19, 1932
('57', 69, 8, 10, 122054) PANDITJI,
('57', 69, 9, 11, 122064) Rambhau’s letter was both very good and very disappointing.
('57', 69, 9, 12, 122124) I have replied 2 to him.
('57', 69, 9, 13, 122149) But I will not give up hope for such an intelligent boy.
('57', 69, 10, 14, 122206) Kaka had told me Sundarbehn’s story when I left for England.
('57', 69, 10, 15, 122267) From that I had concluded that Sundarbehn had never had marital relations.
('57', 69, 10, 16, 122342) Her husband despised her from the beginning as he did not consider her beautiful, that is, fair skinned.
('57', 69, 10, 17, 122447) Now there is no moral reason to look upon a woman, whom her husband never accepted as wife, as a married woman.
('57', 69, 10, 18, 122559) In such cases, when the legal position has no moral basis, we should ignore law and uphold morality.
('57', 69, 10, 19, 122660) It would have been excellent if Sundarbehn could have remained unmarried; 1
('57', 69, 11, 20, 122736) but when she was unable to do that, the only moral course open to her was to find a suitable husband.
('57', 69, 11, 21, 122838) In doing this she ran the risk of being convicted but she accepted it.
('57', 69, 11, 22, 122909) I see no religious objection against such a marriage.
('57', 69, 11, 23, 122963) All laws regarding marriage have their origin in custom.They should be weighed in the scales of self control for examining their validity.
('57', 69, 11, 24, 123102) A course which on the whole promotes self control sho uld be preferred even if it is opposed to custom.
('57', 69, 12, 25, 123206) As regards the Ashram women, if you ask me specific questions I will explain my views further.

('57', 70, 5, 8, 123892) 113. LETTER TO KUSUM
('57', 70, 6, 9, 123913) September 19, 1932 You should not be upset by my decision to fast.
('57', 70, 6, 10, 123980) Your duty is to take sufficient rest and build up a strong body.
('57', 70, 6, 11, 124045) I need not say anything more about this.
('57', 70, 6, 12, 124086) Those who advised that girls, when they are ill, should immediately be married off are ignorant men.
('57', 70, 6, 13, 124187) The number of married women who remain ill is far greater in proportion to that of sickly maidens everywhere.
('57', 70, 6, 14, 124297) You are also right in contrasting people’s attitude towards girls with their attitude towards boys who fall ill.
('57', 70, 6, 15, 124410) However, you should take the implied charge against girls in the right sense and take care never to fall ill.
('57', 70, 6, 16, 124520) Some general knowledge about health, such as I have tried to give in my booklet, is necessary for preventing illness.
('57', 70, 6, 17, 124638) The bodies of unmarried girls should be as strong as steel, and so should be the bodies of unmarried boys.
('57', 70, 6, 18, 124745) But we find both sickly, and they are generally more so after marriage.
('57', 70, 6, 19, 124817) Look at Umiya, Rukhi, and Hari ichchha.
('57', 70, 6, 20, 124857) It did seem for a while that marriage had done Rukhi good but before long she was ill again.
('57', 70, 6, 21, 124950) From this, however, the girls should not rush to the conclusion that all who marry lose their health after marriage.
('57', 70, 6, 22, 125067) It is true, however, that unmarried girls who burn with passion and desire will find their deliverance only in marriage, since their passion is secretly eating them.
('57', 70, 6, 23, 125233) But this also means that such a girl feels before marriage as a married woman does and that she is, therefore, immoral.
('57', 70, 6, 24, 125353) Any person, whether a woman or a man, who yields to passion even though only inwardly, is immoral.
('57', 70, 7, 25, 125452) Blessing from BAPU [From Gujarati]
('57', 70, 8, 26, 125487) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.

('57', 73, 5, 9, 128231) 120. LETTER TO GANGABEHN VAIDYA
('57', 73, 6, 10, 128263) [September 19, 1932] 1
('57', 73, 7, 11, 128286) GANGABEHN,
('57', 73, 8, 12, 128297) Nowadays you have been writing fairly regularly.
('57', 73, 8, 13, 128346) Do not at all be alarmed or upset by the yajna I have in mind.
('57', 73, 8, 14, 128409) I am going to have you all undertake similar sacrifices.
('57', 73, 8, 15, 128466) I will leave this body—if I have to—with the faith that you will be able to do it.
('57', 73, 8, 16, 128549) This is the only way to atone for the sins accumulated through generations.
('57', 73, 8, 17, 128625) Such a vow is not to be imitated.
('57', 73, 8, 18, 128659) It can be fulfilled only if there is a spontaneous urge.
('57', 73, 8, 19, 128716) If the urge is felt while the mind is not yet pure, the fast is likely to be demoniacal.
('57', 73, 8, 20, 128805) Hence such a yajna should beundertaken only if there has been a prior cleansing of the heart.
('57', 73, 8, 21, 128899) The Ashram has come into existence to help people attain such purity.
('57', 73, 8, 22, 128969) But you say that one hears much criticism of the Ashram.
('57', 73, 8, 23, 129026) You should bear with criticism.
('57', 73, 8, 24, 129058) The cause for it, if found to be just, should be examined and corrected.
('57', 73, 8, 25, 129131) We should be indifferent to what is not true.
('57', 73, 8, 26, 129177) People have a right to say what they feel.
('57', 73, 8, 27, 129220) And some may find fault simply out of spite.
('57', 73, 8, 28, 129265) Is not such criticism beneath consideration?
('57', 73, 8, 29, 129310) There is some truth in what we have been hearing about .
('57', 73, 8, 30, 129367) And whatever little there is deserves to be overlooked.
('57', 73, 8, 31, 129423) My little experience of .

('57', 74, 1, 12, 130059) There are two reasons for it.
('57', 74, 1, 13, 130089) First, you are not satisfied with your own performance.
('57', 74, 1, 14, 130145) You aspire to do much more than you can.

('57', 74, 1, 16, 130245) When it crosses the limits the result is grief.
('57', 74, 1, 17, 130293) A greater reason for the loss of your peace is your intolerance.
('57', 74, 1, 18, 130358) You are irked when others fail to work as much as you can or do not agree with you.
('57', 74, 1, 19, 130442) The remedy for it is simple.
('57', 74, 1, 20, 130471) You should rest content with whatever work you can do after applying your body and mind to it and continue to make such progress as you can.
('57', 74, 1, 21, 130612) You should realize that one who does scavenging has as much right to go to heaven as one who learns the Vedas.
('57', 74, 1, 22, 130723) But if a scholar of the Vedas is a mere reciter of the text or a hypocrite he will go to hell however learned he may be and a scavenger who daily cleans latrines in a spirit of service and dedicating his services unto God would certainly rise high although he may not know the word Brahman.
('57', 74, 1, 23, 131014) This contentment is one remedy.
('57', 74, 1, 24, 131046) The other is a liberal attitude.
('57', 74, 1, 25, 131079) We should not take it amiss if others do not work as much as we ourselves do or want them to do.
('57', 74, 1, 26, 131176) Only in this way can we maintain peace in the community in spite of living close to one another.
('57', 74, 1, 27, 131273) Read this letter over and over again and think over it with the help of Nath.

('57', 74, 1, 29, 131372) 5 behn.

('57', 75, 6, 7, 131913) 122. A LETTER
('57', 75, 7, 8, 131927) September 19, 1932 All of us were delighted to read your extremely beautiful letter.
('57', 75, 7, 9, 132012) You have attained a lofty height.
('57', 75, 7, 10, 132046) Rise higher still.
('57', 75, 7, 11, 132065) God will certainly give you the strength to do so.
('57', 75, 7, 12, 132116) I know I should write a long reply to your letter, but cannot spare so much time just now.
('57', 75, 7, 13, 132207) I will preserve your letter, however, and will write to you again if I have sufficient strength and get time to do so.
('57', 75, 7, 14, 132326) But please do not mind if I cannot write.
('57', 75, 7, 15, 132368) I hope none of you has got perturbed by this yajna of my fast.
('57', 75, 7, 16, 132431) God has inspired me to undertake it and may He carry it successfully to its end.
('57', 75, 7, 17, 132512) None knows how many such yajnas we shall have to perform in order to eradicate this evil of untouchability.
('57', 75, 7, 18, 132620) Get ready to perform such a yajna yourself.
('57', 75, 7, 19, 132664) Readiness means self purification.
('57', 75, 7, 20, 132699) Self purification necessarily includes efficiency in work.
('57', 75, 7, 21, 132758) It is true that fine yarn would be costly.
('57', 75, 7, 22, 132801) But we should have the ability to revive the manufacture of Dacca muslin.
('57', 75, 7, 23, 132875) While trying to do so, we shall incidentally make many small inventions.
('57', 75, 7, 24, 132948) In the past, the kings forced workers to spin such yarn and weave it.
('57', 75, 7, 25, 133018) Now, let us spin and weave it by way of yajna.
('57', 75, 7, 26, 133065) Then the question of its being costly will not arise at all and, moreover, the prestige of hand spinning also will increase.
('57', 75, 7, 27, 133190) God willing, I will explain this further in another letter.

('57', 78, 6, 10, 136207) 129. LETTER TO RABINDRANATH TAGORE
('57', 78, 7, 11, 136242) September 20, 1932
('57', 78, 8, 12, 136261) DEAR GURUDEV, This is early morning 3 o’clock of Tuesday.
('57', 78, 8, 13, 136319) I enter the fiery gate at noon.
('57', 78, 8, 14, 136351) If you can bless the effort, I want it.
('57', 78, 8, 15, 136391) You have been to me a true friend because you have been a candid friend often speaking your thoughts aloud.
('57', 78, 8, 16, 136499) I had looked forward to a firm opinion from you one way or the other.
('57', 78, 8, 17, 136569) But you have refused to criticize.
('57', 78, 8, 18, 136604) Though it can now only be during my fast I will yet prize your criticism, if your heart condemns my action.
('57', 78, 8, 19, 136712) I am not too proud to make an open confession of my blunder, whatever the cost of the confession, if I find myself in error.
('57', 78, 8, 20, 136837) If your heart approves of the action I want your blessing.
('57', 78, 8, 21, 136896) It will sustain me.
('57', 78, 8, 22, 136916) I hope I have made myself clear.
('57', 78, 8, 23, 136949) My love.
('57', 78, 9, 24, 136958) M. K. GANDHI [PS.] 10.30 a.m.
('57', 78, 9, 25, 136988) Just as I was handing this to the Superintendent, I got your loving and magnificent wire.
('57', 78, 9, 26, 137078) It will sustain me in the midst of the storm I am about to enter.
('57', 78, 9, 27, 137144) I am sending you a wire.
('57', 78, 10, 28, 137169) Thank you.
