('57', 79, 1, 2, 137302) 130. LETTER TO V. S. SRINIVASA SASTRI
('57', 79, 2, 3, 137340) September 20, 1932
('57', 79, 3, 4, 137359) MY DEAREST FRIEND AND BROTHER, This is early morning of Tuesday just a little after 3 o’clock.
('57', 79, 3, 5, 137454) I have just finished a brief letter 1 to Gurudev.
('57', 79, 3, 6, 137504) You have been ever present before me during these days of anguish.
('57', 79, 3, 7, 137571) I have perhaps read your thoughts.
('57', 79, 3, 8, 137606) You know my regard for you.
('57', 79, 3, 9, 137634) Though we are as poles asunder, or seem to be, in mental outlook at so many points, our hearts are one.
('57', 79, 3, 10, 137738) Wherever therefore I have been able to agree with you, it has been a matter of pure joy.
('57', 79, 3, 11, 137827) Perhaps this step of mine has been for you the last straw.
('57', 79, 3, 12, 137886) Even so I want to have your laceration.
('57', 79, 3, 13, 137926) For I do not want you to cease to strive with me—I remained in banishment from my eldest brother for, I think, fourteen years.
('57', 79, 3, 14, 138053) Year after year he sent me curses by registered post.
('57', 79, 3, 15, 138107) I rejoiced in his curses.
('57', 79, 3, 16, 138133) His curses were so many sparks of love— I won him.
('57', 79, 3, 17, 138184) Six months before his death he saw that I was in the right.
('57', 79, 4, 18, 138244) One of the reasons for his wrath was this very question of untouch ability.
('57', 79, 4, 19, 138320) In our case, I do not know who is in error.
('57', 79, 4, 20, 138364) But I do know that you are as blood brother to me.
('57', 79, 4, 21, 138415) At this (may be) last crisis, you must not cease to strive with me.
('57', 79, 4, 22, 138483) Send me your curses or your blessings.
('57', 79, 4, 23, 138522) You may open my eyes, where others have failed, if you think I am in error.
('57', 79, 4, 24, 138598) You know me too well not to know that I have the God given capacity of owning mistakes, if the conviction comes to me.
('57', 79, 4, 25, 138717) Do write or wire to me.
('57', 79, 4, 26, 138741) I wrote to you a month ago inquiring about your health.
('57', 79, 4, 27, 138797) I never got a reply.
('57', 79, 4, 28, 138818) I wonder if you ever got my postcard.
('57', 79, 4, 29, 138856) Deep love.
('57', 79, 5, 30, 138867) M. K. GANDHI
('57', 79, 6, 31, 138880) Letters of Srinivasa Sastri, p.
('57', 79, 7, 32, 138912) 1Vide the preceding item.
('57', 79, 7, 33, 138938) 2Vide “An Autobiography—Part IV, Chapter V”.
('57', 80, 0, 1, 138983) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 81
('57', 80, 1, 2, 139032) 131. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('57', 80, 2, 3, 139056) September 20, 1932
('57', 80, 3, 4, 139075) MIRA, I got up at 2.30 today to write to Gurudev, then to Sastri and then to you.
('57', 80, 3, 5, 139157) I have your tearing letter.
('57', 80, 3, 6, 139185) At first I thought I would send it to the Governor.
('57', 80, 3, 7, 139237) But I rejected the thought as soon as it came.
('57', 80, 3, 8, 139284) You have chosen to enter the furnace.
('57', 80, 3, 9, 139322) You must remain in it.
('57', 80, 3, 10, 139345) My society is no easy job as you have seen all these years.
('57', 80, 3, 11, 139405) Drink then the poison to the last dregs.
('57', 80, 3, 12, 139446) As I wrote that first letter conveying my vow, I thought of you and of Ba.
('57', 80, 3, 13, 139521) And for a time I became giddy.
('57', 80, 3, 14, 139552) How would you two bear the thing?
('57', 80, 3, 15, 139586) But the voice within said, ‘If you will enter in, you must give up thought of all attachment.’ And the letter went.
('57', 80, 3, 16, 139702) No anguish will be too terrible to wash out the sin of untouchability.
('57', 80, 3, 17, 139773) You must therefore rejoice in this suffering and bear it bravely.
('57', 80, 3, 18, 139839) I know how difficult all this is to do.
('57', 80, 3, 19, 139879) Yet that is exactly what you have to try to do.
('57', 80, 3, 20, 139927) Just think and realize that there is no meaning in having the last look.
('57', 80, 3, 21, 140000) The spirit which you love is always with you.
('57', 80, 3, 22, 140046) The body through which you learnt to love the spirit is no longer necessary for sustaining that love.
('57', 80, 3, 23, 140148) It is well that it lasts whilst there is use for it.
('57', 80, 3, 24, 140201) It is equally well that it perishes when there is no use for it.
('57', 80, 3, 25, 140266) And since we don’t know when it will outlast its use, we conclude that death through whatever cause means that there was no longer any use for it.
('57', 80, 3, 26, 140413) If it is any comfort, know that Vallabhbhai, Mahadev, Ramdas, Surendra, Devdas, whom I have met are all bearing the thing wonderfully well.
('57', 80, 3, 27, 140553) Love to your companions.
('57', 80, 3, 28, 140578) I am glad Kisen is with you.
('57', 80, 3, 29, 140607) She is a good and brave girl.
('57', 80, 3, 30, 140637) May God sustain you.
('57', 80, 4, 31, 140658) BAPU SHRI MIRABAI (SLADE) ARTHUR ROAD PRISON BOMBAY
('57', 80, 5, 32, 140710) From a photostat: C.W. 9509. Courtesy: Mirabehn

('57', 88, 6, 8, 146723) 152. LETTER TO G. K. DEVDHAR
('57', 88, 7, 9, 146752) September 29, 1932
('57', 88, 8, 10, 146771) MY DEAR DEVDHAR, Of course the Society’s home is my home.
('57', 88, 8, 11, 146829) 1 I have lived in exile by choice.
('57', 88, 8, 12, 146864) When God wills it, He will send me back home.
('57', 88, 8, 13, 146910) I have not the slightest notion where the fast will be taken.
('57', 88, 8, 14, 146972) This is a wonderful ordeal.
('57', 88, 8, 15, 147000) I deserve it all.
('57', 88, 8, 16, 147018) For I have the Hindu heart.
('57', 88, 8, 17, 147046) And have we not deserved the most terrible chastisement from God for ourtreatment of the untouchables?
('57', 88, 8, 18, 147149) And so He is trying me through and through before admitting me to the untouchable fold.
('57', 88, 8, 19, 147237) It has been an effort for the past 50 years.
('57', 88, 8, 20, 147282) Please send the enclosed 2 to Sastri.
('57', 88, 9, 21, 147320) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.
('57', 88, 10, 22, 147354) 153. LETTER TO P. N. RAJBHOJ
('57', 88, 11, 23, 147383) September 20, 1932
('57', 88, 12, 24, 147402) DEAR FRIEND, I got your letter only yesterday whilst I was talking to the friends who came to see me.
('57', 88, 12, 25, 147504) I am now replying to it at earliest opportunity.
('57', 88, 12, 26, 147553) I thank you for your letter.
('57', 88, 12, 27, 147582) My position is this: My fast has reference only to separate electorate.
('57', 88, 12, 28, 147654) As soon as that is withdrawn the letter of the vow will be satisfied and I would be bound to call off the fast.
('57', 88, 12, 29, 147766) But a very heavy
('57', 88, 13, 30, 147783) 1 The addressee had invited Gandhiji to stay at the Servants of India Society’s Home at Poona during the fast.
('57', 88, 13, 31, 147894) 2 Vide “Letter to V.S. Srinivasa Sastri”, 20 9 1932.
('57', 89, 0, 1, 147947) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 89, 1, 2, 147988) responsibility will then lie upon me of having a substitute that is infinitely superior to separate electorate.
('57', 89, 1, 3, 148100) If you will not resent my saying it, I would like to say that as I am a “touchable” by birth, I am an “untouchable” by choice.
('57', 89, 1, 4, 148227) And it was in this dual capacity that I wrote to Sir Samuel Hoare and then the Prime Minister.
('57', 89, 1, 5, 148322) It is that dual capacity that has compelled the fast.
('57', 89, 1, 6, 148376) Looking at the matter in this light I must say that I am not in love with the idea of statutory reservation.
('57', 89, 1, 7, 148485) Whilst it is not open to the same objection that separate electorate is, I have not a shadow of a doubt that it will prevent the natural growth of the suppressed classes and will remove the incentive to honourable amends from the suppressors.
('57', 89, 1, 8, 148728) What I am aiming at is a heart understanding between the two, the greatest opportunity of repentance and reparation on the part, of the suppressors.
('57', 89, 1, 9, 148877) I am certain that the moment is ripe for the change of heart among them.
('57', 89, 1, 10, 148950) I would therefore favour widest possible franchise for the suppressed and establish a convention between the two sections for securing proper election of representatives of the suppressed.
('57', 89, 1, 11, 149139) I have drafted a rough tentative scheme which I handed to the friends and which I explained fully yesterday to my son Devdas.
('57', 89, 1, 12, 149265) But to me this is not the largest but it is the least part of the reform I want.
('57', 89, 1, 13, 149346) Nothing will satisfy me till the last vestige of untouchability is gone.
('57', 89, 1, 14, 149419) I would therefore insist on a statutory declaration that all public places of worship, wells, schools, etc., should be open to the sup pressed precisely on the same terms as the suppressors.
('57', 89, 1, 15, 149610) This is roughly my idea.
('57', 89, 1, 16, 149635) If, however, the representatives of suppressed classes will not look at my idea, they are at liberty to have statutory reservation of seats.
('57', 89, 1, 17, 149776) I should not fast against it but you will not expect me to bless any such scheme.
('57', 89, 1, 18, 149858) Nor is my blessing essential to its acceptance by the Government.
('57', 89, 1, 19, 149924) If I get the opportunity, I should certainly try to create public opinion among the suppressed against statutory reservation.
('57', 89, 1, 20, 150050) If my position is not clear or satisfactory, I would be delighted to meet you and other friends including R.B. Raja and Dr. Ambedkar by appointment.
('57', 89, 1, 21, 150199) As you are aware this has become possible only now.
('57', 89, 2, 22, 150251) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('57', 91, 6, 22, 153629) Fasting is a very common practice in Hinduism.

('57', 91, 6, 25, 153736) The Prime Minister’s decision was only the immediate cause.
('57', 91, 6, 26, 153796) It provided me with an opportunity to undertake the fast.
('57', 91, 6, 27, 153854) However, the aim of my fast is not merely to get the decision changed but to bring about the awakening and self purification which are bound to result from the effort to get the decision changed.
('57', 91, 6, 28, 154050) In other words this was an opportunity to strike at the very root of untouchability.

('57', 93, 8, 22, 157106) 159. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS 1
('57', 93, 9, 23, 157136) September 20, 1932
('57', 93, 10, 24, 157155) For the first time in nine months journalists were permitted to see Mahatma Gandhi in Yeravda Jail this evening at 5.30 when they were treated to one of the most easily delivered and seriously thoughtful interviews to which it has ever been my fortune to listen.
('57', 93, 10, 25, 157418) No journalist could see Mahatma Gandhi today and discuss the position with him five hours after he had commenced “a fast unto death” without being immensely impressed .
('57', 93, 11, 26, 157587) When asked if he was hopeful about a happy ending to the affair, he said: I am an irrepressible optimist.
('57', 93, 11, 27, 157693) Unless God has forsaken me, I hope that it will not be a fast unto death.
('57', 93, 12, 28, 157767) Mahatma Gandhi said that he had many telegrams from people who had decided or wished to enter upon a fast in sympathy with him.
('57', 93, 13, 29, 157895) 1 This report of the interview first appeared in The Times of India, 21 9 1932.
('57', 94, 0, 1, 157975) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 95
('57', 94, 1, 2, 158024) I urge everybody not to fast in sympathy.
('57', 94, 1, 3, 158066) I have undertaken it at God’s call, and, therefore, unless there is a similar definite call to these people they have no business to fast.
('57', 94, 1, 4, 158205) For one day, for the sake of purification or identification with the cause, it is a good thing; but that is all.
('57', 94, 1, 5, 158318) Such a fast is both a privilege and a duty, and the privilegeaccrues only to those who have disciplined themselves for it.
('57', 94, 2, 6, 158441) The interview then turned to the question of the day, the representation of the Depressed Classes, or as Mahatma Gandhi calls them, the Suppressed Classes.
('57', 94, 3, 7, 158597) First of all he expressed surprise that the statement 1 given to the Government of Bombay had not been released.
('57', 94, 3, 8, 158710) That had been given five days ago.
('57', 94, 3, 9, 158745) Had he to redraft it today it would be rather different in the light of happenings since then, and he said at the end of the interview that his new statement was supplementary to the other, but not dependent on it.
('57', 94, 3, 10, 158960) He said: My cards are on the table, but, so far as the present instance is concerned, I could say nothing from behind prison bars.
('57', 94, 3, 11, 159091) Now that the restrictions are removed, I have answered the first call of the Press.
('57', 94, 3, 12, 159175) My fast is only against separate electorates, and not against statutory reservation of seats.
('57', 94, 3, 13, 159269) To say that I am damaging the cause by uncompromising opposition to statutory reservation of seats is only partly true.
('57', 94, 3, 14, 159389) Opposed I was, and am even now, but there was never put before me for any acceptance or rejection a scheme for statutory reservation of seats.
('57', 94, 3, 15, 159532) Therefore, there is no question of my having to decide upon that point.
('57', 94, 3, 16, 159604) When I developed my own idea about that point, I certainly expressed disappointment, and in my humble opinion, such statutory reservation, short of doing service, may do harm in the sense that it will stop natural evolution.
('57', 94, 3, 17, 159829) Statutory reservation is like a support to a man.
('57', 94, 3, 18, 159879) Relying on such support to any extent he weakens himself.
('57', 94, 3, 19, 159937) If people won’t laugh at me, I would gently put forward a claim, which I have always asserted, that I am a ‘touchable’ by birth but an untouchable by choice; and I have endeavoured to qualify myself to represent, not the upper ten even among the untouchables, because be it said to their shame there are castes and classes among them, but my ambition is to represent and identify myself with, as far as possible, the lowest strata of untouchables, namely, the ‘invisibles’ and the ‘unapp roachables’, whom I have always before my mind’s eye wherever I go; for they have indeed drunk deep of the poisoned cup.
('57', 94, 3, 20, 160546) I have met
('57', 94, 4, 21, 160557) 1 Vide “Statement to the Press”, 16 9 1932.
('57', 95, 0, 1, 160601) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 95, 1, 2, 160642) them in Malabar and in Orissa, and am convinced that if they are ever to rise, it will not be by reservation of seats but will be by the strenuous work of Hindu reformers in their midst, and it is because I feel that this separation would have killed all prospect of reform that my whole soul has rebelled against it; and, let me make it plain, that the withdrawal of separate electorates will satisfy the letter of my vow but will never satisfy the spirit behind it, and in my capacity of being a self chosen untouchable, I am not going to rest content with a patched up pact between the ‘touchables’ and the untouchables.
('57', 95, 1, 3, 161266) What I want, what I am living for, and what I should delight in dying for, is the eradication of untouchability root and branch.
('57', 95, 1, 4, 161395) I want, therefore, a living pact whose life giving effect should be felt not in the distant tomorrow but today, and, therefore, that pact should be sealed by an all India demonstration of ‘touchables’ and untou chables meeting together, not by way of a theatrical show, but in real brotherly embrace.
('57', 95, 1, 5, 161696) It is in order to achieve this, the dream of my life for the past fifty years, that I have entered today the fiery gates.
('57', 95, 1, 6, 161818) The British Government’s decision was the last straw.
('57', 95, 1, 7, 161872) It was a decisive symptom, and with the unerring eye of the physician that I claim to be in such matters, I detected the symptom.
('57', 95, 1, 8, 162002) Therefore, for me the abolition of separate electorates would be but the beginning of the end, and I would warn all those leaders assembled at Bombay and others against coming to any hasty decision.
('57', 95, 1, 9, 162201) My life I count of no consequence.
('57', 95, 1, 10, 162236) One hundred lives given for this noble cause would, in my opinion, be poor penance done by Hindus for the atrocious wrongs they have heaped upon helpless men and women of their own faith.
('57', 95, 1, 11, 162424) I, therefore, would urge them not to swerve an inch from the path of strictest justice.
('57', 95, 1, 12, 162512) My fast I want to throw in the scales of justice, and if it wakes up caste Hindus from their slumber, and if they are roused to a sense of their duty, it will have served its purpose.
('57', 95, 1, 13, 162696) Whereas, if out of blind affection for me, they would somehow or other come to a rough and ready agreement so as to secure the abrogation and then go off to sleep, they will commit a grievous blunder and will have made my life a misery.
('57', 95, 1, 14, 162933) For, while the abrogation of separate electorates would result in my breaking the fast, it would be living death for me if the vital pact for which I am striving is not arrived at.
('57', 95, 1, 15, 163114) It would simply mean that, as soon as I called off the fast, I would have to give notice of another in order to achieve the spirit of the vow to the fullest extent.
('57', 96, 0, 1, 163279) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 97
('57', 96, 1, 2, 163328) This may look childish to the onlooker but not so to me.
('57', 96, 1, 3, 163385) If I had anything more to give, I would throw that in also to remove this curse, but I have nothing more than my life.
('57', 96, 1, 4, 163504) I believe that if untouchability is really rooted out, it will not only purge Hinduism of a terrible blot but its repercussions will be world wide.
('57', 96, 1, 5, 163652) My fight against untouchability is a fight against the impure in humanity, and, therefore, when I penned my letter 1 to Sir Samuel Hoare I did so in the full faith that the very best in human family will come to my assistance if I have embarked on this thing with a heart, so far as it is possible for a human being to achieve, free of impurity, free of all malice and all anger.
('57', 96, 1, 6, 164032) You will, therefore, see that my fast is based first of all in the cause of faith in the Hindu community, faith in human nature itself, and faith even in the official world.
('57', 96, 1, 7, 164206) In attacking untouchability I have gone to the very root of the matter, and, therefore, it is an issue of transcendental value, far surpassing swaraj in terms of political constitutions, and I would say that such a constitution would be a dead weight if it was not backed by a moral basis, in the shape of the present hope engendered in the breasts of the downtrodden millions that that weight is going to be lifted from their shoulders.
('57', 96, 1, 8, 164644) It is only because the English officials cannot possibly see this living side of the picture that in their ignorance and self satisfaction they dare to sit as judges upon questions that affect the fundamental being of millions of people, and here I mean both caste Hindus and untouchables, that is, the suppr essor and the suppressed; and it was in order to wake up even officialdom from its gross ignorance, if I may make use of such an expression without being guilty of offence, that I felt impelled by a voice from within to offer resistance with the whole of my being.
('57', 96, 2, 9, 165218) He stated that he had made definite suggestions to the deputation from the Emergency Committee whom he received yesterday and he presumed that these would have been communicated to the Press today in Bombay.
('57', 96, 3, 10, 165426) Referring to a possible photograph Mahatma Gandhi made a jocular remark concerning his funeral rites whereupon I asked him he had made any preparations for such rites when visited by his son Devdas yesterday if the very worst happeneed, and I received a dramatic reply.
('57', 96, 4, 11, 165696) 1 Vide “Letter to Sir Samuel Hoare”, 11 3 1932.
('57', 97, 0, 1, 165744) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 97, 1, 2, 165785) I have asked my son to say in my name at the Bombay Conference that he as his father’s son was prepared to forfeit his father’s life rather than see any injury being done to the Suppressed Classes in mad haste.
('57', 97, 2, 3, 165996) What did he really think about the possibilities of his fast lasting?
('57', 97, 2, 4, 166066) He replied: I am as anxious as anyone to live.
('57', 97, 2, 5, 166113) Water has an infinite capacity for prolonging life, and I will take water whenever I feel I require it.
('57', 97, 2, 6, 166217) You can depend upon me to make a supreme effort to hold myself together so that the Hindu conscience may be quickened as also the British conscience and this agony may end.
('57', 97, 2, 7, 166390) My cry will rise to the throne of the Almighty God.
('57', 97, 2, 8, 166442) The Epic Fast, pp.

('57', 99, 3, 10, 169445) 164. LETTER TO KISHORELAL G. MASHRUWALA
('57', 99, 4, 11, 169485) September 21, 1932 I am naturally eager to know whether you consider my step moral or not.
('57', 99, 4, 12, 169576) Nath is a little doubtful about it.
('57', 99, 4, 13, 169612) I have replied 1 to his letter.
('57', 99, 4, 14, 169644) If you have thought about the matter, write to me.

('57', 102, 6, 11, 174038) 171. INTERVIEW TO S. M. MATE, P. N. RAJBHOJ AND LIMAYE 1
('57', 102, 7, 12, 174095) September 21, 1932
('57', 102, 8, 13, 174114) If I had my way I would insist on temple entry and the like being included in any pact that may be concluded and I would invite all reformers and untouchables to do so.
('57', 102, 8, 14, 174283) I am aware that temple entry is a difficult thing to accomplish in the very limited time that my life can hold out against the fast, but all the parties to the pact should pledge themselves to realize this elementary right of human beings at the earliest opportunity.
('57', 102, 8, 15, 174551) At the same time I do not want this fast to be used for coercing orthodoxy.
('57', 102, 8, 16, 174627) The fast is certainly intended to sting even orthodoxy into thinking.
('57', 102, 8, 17, 174697) But if they cannot get on to this elementary truth about human rights we must have patience.
('57', 102, 8, 18, 174790) But temples and the like are the property not of orthodoxy but of all Hindus.
('57', 102, 8, 19, 174868) Therefore this idea of excluding a section of Hindus from the use of public utilities is itself a species of violence, and, therefore, the support of legislation has got to be invoked in order to protect this fundamenal right.
('57', 102, 8, 20, 175095) I recognize, however, that if the majority of the Hindus are against the exercise of this right by the so called untouchables, mere legislation will be wholly ineffective.
('57', 102, 8, 21, 175267) But my opinion is that the mind of the majority is for this reform if it comes stealthily.
('57', 102, 8, 22, 175358) Therefore, reformers should prepare the ground now cease 
('57', 102, 9, 23, 175416) 1 According to the source, what follows is the substance of Gandhiji’s talk.
('57', 103, 0, 1, 175493) 104 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 103, 1, 2, 175535) lessly and vigilantly to convert the passive attitude towards the reform into active approval thereof.
('57', 103, 1, 3, 175638) This rising tide of opinion in favour of the reform will convince orthodoxy that it is inevitable.
('57', 103, 1, 4, 175737) The work, therefore, must be free of all violence, even mental.
('57', 103, 1, 5, 175801) Legislation in a free State always represents the will of the majority.
('57', 103, 1, 6, 175873) All legislation in advance of general opinion argues bank ruptcy of missionary effort.
('57', 103, 1, 7, 175960) My reliance, therefore, always has been on missionary enterprise.
('57', 103, 1, 8, 176026) Therefore, for the pact to be a living pact, it is absolutely necessary that it should be a condition precedent to an acceptance of the political part of it, that the caste Hindus party to the pact will not only endorse it but actively move in the matter.
('57', 103, 1, 9, 176282) My own opinion is quite clear.
('57', 103, 1, 10, 176313) I would accept any pact that has not a tinge of separate electorate about it.
('57', 103, 1, 11, 176391) I would, with the utmost reluctance, tolerate reservation of seats under a joint electorate scheme.
('57', 103, 1, 12, 176491) But I should insist upon what is to me the vital part of the pact, the social and religious reform.
('57', 103, 1, 13, 176591) And, therefore, whilst if a settlement is arrived at on the joint electorate scheme and separate electorate is withdrawn by the British Government, I will break my fast, I will immediately give notice to the millions of Hindus, who have flocked round me at the innumerable meetings from one end of India to the other, that if within, say, six months the social reform is not demonstrably achieved, the fast will be taken up again.
('57', 103, 1, 14, 177022) For, if I do not do so I would be guilty of betraying God in whose name I have taken this great fast and the interest of untouchables for whose sake it has been taken.
('57', 103, 1, 15, 177190) I have not yet approved of the Nasik Satyagraha about Kalaram temple for the simple reason that I have smelt a trace of violence in that satyagraha, and satyagraha is inconsistent with the slightest violence.
('57', 103, 1, 16, 177399) I understand also that with reference to temples like Parvati temple there is a difficulty about the trust.
('57', 103, 1, 17, 177507) The trust deed itself lays an obligation on the trustees to prohibit the entry of untouchables into the temple.
('57', 103, 1, 18, 177619) Where such a disability exists, I would be able to understand the powerlessness of the trustees.
('57', 103, 1, 19, 177716) Any satyagraha in reference to such temples would be pure violence.
('57', 103, 1, 20, 177784) I would hold that at this time of the day such a condition in any trust should be considered against public morals and, therefore, of no effect.
('57', 103, 1, 21, 177929) And if such a judgment can be obtained, clearly legislation must step in and rendersuch a clause invalid.
('57', 103, 1, 22, 178035) Rajbhoj fears that if Dr. Ambedkar accepts a reasonable compromise, Government may call another leader into being who will declare his opposition, and if that fear is realized there would be eternal opposition by the Government to any
('57', 104, 0, 1, 178270) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 105
('57', 104, 1, 2, 178320) pact, and, therefore, my fast must end in my death, and that, therefore, I should give up the fast.
('57', 104, 1, 3, 178420) Granting that Mr. Rajbhoj’s fear is justified I cannot undo a pledge taken with God as witness.
('57', 104, 1, 4, 178516) We are not able to forecast all future events.
('57', 104, 1, 5, 178563) We can, therefore, only control our acts, and it is well with us and our cause if we unflinchingly act on the square in spite of the heaviest odds.
('57', 104, 1, 6, 178711) Our final trust must rest upon the assured victory of truth.
('57', 104, 1, 7, 178772) Such correct action has without exception confounded the opponents and brought out the intended result, granting of course that the cause is as just as the action is correct.
('57', 104, 1, 8, 178947) I must not, therefore, on any account, suspend the fast unless its terms are fulfilled.
('57', 104, 1, 9, 179035) The Epic Fast, pp.

('57', 109, 2, 10, 186274) It is because, rightly or wrongly, I believe the British decision imposing separate electorates threatens to put huge obstacle in the way of reform, which has been for the past ten years moving on in geometrical progression, that I have staked my life to resist it.
('57', 109, 2, 11, 186540) After threed days, my conviction is stronger that the step I have taken is absolutely correct and, if my presentation is true, this cause demands the mobilization of world opinion, so as to compel right conduct by the British Government.

('57', 113, 0, 1, 191068) 114 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 113, 1, 2, 191110) 187. INTERVIEW TO “THE TIMES OF INDIA”
('57', 113, 2, 3, 191149) September 24, 1932 Yes, I shall certainly fast again, should the necessity arise as I firmly believe that by this means one can convince the world of the sincerity of one’s view.
('57', 113, 3, 4, 191328) So said Mr. Gandhi to me in answer to one of my questions when I had the pleasure of having a long talk with him on the fifth day of his fast in Yeravda Jail.
('57', 113, 4, 5, 191487) I certainly did not expect when I set off from Poona station before seven in the morning that I would be able to see Mr. Gandhi so early.
('57', 113, 4, 6, 191625) What a pleasant surprise it was when I received word from the jail authorities that the time was opportune.
('57', 113, 4, 7, 191733) The great doors of Yeravda swung open, and I walked in.
('57', 113, 5, 8, 191789) My escort led me through a courtyard, then through another little door which led on to a small compound roughly 150 feet by 40 feet wide, on one side of which were a few cells intended for State prisoners, but they all appeared to be unocccupied.
('57', 113, 5, 9, 192036) At one end of the compound under the shade of a small mango tree was Mr. Gandhi lying on a cot covered with a prison blanket.
('57', 113, 6, 10, 192162) At his head was one of his faithful followers fanning him gently with a towel to keep off pestering flies.
('57', 113, 6, 11, 192269) Seated round him were Mr. Vallabhbhai Patel, Mrs. Gandhi, Mr. Mahadev Desai.
('57', 113, 6, 12, 192346) Introductions over, Mr. Gandhi soon fell to asking me what particular question I wanted to ask him.
('57', 113, 6, 13, 192446) But to see him looking so frail and weak and obviously ill—well, it seemed too much to start interviewing.
('57', 113, 7, 14, 192553) But his eyes flashed when he answered my question.
('57', 113, 7, 15, 192604) He then appeared to recede into his shell, only raising himself up on his elbows to take a drink of water from a bottle at his side.
('57', 113, 8, 16, 192737) He said: Very nasty, you know.
('57', 113, 8, 17, 192768) At times I try to change it by putting in a pinch of salt, but through it all my stomach is in an intense state of nausea.
('57', 113, 9, 18, 192891) Mr. Gandhi said that he would be delighted to go to London for the third Conference if his demands would be met, but not otherwise.
('57', 113, 10, 19, 193023) Then I asked him what I thought was a pertinent question and certainly did not expect an answer, but the ailing man had always a ready reply, and here is what he said: You ask, ‘Suppose all Indian leaders decided to practise this method of gaining their own ends, no matter for what cause?’ Well, I admit, there is a lot of risk in the method.
('57', 113, 10, 20, 193367) But it is like every great power in the world.
('57', 113, 10, 21, 193414) Misuse creates mischief.
('57', 113, 10, 22, 193439) Let us take the
('57', 114, 0, 1, 193455) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 115
('57', 114, 1, 2, 193505) illustration of a well known poison—arsenic.
('57', 114, 1, 3, 193550) It is a most powerful medicinal drug, but should not on that account be blotted out of exist ence, although we know that many people make harmful use of it.
('57', 114, 1, 4, 193707) Therefore, if a thing is inherently good, and it is used at the proper time and in the proper measure, it is calculated to do universal good on an extensive scale almost bordering on the miraculous.
('57', 114, 1, 5, 193906) One must make use of that power irrespective of the fact that others are likely to make harmful use of it.
('57', 114, 2, 6, 194013) Further, in case of fasting of this nature, there is not much scope for it to thrive or become popular for the simple reason that it is such an agonizing process that ordinary human nature shudders at the very thought of having to undergo it.
('57', 114, 3, 7, 194256) So you see, the danger is not so very great.
('57', 114, 3, 8, 194301) It is only by training the body that one can do without food for any length of time.
('57', 114, 3, 9, 194386) The undisciplined and weak would soon give up the idea.
('57', 114, 4, 10, 194442) At the end of this long statement Mr. Gandhi leant back, weak from exhaustion, onto his bed.
('57', 114, 4, 11, 194535) Immediately two of the jail doctor were at his side to render what help they could.
('57', 114, 4, 12, 194619) But Mr. Gandhi seemed to derive most comfort from Mrs. Gandhi, who although obviously suffering, seemed delighted to have the opportunity of altering his pillow, rubbing his forehead with olive oil, and quietly talking to him.
('57', 114, 5, 13, 194846) Meanwhile, Mr. Gandhi’s disciples were receiving other political visitors and soon the compound was a scene of bustle and excitement.
('57', 114, 6, 14, 194980) From his secretary I gathered that Mr. Gandhi rose duirng his fast every morning at four; prayers were said from then to about half past four or five; then a shave by his prison barber, his breakfast—a drink of water—and, perhaps, an hour’s sleep.
('57', 114, 6, 15, 195228) But this was constantly interrupted by special cables from all over the world.
('57', 114, 7, 16, 195307) The Epic Fast, pp.

('57', 117, 7, 13, 198649) 194. RESOLUTION AT THE HINDU LEADERS’ CONFERENCE, BOMBAY 1
('57', 117, 8, 14, 198708) September 25, 1932 This Conference resolves that henceforth, amongst Hindus, no one shall be regarded as an untouchable by reason of his birth and those who have been so regarded hitherto will have the same rights as the other Hindus as regard to the use of public wells, public roads and other public institutions.
('57', 117, 8, 15, 199024) This right shall have statutory recognition at the first opportunity and shall be one of the earliest acts of the Swaraj Parliament, if it shall not have received such recognition before that time.
('57', 117, 8, 16, 199222) It is further agreed that it shall be the duty of all Hindu leaders to secure, by every legitimate and peaceful means, an early removal of all social disabilities now imposed by custom upon the so called untouchable classes including the bar in respect of admission to temples.
('57', 117, 9, 17, 199500) Mahatma, Vol. III, p.
('57', 117, 10, 18, 199522) 195. DRAFT RESOLUTION ON UNTOUCHABILITY
('57', 117, 11, 19, 199562) [September 25, 1932] 2
('57', 117, 12, 20, 199585) I am touchable by birth and an untouchable by choice.
('57', 117, 12, 21, 199639) It is as an untouchable that I have conceived the following part for the acceptance of touchables and untouchables.
('57', 117, 12, 22, 199755) Henceforth in Hinduism
('57', 117, 13, 23, 199778) 1 This resolution was drafted by Gandhiji.
('57', 117, 13, 24, 199821) 2 From para 2, which is reproduced as a “Resolution at the Hindu Leaders’ Conference, Bombay”, 25 9 1932; Vide “Resolution at the Hindu Leaders’ Conference, Bombay”, 25 9 1932.

('57', 118, 1, 2, 200048) no one shall be regarded as untouchable by reason of his birth or occupation.
('57', 118, 1, 3, 200126) Those who have been so regarded have the same right that the other Hindus have to entry into public temples, use of public wells, public schools, public roads and all other public institutions.
('57', 118, 1, 4, 200320) This right shall receive statutory recognition at the first opportunity and shall be the first act of the Swaraj Parliament if it has not already received statutory recognition.
('57', 118, 1, 5, 200498) Every adult male and female belon ging to the erstwhile untouchables class shall be registered as voter in the general joint register unless disqualified by reason of impriso nment or lunacy or mental deficiency within one year after first election for new provincial legislatures and the central legislature under the revised franchise.
('57', 118, 1, 6, 200836) A referendum shall be taken of the voters belonging to the e.u.c.
('57', 118, 1, 7, 200902) and if it is found that thirty three per cent of the votes of a provincial legislature or the central legislature as the case may be, have signified their dissatisfaction with the number of representatives of e.u.
('57', 118, 1, 8, 201116) class returned by the electorate, fresh elections of members of the general electorate shall take place for the particular provincial legislature or the central legislature as he case may be, with reservation of seat for the e.u.c.
('57', 118, 1, 9, 201348) guaranteed by statute for the next ten years on the basis of population, provided however that no referendum will be necessary where representatives of that class have been elected in accordance with the proportion of their population.
('57', 118, 1, 10, 201584) Untouchables shall be defined as those Hindus whose touch, sight or sound is regarded by popular local Hindu custom as pollution.
('57', 118, 1, 11, 201714) This pact 1 shall be sealed by representatives of Hindu Mahasabha, Hindu religious heads, well known learned Hindu scholars and shall be accompanied by a pledge as under, signed by at least two persons who have been known for their service of the cause of untouchability.
('57', 118, 1, 12, 201986) I hereby solemnly pledge myself to serve by strictly non violent and truthful means the due fulfilment by the so called caste Hindus of the pact entered into between them and the Hindus hitherto known as ‘untouchables’ and to that end shall be prepared to undergo all the
('57', 118, 2, 13, 202258) 1 Presumably the Poona Pact which was entered into between the leaders of Hindus and Depressed Classes at Poona on 24 9 1932 regarding reservation of seats for the Depressed Classes in the Legislatures; Vide “Agreement Between Depressed Classes Leaders and Caste Hindu Leaders”.

('57', 119, 3, 4, 202810) 196. MESSAGE TO GREAT BRITAIN 1
('57', 119, 4, 5, 202842) September 25, 1932
('57', 119, 5, 6, 202861) Every day of the fast seems to me conclusive evidence of the hand of God in it.
('57', 119, 5, 7, 202941) Even I with my boundless faith in God and His mercy was not prepared for this great wave of awakening against untouchability.
('57', 119, 5, 8, 203067) That some of the great temples should have spontaneously admitted the untouchables without restriction is to me a modern miracle.
('57', 119, 5, 9, 203197) They have only now admitted God.
('57', 119, 5, 10, 203230) Hitherto, the images which the custodians, falsely and in their pride, thought had God within were Godless.
('57', 119, 5, 11, 203338) The Cabinet decision was to me a timely warning from God that I was asleep when He was knocking at the door and waking me up.
('57', 119, 5, 12, 203464) The settlement 2 arrived at is to me but the beginning of the work of purification.
('57', 119, 5, 13, 203548) The agony of the soul is not going to end until every trace of untouchability is gone.
('57', 119, 5, 14, 203635) I do not want the British Cabinet to come to any hasty decision.
('57', 119, 5, 15, 203700) I do not want them for saving my life or for appearing to be right with the world to accept it in a niggardly spirit.
('57', 119, 5, 16, 203818) If they have not realized the true inwardness of the Agreement, they must summarily reject it, but if they have, they will not alter one word or comma of it, but they will implement every condition that is implied in the great settlement which the so called untouchables and the so called touchables have arrived at with all their heart and with God as their witness.
('57', 119, 5, 17, 204186) I hope that they and the world will realize that this settlement is, if I may say so in all humility, far superior to the Cabinet decision.
('57', 119, 5, 18, 204326) There is no pride about it.
('57', 119, 5, 19, 204354) The Cabinet composed of foreigners, knowing nothing first hand of the Indian conditions or what untouchability could mean, were labouring under a heavy handicap,
('57', 119, 6, 20, 204516) 1 The message was given in an interview to Ellen Wilkinson and V. K. Krishna Menon of the India League and was first published in The Daily Herald of London.
('57', 119, 6, 21, 204674) 2 For the text of the settlement, signed on September 24, Vide“Agreement Between Depressed Classes Leaders and Caste Hindu Leaders”.
('57', 120, 0, 1, 204807) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 121
('57', 120, 1, 2, 204857) and even though some Indians had referred this matter to them, they should have declined the responsibility to which they were wholly unequal.
('57', 120, 1, 3, 205000) I am not saying this from my penitential bed in any carping spirit or spirit of irritation.
('57', 120, 1, 4, 205092) I claim to be a true friend of the British nation and also of the Cabinet, and I would be untrue to them, to myself and to my call, if at this moment I suppressed my relevant opinion.
('57', 120, 1, 5, 205276) I would like finally to assure Britain that so long as life lasts in me, I shall undergo as many fasts as are necessary in order to purify Hinduism of this unbearable taint.
('57', 120, 1, 6, 205450) Thank God there is not only one man in this movement but, I believe, there are several thousands who will lay down their life in order to achieve this reform in its fulness.
('57', 120, 1, 7, 205624) The Epic Fast, pp.
('57', 120, 2, 8, 205643) 197. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('57', 120, 3, 9, 205671) September 25, 1932 If the Premier accepts the settlement in toto I would be bound to break the fast.
('57', 120, 3, 10, 205772) The settlement, as far as the political part of it is concerned, merely removes the tremendous obstacle that the Cabinet’s decision put in the way of reform.
('57', 120, 3, 11, 205930) The real part of the settlement is now to come and whilst, if the Premier accepts in toto the settlement cabled to him, my fast must end, the real struggle for me only begins.
('57', 120, 3, 12, 206106) As a matter of fact if the Cabinet had published the correspondence in time I would have been in honour bound to insist on the due fulfilment of the duty that lies on the so called caste Hindus.
('57', 120, 3, 13, 206301) I should be guilty of betrayal of trust if I did not ensure that, but as they had no notice worth the name of my intention to fast, I could not expect them all of a sudden to revolutionize Hindu thought.
('57', 120, 3, 14, 206505) They must, therefore, have breathing time for work, and so I have told fellow workers that if this fast is broken in virtue of the Cabinet’s satisfactory answer it would be put in suspension, but sure as fate, it will be taken up again if the part to be performed by the caste Hindus is not well played during the coming months.
('57', 120, 3, 15, 206834) The tremendous awakening that has taken place in the country during the five days fills me with hope that orthodoxy will surpass itself and rid Hinduism of the canker of untouchability which is eating into its vitals.
('57', 120, 3, 16, 207052) I suppose the future plan is in the hands of Government.
('57', 120, 3, 17, 207109) The Epic Fast, p.

('57', 121, 1, 2, 207169) 198. MESSAGE TO SOUTH INDIA
('57', 121, 2, 3, 207197) September 25, 1932 It has been a matter of increasing joy, day by day, to find great ancient temples being opened to the so called “untouchables” and thus becoming purified.
('57', 121, 2, 4, 207371) This one fact, among many others, has been a great sustaining force during these days of agony of body, mind and soul.
('57', 121, 2, 5, 207490) But the joy about the opening of the temples has not been unmixed with sorrow, in that the South, where my work on a larger scale amongst “untouchables” began, though in South Africa, has not been as prompt and generous in throwing open the gates of the temples to outcastes.
('57', 121, 2, 6, 207766) Speaking as a Hindu, striving to find and to live up to the very essence of it, I say, without the slightest hesitation, that God will be installed in the idols of the temples only if they are thrown open unreservedly to outcastes.
('57', 121, 2, 7, 207998) Today, with human outcastes, God Himself is an outcaste.
('57', 121, 2, 8, 208055) M. K. GANDHI The Hindu, 26 9 1932

('57', 122, 6, 8, 209628) 201. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS
('57', 122, 7, 9, 209656) September 26, 1932
('57', 122, 8, 10, 209675) The fast undertaken in the name of the God was broken in the presence of Gurudev, and Parachure Shastri, the leper prisoner and a learned pandit, seated opposite each other, and in the company of loving and loved ones who had gathered round me.
('57', 122, 8, 11, 209920) The breaking was preceded by the Poet singing one of his Bengali hymns, then mantras from the Upanishads by Parachure Shastri, and then my favourite hymn “Vaishnava Jana” .
('57', 122, 8, 12, 210093) The hand of God has been visible in the glorious manifestation throughout the length and breadth of India during the past seven days.
('57', 122, 8, 13, 210227) The cables received from many parts of the world blessing the fast have sustained me through the agony of body and soul that I passed through during the seven days, but the cause was worth going through that agony.
('57', 122, 8, 14, 210442) The sacrificial fire, once lit, shall not be put out as long as there is the slightest trace of untouchability still left in Hinduism.
('57', 122, 8, 15, 210577) If it is God’s will that it does not end with my life, I have the confidence that there are several thousands of earnest reformers who will lay down their lives in order to purify Hinduism of this awful curse.
('57', 122, 8, 16, 210787) The settlement arrived at is, so far as I can see, a generous gesture on all sides.
('57', 122, 8, 17, 210871) It is a meeting of hearts, and my Hindu gratitude is due to Dr. Ambedkar, Rao Bahadur Srinivasan and their party on the one hand and Rao Bahadur M. C. Raja on the other.
('57', 122, 8, 18, 211041) They could have taken up an uncompromising and defiant attitude by way of punishment to the so called caste Hindus for the sins of generations.
('57', 122, 8, 19, 211185) If they had done so, I at least could not have resented their attitude and my death would have been but a triffling price exacted for the
('57', 123, 0, 1, 211323) 124 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 123, 1, 2, 211365) tortures that the outcastes of Hinduism have been going through for unknown generations.
('57', 123, 1, 3, 211454) But they chose a nobler path and have thus shown that they have followed the precept of forgiveness enjoined by all religi ons.
('57', 123, 1, 4, 211582) Let me hope that the caste Hindus will prove themselves worthy of this forgiveness and carry out to the letter and spirit every clause of the settlement with all its implications.
('57', 123, 1, 5, 211762) The settlement is but the beginning of the end.
('57', 123, 1, 6, 211810) The political part of it, very important though it no doubt is, occupies but a small space in the vast field of reform that has to be tackled by caste Hindus during the coming days, namely, the complete removal of social and religious disabilities under which a large part of the Hindu population has been groaning.
('57', 123, 1, 7, 212126) I should be guilty of a breach of trust if I did not warn fellow reformers and caste Hindus in general that the breaking of the fast carried with it a sure promise of a resumption of it if this reform is not relentlessly pursued and achieved within a measurable period.
('57', 123, 1, 8, 212396) I had thought of laying down a period, but I feel that I may not do so without a definite call from within.
('57', 123, 1, 9, 212504) The message of freedom shall penetrate every untouchable home and that can only happen if reformers will cover every village.
('57', 123, 1, 10, 212630) Yet, in the wave of enthusiasm and in an inordinate desire to spare me a repetition of the agony, there should be no coercion.
('57', 123, 1, 11, 212757) We must, by patient toil and self suffering, convert the ignorant and the supersti tious but never seek to compel them by force.
('57', 123, 1, 12, 212886) I wish, too, that the almost ideal solution that has been arrived at may be followed by the other communities, and that we might see the dawn of a new era of mutual trust, mutual give and take, and a recognition of the fundamental unity of all communities.
('57', 123, 1, 13, 213143) I would here single out the Hindu Muslim Sikh question.
('57', 123, 1, 14, 213199) I am the same to the Mussalman today that I was in 1920 22. I should be just as prepared to lay down my life as I was in Delhi 1 to achieve organic unity andpermanent peace between them.
('57', 123, 1, 15, 213386) I hope and pray that there will be, as a result of this upheaval, a spontaneous move in this direction and then, surely, the other communities can no longer stand out.
('57', 123, 1, 16, 213554) In conclusion, I would like to thank the Government and the Jail staff and the medical men appointed by the Government to look after me.
('57', 123, 1, 17, 213691) Extreme care and attention was bestowed upon me.
('57', 123, 1, 18, 213740) Nothing was left undone.
('57', 123, 1, 19, 213765) The jail staff worked under terrible pressures, and I
('57', 123, 2, 20, 213819) 1 In September 1924.
('57', 124, 0, 1, 213840) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 125
('57', 124, 1, 2, 213890) observed that they did not grudge this labour.
('57', 124, 1, 3, 213937) I thank them all from high to low.
('57', 124, 1, 4, 213972) I thank the British Cabinet for hastening the decision on settlement.
('57', 124, 1, 5, 214042) The terms of the decision sent to me I have not approached without misgivings.
('57', 124, 1, 6, 214121) It accepts, I suppose very naturally, only that part of the Agreement that refers to the British Cabinet’s communal decision.
('57', 124, 1, 7, 214247) I expect that they had a constitutional difficulty in now announcing their acceptance of the whole Agreement.
('57', 124, 1, 8, 214357) But I would like to assure my Harijan friends, as I would like hencefoth to name them, that so far as I am concerned, I am wedded to the whole of that Agreement, and that they may hold my life as hostage for its due fulfilment, unless we ourselves arrive at any other and better settlement of our own free will.
('57', 124, 2, 9, 214669) The Hindu, 27 9 1932, and The Epic Fast, pp.

('57', 129, 2, 4, 220795) They have to perform their part during this period of purification.
('57', 129, 2, 5, 220863) Owing to suppression they have been deprived of ways and means of observing, and the incentive to the observation of, the ordinary laws of cleanliness and the like, but let us hope that a new era has dawned upon us.
('57', 129, 2, 6, 221079) I hope that Harijans will understand this and in so far as possible they will observe the laws of cleanliness, abstain from intoxicating liquors and drugs and make a mighty effort to get rid of all social evils.

('57', 131, 5, 6, 224245) 215. LETTER TO M. G. BHANDARI
('57', 131, 6, 7, 224275) September 29, 1932 (1.45 p.
('57', 131, 7, 8, 224303) DEAR MAJOR BHANDARI,
('57', 131, 8, 9, 224324) The orders you verbally conveyed to me at 12.30 this morning I interpret as follows: I am not to be allowed to see from this date any visitors regarding untouchability or any other public work, except Sjts.
('57', 131, 8, 10, 224531) Ghanshyamdas Birla and Mathuradas Vasanji.
('57', 131, 8, 11, 224574) Secondly Mrs. Gandhi should be forthwith removed to the Female Yard; all other visits to be regulated as before the fast, under the general instructions that were conveyed to me soon after my admission and amended thereafter.
('57', 131, 8, 12, 224800) This means that I shall not have the privilege of seeing Shrimati Sarojinidevi, whose presence during my illnesses has produced a soothing effect on me, nor of my son Devdas and his intended wife, nor of the Ashram inmates who have been in attendance upon me during this crisis.
('57', 131, 8, 13, 225079) I must confess that I was wholly unprepared for this very sudden and rude reminder that I was but a prisoner whose body was entirely at the mercy of the Government.
('57', 131, 8, 14, 225244) I would like, however, the Government to know that I am still considered to be convalescent and under orders not even to move from my bed.
('57', 131, 8, 15, 225383) I had hoped that at least during the convalescent period I would be saved all unnecessary shock to my nerves.
('57', 131, 8, 16, 225493) However, this need not be a matter of moment to the Government and ought not to worry me overmuch, if at all.
('57', 131, 8, 17, 225603) Indeed I am thankful for the medical attendance that the Government provided for me and the free attendance of visitors and friends during the fast.
('57', 131, 8, 18, 225752) But what I cannot understand is this sudden stopping of all visits, even in connection with untouchability work, save those of Sjts.
('57', 131, 8, 19, 225885) Ghanshyamdas and Mathuradas.
('57', 131, 8, 20, 225914) The Government cannot be unaware of the phenomenal awakening that has taken place in the country, nor of the repercussions of the fast whose limitations have been but little understood and which is being blindly imitated by enthusiastic young men.
('57', 131, 8, 21, 226162) I therfore hold it absolutely necessary that I should be left
('57', 132, 0, 1, 226224) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 133
('57', 132, 1, 2, 226274) entirely free to see whomsoever I consider necessary regarding untouchability.
('57', 132, 1, 3, 226353) The Government have not yet seemed to have revised their instructions regarding correspondence.
('57', 132, 1, 4, 226449) Needless to say what applied to visitors regarding untouchability applies equally to correspondence.
('57', 132, 1, 5, 226550) Nor need I add that I should not have the slightest objection to Government officials and interpreters attending any interviews I might have with visitors and my correspondence being scrutinized.
('57', 132, 1, 6, 226746) As this is a matter of the greatest urgency, I hope that the Government will favour me with their decision at the earliest possible moment.
('57', 132, 2, 7, 226886) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('57', 132, 3, 8, 226916) From a photostat: G.N. 3861. Also Bombay Secret Abstracts, Home Department, Special Branch, File No.
('57', 132, 3, 9, 227017) 800(40)(4), Pt. I, p.

('57', 142, 1, 2, 239146) 243. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('57', 142, 2, 3, 239170) [October 1] 1 1932
('57', 142, 3, 4, 239189) MIRA, As you were not getting my letters regularly I purposely refrained from writing to you yesterday.
('57', 142, 3, 5, 239293) This I am writing early morning just after taking oranges and grape juice.
('57', 142, 3, 6, 239368) I am flourishing, my weight showeed 993 4 yesterday against 931 2 which was the weight on Monday.
('57', 142, 3, 7, 239466) This is a wonderful improvement.
('57', 142, 3, 8, 239499) In a day or two, I shall be walking a little.
('57', 142, 3, 9, 239545) The bowels require the enema still but I expect them to be normal soon.
('57', 142, 3, 10, 239617) Food is oranges eight, grapes, glucose powder four tea spoons, milk 11 2 Ib., clear vegetable soup marrow and tomatoes.
('57', 142, 3, 11, 239737) Of these I take something on an average every 21 2 hours.
('57', 142, 3, 12, 239795) I spun yesterday 235 rounds without feeling much tired.
('57', 142, 3, 13, 239851) The spinning was done in two periods.
('57', 142, 3, 14, 239889) Wrote a number of letters for the English mail and to correspondents here.
('57', 142, 3, 15, 239964) With intervals for meals and rest, etc.
('57', 142, 3, 16, 240004) I worked till 8 p.m.
('57', 142, 3, 17, 240025) yesterday and now feel none the worse for it.
('57', 142, 3, 18, 240071) All this is very good progress.
('57', 142, 3, 19, 240103) And so I continue to hum, ‘God is great and merciful.’ The fast was nothing compared to what it brought forth.
('57', 142, 3, 20, 240214) It was not man's achievement.
('57', 142, 3, 21, 240244) It was God’s doing.
('57', 142, 3, 22, 240264) All this must remove your sadness.
('57', 142, 3, 23, 240299) You must have seen from the papers that as to interviews, etc., the pre fast restrictions are practically in force.
('57', 142, 3, 24, 240415) Ba can see me during the day.
('57', 142, 3, 25, 240445) Love to you and Kisen.
('57', 142, 4, 26, 240468) BAPU [PS.] I understand you have now no other companion.

('57', 146, 10, 13, 244855) 254. LETTER TO S. M. MATE
('57', 146, 11, 14, 244881) October 2, 1932 I can understand your reasoning.
('57', 146, 11, 15, 244930) 4 Only my fast is not intended to coerce anybody.
('57', 146, 11, 16, 244980) It is meant to quicken into life sluggish con science.
('57', 146, 11, 17, 245035) That it may coerce some is unfortunately true.
('57', 146, 11, 18, 245082) But such coercion can neither be prolonged nor extensive.
('57', 146, 11, 19, 245140) A religious reformer does not attempt to dominate the mind.
('57', 146, 11, 20, 245200) He stirs up people and makes them think and act.
('57', 146, 11, 21, 245249) I must not purchase my release at the sacrifice of my principles.
('57', 146, 11, 22, 245315) Removal of untouchability is a vital part of my life’s programme, but it is not the sole part of it.
('57', 146, 11, 23, 245416) 5 My life is in God’s hands.
('57', 146, 11, 24, 245445) He will shape it as He wills.
('57', 146, 11, 25, 245475) Do you not think I am in safe hands?
('57', 146, 12, 26, 245512) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, p.
('57', 146, 13, 27, 245545) 1 The addressee, Gandhiji’s elder sister, had wired her good wishes on the occasion of Gandhiji’s birthday.
('57', 146, 13, 28, 245653) 2 This was in reply to a telegram dated September 30, from the addressee saying he was writing a book about Gandhiji’s life mission with special reference to the historic fast and seeking Gandhiji’s blessings.
('57', 146, 13, 29, 245863) 3 In “Diary, 1932” Gandhiji, in the entry under October 3, mentions having sent a telegram to the addressee the previous day.
('57', 146, 13, 30, 245989) Presumably this is the telegram.
('57', 146, 13, 31, 246022) 4 The addressee had advised Gandhiji that instead of seeking to coerce through fasting he should use the method of peaceful persuasion.
('57', 146, 13, 32, 246158) 5 The addressee had further said that if he were to declare that he would only work for the removal of untouchability for a year he might be released.

('57', 147, 1, 2, 246351) 255. LETTER TO PURATAN BUCH
('57', 147, 2, 3, 246379) October 2, 1932
('57', 147, 3, 4, 246395) PURATAN, You have asked a good question.
('57', 147, 3, 5, 246436) Arjuna did not know what to do and he asked [Krishna] 1 to guide him.
('57', 147, 3, 6, 246506) No such doubt had arisen in my mind, but Krishna himself roused me and urged me not to miss this opportunity.
('57', 147, 3, 7, 246616) An indefinite fast may be the highest expression of ahimsa and it may even be folly.
('57', 147, 3, 8, 246701) I believe that my fast was the former.
('57', 147, 3, 9, 246740) The outcome also seems to indicate that it was so.
('57', 147, 3, 10, 246791) Fasting has a place, and an important one, in the tapascharya enjoined 2 in Hindu dharma.
('57', 147, 3, 11, 246881) Thus there is a difference between Arjuna’s case and [mine].
('57', 147, 3, 12, 246942) I don’t wish to suggest by this that I have more knowledge than Arjuna.
('57', 147, 3, 13, 247014) I only wish to point out that in this instance it was not a question of ignorance in me.
('57', 147, 3, 14, 247103) Is this clear ?
('57', 147, 3, 15, 247119) You must have read in the newspapers that visitors are no longer permitted to see me.
('57', 147, 4, 16, 247205) Blessings from BAPU
('57', 147, 5, 17, 247225) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G. N. 9169

('57', 148, 6, 8, 247856) 258. LETTER TO RAMDAS GANDHI
('57', 148, 7, 9, 247885) October 2, 1932 There is no doubt that the vow which you contemplate is excellent.
('57', 148, 7, 10, 247968) If you have arrived at the decision independently on your own, there is no need to discuss the matter with Nimu for the present.
('57', 148, 7, 11, 248097) Your peace of mind is bound to have its effect on her.
('57', 148, 7, 12, 248152) That is the beauty of brahmacharya.
('57', 148, 7, 13, 248188) The need for mutual discussion arises when both are equally weak in mind, but equally eager to practise self control also; for, then, the resolution of one partner helps the other.
('57', 148, 7, 14, 248369) When one partner has made up his or her mind, he or she will not discuss the matter with the other, as his or her self control will of itself work on the other.
('57', 148, 7, 15, 248530) This is only to tell you my own experience in the matter, and you are free to act as you think best.
('57', 148, 7, 16, 248631) In such matters other people’s wisdom does not avail one much.
('57', 148, 7, 17, 248694) In such a holy resolution you can of course take my blessings for granted, but take the vow only after you are released from prison.
('57', 148, 7, 18, 248827) Many have given up the vows they made while in prison.
('57', 148, 7, 19, 248882) The two environments are different.
('57', 148, 7, 20, 248918) They are two entirely different worlds.
('57', 148, 7, 21, 248958) [From Gujarati]
('57', 148, 8, 22, 248974) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, p.
('57', 148, 9, 23, 249007) 259. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI
('57', 148, 10, 24, 249039) October 2, 1932
('57', 148, 11, 25, 249055) CHHAGANLAL (JOSHI), Do not expect a long letter for some time yet.
('57', 148, 11, 26, 249122) I have started writing letters to the Ashram and intend to write to as many persons as I can.
('57', 148, 11, 27, 249216) You exercised good self control in not coming to see me.

('57', 149, 0, 1, 249340) 150 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 149, 1, 2, 249382) fault with you.
('57', 149, 1, 3, 249398) But I admire you the better for not coming.
('57', 149, 1, 4, 249442) The get up of Ashramvasi Pratye is beautiful indeed.
('57', 149, 1, 5, 249495) As for the contents, I have yet to look into them.
('57', 149, 1, 6, 249546) I know that anti untouchability work in villages is very difficult.
('57', 149, 1, 7, 249614) Only workers like you can judge how far the awakening witnessed during the week of the fast has spread among the villages.

('57', 149, 1, 10, 249864) I fasted as long as it was God's will that I should.

('57', 149, 1, 13, 250111) Has He not given His word that He will give us the strength to do so ?

('57', 150, 1, 2, 251288) 261. LETTER TO PREMABEHN KANTAK
('57', 150, 2, 3, 251320) October 2, 1932
('57', 150, 3, 4, 251336) PREMA, I cannot write you a long letter today.
('57', 150, 3, 5, 251383) Who is afraid of your biting?
('57', 150, 3, 6, 251413) Our cat often bites its kittens, but the more she does that the more they cling to her.
('57', 150, 3, 7, 251501) When she lifts Soma 1 with her teeth, he does not cry but, on the contrary, feels more secure.
('57', 150, 3, 8, 251596) Your biting must be like the cat’s.
('57', 150, 3, 9, 251632) You have quoted fine verses indeed.
('57', 150, 3, 10, 251668) I admire your self control, too.
('57', 150, 3, 11, 251701) But neither you nor the other inmates of the Ashram need feel elated.
('57', 150, 3, 12, 251771) Old man Abbas, Raihana and others danced with joy when they knew the cause of my fast.
('57', 150, 3, 13, 251858) They did not even express a wish to come and see me.
('57', 150, 3, 14, 251911) They trusted that I was under God’s care and went on with their tasks.
('57', 150, 3, 15, 251982) Others, too, acted in the same manner.
('57', 150, 3, 16, 252021) Tell me, now, how much weight did you gain during my fast ?

('57', 152, 1, 2, 253631) 266. LETTER TO MAHALAKSHMI M. THAKKAR
('57', 152, 2, 3, 253669) October 2, 1932
('57', 152, 3, 4, 253685) MAHALAKSHMI, I got your letter.
('57', 152, 3, 5, 253717) You have done no wrong in starting wearing bangles.
('57', 152, 3, 6, 253769) The mistake lay in your resolution not to wear them, and so I think that you have now made amends for the mistake by wearing them to please the elders in the family.
('57', 152, 3, 7, 253935) Let this be a lesson to you that all resolutions should be made after careful thinking, and that once you have made a resolution you should not give it up for anybody’s sake.
('57', 152, 3, 8, 254110) Do not brood over what has happened.
('57', 152, 3, 9, 254147) Live on milk, vegetables and fruit if rotli does not agree.
('57', 152, 3, 10, 254207) Milk of course includes curds and buttermilk.
('57', 152, 3, 11, 254253) Aren’t the children still in a condition to live in the Ashram?
('57', 152, 3, 12, 254317) Pay a visit to the Ashram and see how things are there at present.
('57', 152, 3, 13, 254384) If you cannot do that, don’t shift them from Calcutta but be satisfied with what you can do for them there.
('57', 152, 3, 14, 254492) Ultimately their place is in the Ashram, and, to accustom them to the Ashram you should live there for a short time, if necessary.
('57', 152, 4, 15, 254623) Blessings from BAPU

('57', 153, 7, 13, 255518) [October 2, 1932] 1
('57', 153, 8, 14, 255538) NARANDAS,
('57', 153, 9, 15, 255548) The accompanying letters will give you an indication of my strength.
('57', 153, 9, 16, 255617) I have now regained a good deal of it.
('57', 153, 9, 17, 255656) I became weaker than I had thought, but I am recovering rapidly.
('57', 153, 9, 18, 255721) On the Sunday during my fast, my weight was 931 2 pounds.
('57', 153, 9, 19, 255779) Today, which is again a Sunday, it stands at 100 pounds.
('57', 153, 9, 20, 255836) This is good improvement.
('57', 153, 9, 21, 255862) My diet at present is a pound and a half of milk, eight to ten oranges, pomegranate or grape juice, soup of gourd and tomatoes, honey and lemon juice.
('57', 153, 9, 22, 256013) I hope that I shall be able to increase the quantity of milk by a little.
('57', 153, 9, 23, 256087) I don’t expect I shall make any other change for some time.
('57', 153, 9, 24, 256147) I walked a little yesterday and today.
('57', 153, 9, 25, 256186) The quantity of stool has increased today in the natural course.
('57', 153, 9, 26, 256251) I sleep fairly well.
('57', 153, 9, 27, 256272) Ba spends the whole day with me.
('57', 153, 9, 28, 256305) In the evening, she goes to Lady Vithaldas’s place.
('57', 153, 9, 29, 256357) I suffered much during the fast but enjoyed boundless peace.
('57', 153, 9, 30, 256418) God tested me fairly severely.
('57', 153, 9, 31, 256449) Yet on the whole the test was light.
('57', 153, 9, 32, 256486) A seven days’ fast means nothing to me.
('57', 153, 9, 33, 256526) But the physical and mental suffering during this short period was considerable.
('57', 153, 9, 34, 256607) I cannot say how

('57', 173, 7, 15, 280611) October [5] 1, 1932
('57', 173, 8, 16, 280631) MIRA, Your letter came in today (Wednesday).
('57', 173, 8, 17, 280676) My writing was with the right hand.
('57', 173, 8, 18, 280712) You found it clear because owing to the weakness of the body I had to trace my letters slowly.
('57', 173, 8, 19, 280807) The left elbow was at fault.
('57', 173, 8, 20, 280836) Up to yesterday there was no pain at all.
('57', 173, 8, 21, 280878) But today I have a feeling that it would return with the filling in of the flesh.
('57', 173, 8, 22, 280960) If it does return, it need not cause any anxiety.

('57', 173, 8, 24, 281055) 200 rounds at least.
('57', 173, 8, 25, 281076) Keshu brought a new Gandiva.
('57', 173, 8, 26, 281105) It works extremely well.
('57', 173, 8, 27, 281130) I do not think I take more than one and a half hours.
('57', 173, 8, 28, 281184) My weight stands at 99 lb.
('57', 173, 8, 29, 281211) Now that I take some exercise, the weight cannot and must not increase by leaps.
('57', 173, 8, 30, 281292) I have taken two pounds of milk today and for the first time, 20 dates.
('57', 173, 8, 31, 281364) Ba is with me during the day, feeding and nursing me.
('57', 173, 8, 32, 281418) I have to give much time to correspondence as the volume has increased enormously.
('57', 173, 8, 33, 281501) I wrote a note to Kisen.
('57', 173, 8, 34, 281526) I wonder if she received it.
('57', 173, 8, 35, 281555) Narandas has got the permission to see you, if you would care to see him.
('57', 173, 8, 36, 281629) Do you get all the letters collected during the week or only one per week?
('57', 173, 8, 37, 281704) So you see that you cannot build a theory on a few days’ or even months’ observation.
('57', 173, 8, 38, 281790) Do not now try to fix the quantity of salt mechanically.

('57', 177, 10, 21, 287068) Now that matter is one of life and death and though Sjt.
('57', 177, 10, 22, 287125) Kelappan’s fast has been suspended at my instance, he is by no means yet out of the wood.
('57', 177, 10, 23, 287215) And now I am necessarily dragged into it because of my successful intervention.
('57', 177, 10, 24, 287295) The Zamorin of Calicut is the central figure in this controversy.
('57', 177, 10, 25, 287361) Kelappan’s fast is suspended only for three months.
('57', 177, 10, 26, 287413) There is not therefore much time to be wasted.
('57', 177, 10, 27, 287460) I should therefore like to know when this telegram will be sent to the Zamorin and whether I am free to carry on correspondence in connection with untouch ability.
('57', 177, 10, 28, 287624) Delay is a matter of great danger and vexation.

('57', 178, 5, 10, 288242) October 6, 1932 Thanks for your sweet letter.

('57', 178, 5, 12, 288355) My feeling coincides with your washer woman’s.
('57', 178, 5, 13, 288402) There was once a scientific expedition in search of God.

('57', 179, 1, 2, 289457) 327. LETTER TO HARIBHAU PHATAK
('57', 179, 2, 3, 289488) October 6, 1932 Let this suffice as a brief answer to your questions.
('57', 179, 2, 4, 289558) Inter dining and intermarriage are not an essential part of removal of untouchability root and branch.
('57', 179, 2, 5, 289661) These two form a separate reform and must come one day for all sections of Hinduism.
('57', 179, 2, 6, 289746) Nothing can be or should be done by compulsion.
('57', 179, 2, 7, 289794) Fasting and the like are not designed to compel people to act against their wills, they are designed to make people think and act.
('57', 179, 2, 8, 289925) If untouchables are no longer untouchable what are they in Hindu society?
('57', 179, 2, 9, 289999) My own opinion is that the varna system has just now broken down.
('57', 179, 2, 10, 290065) There is no true Brahmin or true Kshatriya or Vaishya.
('57', 179, 2, 11, 290120) We are all Shudras, i.e., one varna.
('57', 179, 2, 12, 290157) If this position is accepted, then the thing becomes easy.
('57', 179, 2, 13, 290216) If this does not satisfy our vanity, then we are all Brahmins.
('57', 179, 2, 14, 290279) Removal of untouchability does mean root and branch destruction of the idea of superiority and inferiority.
('57', 179, 2, 15, 290387) He who says, ‘ I am more than my fellow’ debases himself; he who says, ‘I am the least among my fellows’ raises himself.
('57', 179, 2, 16, 290508) My fast was intended not to deal with the question superficially but to make us true.
('57', 179, 2, 17, 290594) I wish I could mechanically fix the time limit.
('57', 179, 2, 18, 290642) Who am I to do so?
('57', 179, 2, 19, 290661) But this I can say from my past, there will be no fast in this matter if the reform is progressing steadily and there is no humbug or make believe behind it.
('57', 179, 2, 20, 290819) Real progress is self demonstrated.
('57', 179, 2, 21, 290855) The Harijans will feel its glow in unmistakable terms.
('57', 179, 2, 22, 290910) I would beseech you therefore not to worry about the time limit.
('57', 179, 2, 23, 290975) We all believe in idols and images of some sort.
('57', 179, 2, 24, 291024) The ordinary temple has no attraction for me personally.
('57', 179, 2, 25, 291081) But it has a tremendous spiritual value.
('57', 179, 2, 26, 291122) Therefore it must be open to Harjians.
('57', 179, 2, 27, 291161) Reform of temples, not their destruction, is necessary.
('57', 179, 3, 28, 291217) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.
('57', 180, 0, 1, 291251) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 181

('57', 183, 4, 9, 295354) 337. LETTER TO NIRMALA B. MASHRUWALA
('57', 183, 5, 10, 295391) October 7, 1932
('57', 183, 6, 11, 295407) NIRMALA, You must have got my postcards 1. All who go to Nasik or write to a prisoner there should remember what I have explained.
('57', 183, 6, 12, 295538) Anybody who goes to Thana or writes to someone there may also make use of it.
('57', 183, 7, 13, 295616) I got two letters from Kishorelal and one from Gomati.
('57', 183, 7, 14, 295671) I need not say anything about the propriety or otherwise of the fast.
('57', 183, 7, 15, 295741) There was certainly some defect in it, but the fast was absolutely necessary.
('57', 183, 7, 16, 295819) It may be regarded as the ultimate step in non violence.
('57', 183, 7, 17, 295876) I am now gradually regaining my strength.
('57', 183, 7, 18, 295918) In fact I have regained most of it.
('57', 183, 7, 19, 295954) The weight, which had gone down to 93.5 lb has now risen to 99. Before the fast it was 101. I am sure that on the whole the fast will benefit my health.
('57', 183, 7, 20, 296107) My daily food consists of 2lb.of milk, nine oranges or mosambis juice of pomegranates or grapes, and gourd or tomato soup once a day.
('57', 183, 7, 21, 296241) I walk in the morning and in the evening for a total of an hour and a half without getting tired, write quite a large number of letters, and spin at least 200 rounds, going up to as far as 40 counts.
('57', 183, 7, 22, 296441) Ba is allowed to stay with me during the day.
('57', 183, 7, 23, 296487) Devdas is permitted to come and see me.
('57', 183, 7, 24, 296527) It is necessary that we should spin as fine yarn as we can.
('57', 183, 7, 25, 296587) I also admit the moral blemish in wearing clothes of fine yarn, but fine cloth
('57', 183, 8, 26, 296666) 1 For one of these Vide “Letter to Nirmala B. Mashruwala”, 3 10 1932.

('57', 184, 1, 2, 296786) has also some benefits.
('57', 184, 1, 3, 296810) It is very necessary from an artistic point of view.
('57', 184, 1, 4, 296863) In the attempt to spin fine yarn, one makes many discoveries.
('57', 184, 1, 5, 296925) It makes for deftness of the hand.
('57', 184, 1, 6, 296960) In the past the people were forced to spin fine yarn.

('57', 184, 1, 8, 297217) If we have to pay the full labour charges for fine yarn, the cost of such cloth would be exceedingly high.
('57', 184, 1, 9, 297324) It was not proper for Kishorelal to have insisted on spinning a thousand rounds during the week of the fast.

('57', 187, 1, 2, 301295) 342. LETTER TO MOHANLAL
('57', 187, 2, 3, 301319) October 8, 1932
('57', 187, 3, 4, 301335) BHAISHRI MOHANLAL, You are right in your view that inter dining and inter marrying with Antyajas are not a necessary part of the movement for the eradication of untouchability.
('57', 187, 3, 5, 301512) Hence there can be no coercion brought to bear on anybody in regard to these.
('57', 187, 3, 6, 301590) If, however, anybody wishes of his own free will to have such relations with Antyajas, he should not be prevented from doing so, just as members of “touchable” communities are not prevented from having such relations among themselves.
('57', 187, 3, 7, 301825) Eradication of untouchability means permitting Harijans, and persuading others to permit them, to enjoy the rights which as a human being every Hindu enjoys.
('57', 187, 4, 8, 301983) MOHANDAS GANDHI
('57', 187, 5, 9, 301999) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 232
('57', 187, 6, 10, 302042) 343. LETTER TO MOHANLAL M. BHATT
('57', 187, 7, 11, 302075) October, 8, 1932 There was some merit in Mohamad Kaji’s decision to observe the roza.
('57', 187, 7, 12, 302161) Islam enjoins keeping of the roza during a time of mis fortune.
('57', 187, 7, 13, 302225) One other Muslim friend also had kept the roza at that time.
('57', 187, 7, 14, 302286) The roza is not a fast.
('57', 187, 7, 15, 302310) In this matter Muslim friends should earnestly wish that, just as the problem of the Antyajas has been solved, that of the Hindus, Muslims and Sikhs also may be solved, and should do their duty towards that end.
('57', 187, 7, 16, 302522) A solution of the problem from the religious point of view was certainly one of the aims of my fast.
('57', 187, 7, 17, 302623) The Hindu public realized this without any propaganda for that purpose, and the great awakening that has come about is indeed of a religious nature.
('57', 187, 7, 18, 302772) From the religious standpoint the Government award would have destroyed the Antyajas.
('57', 187, 7, 19, 302858) As compared with that aspect of the problem, the political aspect was insignificant.
('57', 187, 7, 20, 302943) Politics is included in religion and is not an independent activity.
('57', 187, 7, 21, 303012) The solution of the Antyajas problem from a religious point of view includes the solution of the problem of all oppressed races in the world.
('57', 187, 7, 22, 303154) The Christians and Muslims also seem to have grasped this point.
('57', 187, 7, 23, 303219) I see no violation of principle in a teetotaller present at a feast
('57', 188, 0, 1, 303287) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 189
('57', 188, 1, 2, 303337) passing a glass of wine.
('57', 188, 1, 3, 303362) If one attends such a feast, it is one’s duty, according to me, to pass the glass and there is no hypocrisy in doing so.
('57', 188, 1, 4, 303483) That is one way of quietly winning the love of the people who drink.
('57', 188, 1, 5, 303552) This argument applies only to a strict teetotaller, and the question also was put with reference to such a person.
('57', 188, 1, 6, 303667) If my reply is not properly understood, it is likely to be misapplied, but I have no fear in giving you this reply.
('57', 188, 1, 7, 303783) [From Gujarati]
('57', 188, 2, 8, 303799) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.
