('57', 189, 9, 10, 305302) 347. LETTER TO NARAYAN M. KHARE
('57', 189, 10, 11, 305334) October 8, 1932
('57', 189, 11, 12, 305350) PANDITJI, I got your letters.
('57', 189, 11, 13, 305380) Mixed dinner parties with Harijans are not a necessary part of the movement against untouchability, but they are consequence of it.
('57', 189, 11, 14, 305512) I am glad, too, that they take place.
('57', 189, 11, 15, 305550) Though opposition to them is only to be expected, no one will be able to stop them if such dinners have become a popular movement.
('57', 189, 11, 16, 305681) There is no argument whatever based on dharma in support of ideas of pollution through food, etc.
('57', 189, 11, 17, 305779) While we do not encourage image worship in the Ashram, we do not forbid it either.
('57', 189, 11, 18, 305862) Temples in one form or another will always remain as long as Hinduism flourishes.
('57', 189, 11, 19, 305944) Antyajas should have the right to enter all temples recognized as such by the Hindus.
('57', 189, 11, 20, 306030) It cannot be otherwise if we wish to root out the very idea of a certain class of people being Antyajas.
('57', 189, 11, 21, 306135) Hence, not only is there no contradiction of Ashram principles in an Ashram inmate encouraging temple entry, but on the contrary it is his duty to encourage it.
('57', 189, 11, 22, 306296) From a religious standpoint, this issue is very important for the Antyajas.
('57', 189, 11, 23, 306372) It is going to be a test for the Hindus.
('57', 189, 11, 24, 306413) I think it necessary that Ashram inmates should be permitted to go, or should go, to work outside for anti untouchability work.
('57', 189, 11, 25, 306541) All Ashram inmates are intended and trained ultimately to go out to work
('57', 190, 0, 1, 306614) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 191
('57', 190, 1, 2, 306664) among the people.
('57', 190, 1, 3, 306682) No inmate of the Ashram who wishes to worship Ganesh or any other deity should be stopped from doing so.
('57', 190, 2, 4, 306787) However, as an institution we should, in my opinion, remain equal towards all religions and, therefore, should not permit a public temple with an idol in the Ashram.
('57', 190, 2, 5, 306953) Our public temple is the open prayer ground with the horizons in the different directions as its walls, the sky as its roof and formless God as the idol in the temple.
('57', 190, 2, 6, 307121) If we followed any other course, we would be required to provide for a mosque, a fire temple, a church, a synagogue and so on.
('57', 190, 2, 7, 307248) At present the number of Hindus is indeed greater, but we do wish that followers of other faiths also should join us in course of time.
('57', 190, 2, 8, 307384) An attitude of equality towards all religions requires us to keep in view from now the necessity for all such places of worship.
('57', 190, 2, 9, 307513) If we do that, however, we might not be able to keep up our attitude of equality, and therefore, the golden rule for us to follow in this as in other matters is to exercise self control.
('57', 190, 2, 10, 307700) Think over all this carefully and understand it fully, and ask me again and again till you have done so.
('57', 190, 2, 11, 307805) I shall not get tired of answering your questions.
('57', 190, 2, 12, 307856) I have now regained sufficient strength to attend to such duties.
('57', 190, 2, 13, 307922) I have forgotten how Sundarabai and Deshpande came to know each other.
('57', 190, 2, 14, 307993) The religious issue arose because of the previous marriage that was believed to have taken place.
('57', 190, 2, 15, 308091) I only suggested it as an ideal that there should be no marriage between a teacher and his pupil or between one teacher and another working in the same institution.
('57', 190, 2, 16, 308256) There is certainly no religious objection to such marriages.
('57', 190, 2, 17, 308317) If any two persons wish to marry, we may not encourage them but we certainly cannot prevent them.
('57', 190, 2, 18, 308415) I am writing this as a general rule only; I have forgotten what actually happened in this particular case.
('57', 190, 2, 19, 308522) The ideal which I have explained has also not been sufficiently explained to people.
('57', 190, 2, 20, 308607) Nor is any warning given to persons joining the Vidyapith.
('57', 190, 2, 21, 308666) How can we, then, apply the principle in this case?
('57', 190, 2, 22, 308718) In such instances, though sticking to our ideal, we should adopt a liberal attitude.
('57', 190, 3, 23, 308803) Blessings from BAPU From Gujarati: C. W. 236. Courtesy: Lakashmibehn N. Khare

('57', 191, 1, 2, 309018) 348. LETTER TO MANIBEHN PATEL
('57', 191, 2, 3, 309048) October 8, 1932
('57', 191, 3, 4, 309064) MANI, I did get your long letter though it was not long enough for me.
('57', 191, 3, 5, 309135) The fast is now a thing of the past.
('57', 191, 3, 6, 309172) It was inspired by God and so it was crowned with success.
('57', 191, 3, 7, 309231) I am rapidly getting back my normal health.
('57', 191, 3, 8, 309275) I have almost regained my strength.
('57', 191, 3, 9, 309311) Everyday I take two pounds of milk and lots of juice of oranges, pomegranates or grapes, and gourd of tomato soup.
('57', 191, 3, 10, 309426) 1 I can take a fairly good walk, and spin at least 200 rounds of fine yarn, of 45 counts.
('57', 191, 3, 11, 309516) I also write a great many letters.
('57', 191, 3, 12, 309551) So you see there is no cause now for anxiety.
('57', 191, 3, 13, 309597) Ba is permitted to stay with me during the day.
('57', 191, 3, 14, 309645) Davdas also is allowed to come and see me.
('57', 191, 3, 15, 309688) He is all right now.
('57', 191, 3, 16, 309709) Your dreaming about food could be a sign of indigestion, if nothing more.
('57', 191, 3, 17, 309783) Such dreams are common when one is very hungry or suffers from indigestion.
('57', 191, 3, 18, 309859) You should find out the real cause and take the necessary measures, and then stop worrying about the matter.
('57', 191, 3, 19, 309968) If one’s life is regulated by rules of self discipline, such dreams are bound to stop in the course of time.
('57', 191, 3, 20, 310077) We must not expect the veils of ignorance of many lives to vanish all at once; they will take their own time.
('57', 191, 3, 21, 310187) But we need not, for that reason, lose heart or give way to despair or slacken our efforts, and we must entertain no doubt nor worry about the ultimate victory.
('57', 191, 3, 22, 310348) This is the meaning of non attachment taught by the Gita.
('57', 191, 3, 23, 310406) Fasting produces different effects on different persons, and this is not surprising.
('57', 191, 3, 24, 310491) They depend on one’s physical constitution and psychological attitude towards the fast.
('57', 191, 3, 25, 310579) One who is not accustomed to fasting will be upset by the thought of fasting even for one day.
('57', 191, 3, 26, 310674) But fasting is child’s play for one who is in the habit of fasting from time to time.
('57', 191, 3, 27, 310760) Similarly, a person who has not much fat in his system cannot hold out for many days.
('57', 191, 3, 28, 310846) But a fat person, if he is patient, can prolong the fast for a long time and physically benefit by it.
('57', 191, 3, 29, 310949) Father and Mahadev are all right.
('57', 191, 3, 30, 310983) We never enjoyed such solitude before, and it has done us much good.
('57', 191, 3, 31, 311052) I hope you are in good health and so also are Lilavati and Kamaladevi.
('57', 191, 3, 32, 311123) My blessings to the other women there.
('57', 191, 3, 33, 311162) Tell Lilavati that

('57', 193, 3, 4, 313005) MAHALAKSHMI, I hope you got the letter which I wrote to you last week.
('57', 193, 3, 5, 313076) You have done right in giving up cereals and pulses for some time.
('57', 193, 3, 6, 313143) If you restrict your food to milk and curds, raisins, juice of sour lemon with soda bicarb, oranges, mosambis, cucumber, tomatoes, radishes and salad, your weight will certainly go down.
('57', 193, 3, 7, 313330) Do not eat almonds or other nuts.
('57', 193, 3, 8, 313364) If you wish to chew something, you may eat one ounce of coconut.
('57', 193, 3, 9, 313429) You may eat less but not more than one ounce.
('57', 193, 3, 10, 313475) If it does not agree with you, you can stop it.

('57', 193, 6, 12, 313568) 351. LETTER TO MATHURADAS TRIKUMJI
('57', 193, 7, 13, 313603) [October 8, 1932] 1
('57', 193, 8, 14, 313623) I got both your letters.
('57', 193, 8, 15, 313648) There is nobody now among the prominent leaders who has not blessed my fast.
('57', 193, 8, 16, 313725) There is no doubt that a fast is the ultimate weapon in non violence.
('57', 193, 8, 17, 313795) It is being misused and will probably be misused still more.
('57', 193, 8, 18, 313856) But there is a saving grace even in its misuse.
('57', 193, 8, 19, 313904) It can harm only the person who misuses it.
('57', 193, 8, 20, 313948) And, if we consider the matter deeply, even the harm to him is very small.
('57', 193, 8, 21, 314023) If his motive is pure, his soul will not be sullied, and only the body will be harmed.
('57', 193, 8, 22, 314110) However, not many would come forward even to misuse it.
('57', 193, 8, 23, 314166) How many, after all, would be ready to endure the physical suffering involved in a fast?
('57', 193, 8, 24, 314255) I am regaining strength quite rapidly.
('57', 193, 8, 25, 314294) I take two pounds of milk and plenty of juice of oranges, mosambis, grapes and pome granates.
('57', 193, 8, 26, 314388) I also take soup of gourd or tomato.
('57', 193, 8, 27, 314425) The weight, which had gone down to 93 1/2 lb., has now risen to 99 lb.
('57', 193, 8, 28, 314496) I can walk for a total of an hour and a half daily, and can write a large number of letters.
('57', 193, 8, 29, 314589) I have thus practically regained my original strength.
('57', 193, 8, 30, 314644) I spin at least 200 rounds of nearly 45 counts.
('57', 193, 8, 31, 314692) Nor do I feel much tired afterwards.
('57', 193, 8, 32, 314729) There is, therefore, no cause for the slightest anxiety.
('57', 193, 8, 33, 314786) Taramati came and saw me, accompanied by her children.

('57', 200, 6, 16, 324617) 364. A LETTER
('57', 200, 7, 17, 324631) October 9, 1932 No son is entitled to sit in judgment over his father.
('57', 200, 7, 18, 324702) Your work is that of a reformer.
('57', 200, 7, 19, 324735) A soldier in the cause of reform works so as to influence the criminal minded and does not publicize their weaknesses or drag them to courts of law.
('57', 200, 7, 20, 324884) Your duty is to reform your father’s conduct through love, but it would be a sin for you to make his weaknesses public.
('57', 200, 7, 21, 325004) You actually mention several virtues of your father.
('57', 200, 7, 22, 325057) It would of course be better if he were free from greed, but you will be able to overcome that weakness in time through loving persuasion.
('57', 200, 7, 23, 325196) You should tolerate it till then.
('57', 200, 7, 24, 325230) Reason with your brothers and sisters.
('57', 200, 7, 25, 325269) Make your own life purer and more self controlled.
('57', 200, 7, 26, 325320) If even after all these efforts you cannot persuade your father to change his ways, you may leave your home.
('57', 200, 7, 27, 325429) I would see nothing improper in that.
('57', 200, 7, 28, 325467) But even that you should do after giving him sufficient time to improve.
('57', 200, 7, 29, 325540) We ought not to be self righteous and expect, as soon as we have changed, that the world will change too.
('57', 200, 7, 30, 325646) We may have changed in one respect, but probably we do not see the many other weaknesses which remain in us.
('57', 200, 7, 31, 325755) We ought to bear this in mind and adopt a liberal attitude towards the weaknesses of other people.
('57', 200, 7, 32, 325854) I think you now have the answers to all your questions.
('57', 200, 7, 33, 325910) [From Gujarati]
('57', 200, 8, 34, 325926) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.
('57', 201, 0, 1, 325960) 202 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('57', 201, 11, 23, 326985) October 10, 1932
('57', 201, 12, 24, 327002) You do not seem to have studied my very first statement given to the Press.
('57', 201, 12, 25, 327078) You will find from it that although technically I could express my purpose in the manner I did, the fast was in truth addressed to the Hindus and others who had faith in me.
('57', 201, 12, 26, 327252) You will observe too that the vast mass of Hindus instinctively understood the purpose of the fast.
('57', 201, 12, 27, 327352) I hope this is quite clear.
('57', 201, 12, 28, 327380) The reason why
('57', 201, 13, 29, 327395) 1 The addressee, writing from Ceylon, had asked why Gandhiji was not satisfied by the Pact itself and had made the Government’s acceptance of it a condition for breaking his fast.
('57', 202, 0, 1, 327575) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 203
('57', 202, 1, 2, 327625) Government acceptance was necessary was because the Pact would be useless in the teeth of the adverse decision.
('57', 202, 1, 3, 327737) This was the natural corollary to the Pact and the fast.

('57', 202, 3, 5, 327827) 368. LETTER TO JAMNALAL BAJAJ
('57', 202, 4, 6, 327857) October 10, 1932
('57', 202, 5, 7, 327874) CHI JAMNALAL,
('57', 202, 6, 8, 327888) I had got your letter.
('57', 202, 6, 9, 327911) You may have thought it too long, but I did not feel so, especially as it gave me the news that the ‘begger’ had started on his begging mission.
('57', 202, 6, 10, 328056) Tell him that I had got his letter.
('57', 202, 6, 11, 328092) Since he has relieved me of my worry, I intend this letter for him too.
('57', 202, 6, 12, 328164) My body has almost recovered its normal strength.
('57', 202, 6, 13, 328214) My diet includes milk, oranges, mosambis, grapes or pomegranates, and gourd and tomatoes among vegetables.
('57', 202, 6, 14, 328321) Sometimes I drop milk for a day or two.
('57', 202, 6, 15, 328361) I walk twice a day, for a total of an hour and a half.
('57', 202, 6, 16, 328416) I write a great many letters.
('57', 202, 6, 17, 328446) I spin, as I used to do before the fast, not less than 200 rounds daily, of more than 45 counts.
('57', 202, 6, 18, 328543) This should reassure everyone.
('57', 202, 6, 19, 328574) I suffered much physically during the fast but the mind was compeletely at peace.
('57', 202, 6, 20, 328656) If the fast had had to be prolonged, I would not have felt any strain on the mind.
('57', 202, 6, 21, 328739) But it was for God, at whose prompting I had undertaken the fast, to prolong it or make it short.
('57', 202, 6, 22, 328837) Ba is still permitted to stay with me for the whole day.
('57', 202, 6, 23, 328894) But that will probably stop now.
('57', 202, 6, 24, 328927) Devdas can come and see me for some time.
('57', 202, 6, 25, 328969) However he does not come every day.
('57', 202, 6, 26, 329005) Sardar and Mahadev continue to be with me.
('57', 202, 6, 27, 329048) Your health can be considered all right.
('57', 202, 6, 28, 329089) If you have lost some weight, that is to the good.

('57', 202, 6, 34, 329458) These two save us from many diseases.

('57', 202, 6, 36, 329531) You should be happy that you are a ‘C’ class prisoner.

('57', 202, 6, 38, 329649) Even in ‘C’ class one can secure the facilities necessary to preserve one’s health.

('57', 202, 6, 41, 329803) Sardar had acquired great speed in his study of Sanskrit, but owing to the fast it has slowed down a little.

('57', 203, 4, 12, 330503) 369. LETTER TO DADACHANJI
('57', 203, 5, 13, 330529) October 10, 1932
('57', 203, 6, 14, 330546) BHAI DADACHANJI , This is in reply to your letter of the 23rd.
('57', 203, 6, 15, 330609) I wish to clarify my position in regard to Baba 1. I find it very difficult to believe that one person can help another to see God.
('57', 203, 6, 16, 330741) My heart refuses to accept this idea.
('57', 203, 6, 17, 330779) When Baba, however, makes such a claim, I can only tell him that I would welcome his help if he could make me see God.
('57', 203, 6, 18, 330898) We need not believe that a person has necessarily seen God just because he says that he has seen Him.
('57', 203, 6, 19, 331000) Many persons who make such a claim are found to be suffering from a delusion.
('57', 203, 6, 20, 331078) In many cases the claim is merely an echo of one’s own wishes.
('57', 203, 6, 21, 331141) I certainly do not believe that seeing God means seeing some Power outside of us, for I believe that He dwells in the hearts of us all.
('57', 203, 6, 22, 331277) But only one in thousands knows Him through the heart.
('57', 203, 6, 23, 331332) It is not enough to know God with one’s intellect.
('57', 203, 6, 24, 331383) I do feel that no person can help another to see God in this sense.
('57', 203, 6, 25, 331451) One cannot fast at the instance of somebody else in order to be able to see God.
('57', 203, 6, 26, 331532) I would do so only when I feel an urge from within me.
('57', 203, 6, 27, 331587) And when there is such an urge, I will not let myself be dissuaded from the step by anybody.
('57', 203, 6, 28, 331680) There is absolutely no reason for assuming that fasting would help me to see God.
('57', 203, 6, 29, 331762) I cannot believe that, if I agree to fast for forty days, Baba can help me to see God.
('57', 203, 6, 30, 331849) That would be an easy bargain.
('57', 203, 6, 31, 331880) If one can see God as easily as that, the experience has no value for me.
('57', 203, 7, 32, 331954) 1 Meher Baba
('57', 204, 0, 1, 331967) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 205
('57', 204, 1, 2, 332017) I thought that Baba did not divide life into separate fields.
('57', 204, 1, 3, 332079) To a person whose life is dedicated to dharma, politics, economics, etc., are all aspects of dharma, and he cannot leave out any of them.
('57', 204, 1, 4, 332217) According to me, a person who regards dharma as one of the many activities of life does not know what dharma is.
('57', 204, 1, 5, 332330) It is, therefore, inconceivable to me that I might some day give up politics, social reform and other similar activities.
('57', 204, 1, 6, 332452) I have entered the fields of politics, social service, etc., for the sake of dharma.
('57', 204, 1, 7, 332537) I did not promise to translate Baba’s writings into Gujarati.
('57', 204, 1, 8, 332599) On the contrary, I suggested to Baba that he should come out of the spell of English and not write or get somebody to write for him in English, but write and explain his ideas in Gujarati, his mother tongue, or in Persian which as he says, he knows very well.
('57', 204, 1, 9, 332859) Yes, I would certainly translate into Gujarati any of his writings which deeply appeal to me.
('57', 204, 1, 10, 332953) In short, I am a student of Baba’s ideas.
('57', 204, 1, 11, 332995) I saw Baba, having received a wire from Jamshed Mehta whom I regard as a pure soul.
('57', 204, 1, 12, 333079) I am always in search of bhaktas of God and, thinking that Baba was one, I met him.

('57', 211, 1, 2, 341897) 384. A LETTER 1
('57', 211, 2, 3, 341913) October 11, 1932 Eradication of untouchability means that we should treat Antyajas as we treat members of the other communities.
('57', 211, 2, 4, 342042) That is, we should not object to their physical touch or to drinking water served by them, and they may enter our homes or public temples and attend schools like other Hindus.
('57', 211, 2, 5, 342218) This much is necessarily implied in it.
('57', 211, 2, 6, 342258) Whether one should eat food cooked by them or eat in their company or intermarry with them is a matter of one’s own choice.
('57', 211, 2, 7, 342382) Religion does not forbid that, nor does it enjoin it.
('57', 211, 2, 8, 342436) The mixed dinner parties which are often arranged these days are not a necessary part of the movement.
('57', 211, 2, 9, 342539) But I have no doubt that they deserve to be commended.
('57', 211, 2, 10, 342594) [From Gujarati]

('57', 211, 5, 13, 342659) October 11, 1932 I have your letter.
('57', 211, 5, 14, 342696) The Congress workers who left the meeting because drinking water was fetched by untouchables acted most imporperly.
('57', 211, 5, 15, 342812) Drinking of water offered by untouchables is an intergral part of the eradication of untouchability.
('57', 211, 5, 16, 342913) Our dharma is to treat the untouchables the same way we treat other communities.
('57', 211, 5, 17, 342994) Those who have done “expiation” have committed a sin and acted against the Congress.
('57', 211, 5, 18, 343079) Your being boycotted is immoral and you must on no account undergo expiation.
('57', 211, 5, 19, 343157) I am distressed that some of our brothers at Bilaspur by their immoral conduct have created a misunderstanding in the minds of the untouchables.
('57', 211, 5, 20, 343302) I want them to make a public acknowledgement of their mistake.

('57', 218, 6, 14, 353664) In other words, Harijans should have the same status as the rest of the Hindus in all matters.
('57', 218, 6, 15, 353759) Inter dining does not mean eating out of the same plate.
('57', 218, 6, 16, 353816) Hence, there can be no question of anybody’s saliva being mixed with food.

('57', 220, 1, 2, 355653) 405. LETTER TO S. K. GEORGE
('57', 220, 2, 3, 355681) October 14, 1932
('57', 220, 3, 4, 355698) MY DEAR GEORGE, I prize your letter 1 for its gentle frankness.
('57', 220, 3, 5, 355762) Only I cannot give you the full reply it deserves.
('57', 220, 3, 6, 355813) My position as a prisoner would not warrant my giving you a detailed reply.
('57', 220, 3, 7, 355889) One thing I may say.
('57', 220, 3, 8, 355910) I do not isolate politics from religion as you appear to me to do.
('57', 220, 3, 9, 355977) Religion to be true must pervade every activity of life.
('57', 220, 3, 10, 356034) And that activity which cannot be pursued without sacrificing religion is an immoral activity to be shunned at all costs.
('57', 220, 3, 11, 356156) Politics is not only not such an activity but it is an integral part of civic life.
('57', 220, 3, 12, 356240) The rest of the discussion must be postponed to more auspicious occasion.
('57', 220, 3, 13, 356314) Only do not give me up in despair.
('57', 220, 3, 14, 356349) I hope you had my previous letter 2. Yours, BAPU Gandhiji’s Challenge to Christianity, p.
('57', 220, 4, 15, 356439) 406. LETTER TO MAHALAKSHMI M. THAKKAR
('57', 220, 5, 16, 356477) October 14, 1932
('57', 220, 6, 17, 356494) MAHALAKSHMI, The purpose behind bangles, the vermilion mark, and the coloured sari might be adornment or conformity to custom, just as one might eat for pleasure or only to give the body its hire.
('57', 220, 6, 18, 356691) One ought to give up eating for the sake of pleasure, but may give the body anything it needs, even if it be something which one enjoys eating.
('57', 220, 6, 19, 356835) Milk and curds taken with dates give us no little pleasure.
('57', 220, 6, 20, 356895) But you eat them, since you have not adopted that diet for the pleasure of the palate.
('57', 220, 6, 21, 356982) In the same way, you should give up bangles, the vermilion mark and coloured sari despite opposition from society, if they arouse passion in you, but it is not blameworthy to retain them if you do so merely in obedience to custom or to respect the wishes of the elders.
('57', 220, 6, 22, 357252) In other words, there is no absolute duty not to retain them, as there is the absolute duty of not telling a lie.
('57', 220, 6, 23, 357366) It was for such a reason that I
('57', 220, 7, 24, 357398) 1 Of October 5. In it the addressee had expressed his misgivings about building up the “Kingdom of God with people who have not seen the Vision of it”— by which he meant the Congress, which had accepted non violence only as a policy.
('57', 220, 7, 25, 357632) He had also criticized Gandhiji for his fast in connection with untouchability, saying it was religious, not political and therefore was not for independence.
('57', 220, 7, 26, 357791) 2 Vide “Letter to S.k.
('57', 220, 7, 27, 357814) George”, 3 10 1932.
('57', 221, 0, 1, 357834) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 221, 1, 2, 357876) said in my letter that the error was in taking a vow not to wear bangles.
('57', 221, 1, 3, 357950) It is not proper to take a sudden vow for something which is not an absolute duty.
('57', 221, 1, 4, 358033) There is no great self sacrifice in such a step.
('57', 221, 1, 5, 358082) It would have been right for you to take that vow if you had been pining for bangles, travelling all over the world to get bangles of your choice or were in the habit of stealing them.
('57', 221, 1, 6, 358267) I know women who want to have bangles of various styles, fight with their husbands to get them or steal them.
('57', 221, 1, 7, 358377) It would be good for such women to take a vow not to wear bangles, but they would fight with me if I so much as made such a suggestion.
('57', 221, 1, 8, 358513) A woman who thinks that all her beauty lies in her hair would get red with anger at the mere suggestion that she should cut off her hair.
('57', 221, 1, 9, 358651) She might get it cut off, but it is not wrong for a woman, who dislikes long hair and thinks it to be a burden, to keep her hair long to please her parents or to avoid being cut off from society.
('57', 221, 1, 10, 358847) Do you now understand this shastra of bangle wearing?
('57', 221, 1, 11, 358901) Now about the children.
('57', 221, 1, 12, 358925) The problem is similar to that of the bangles.
('57', 221, 1, 13, 358972) Suppose the children do not feel at home in the Ashram without you, and suppose that there is no other place where they may be kept; then it will be your duty to stay for sometime with them in the Ashram.
('57', 221, 1, 14, 359177) This cannot be described as “living”in the Ashram.
('57', 221, 1, 15, 359228) Just as it is not wrong for a person who is very ill to take rest from work for a time, similarly it is not wrong to spend a fortnight or a month in the Ashram for the sake of the children, that might even be one’s dharma.
('57', 221, 1, 16, 359451) Such matters require careful thinking.
('57', 221, 1, 17, 359490) That is why the Gita says that it is not easy to distinguish between what is right action, what is wrong action and what is inaction.
('57', 221, 1, 18, 359624) If, therefore, you are convinced that it is difficult to keep the children at Calcutta and that it is your duty to put them in the Ashram, you should spend, on my responsibility and above all for their sake, one month with them in the Ashram after their arrival and accustom them to the life there.
('57', 221, 1, 19, 359923) Even during that period, if some urgent work requires you to leave you may certainly go, and Narandas will look after the children as best he can.
('57', 221, 1, 20, 360070) Wouldn't he have to look after them if you were to die and there was nobody at Calcutta?
('57', 221, 1, 21, 360159) However, let the children remain where they are if this arrangement does not suit you or the children refuse to go or the elders are likely to feel very much hurt.
('57', 221, 1, 22, 360323) Blessings from BAPU [PS.] Do ask me if you still have any doubts.
('57', 221, 1, 23, 360389) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 6823
('57', 222, 0, 1, 360433) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 223
('57', 222, 1, 2, 360483) 407. LETTER TO WOMEN PRISONERS
('57', 222, 2, 3, 360514) October 14, 1932 Tell Durgabai Joag that the women can get rid of the fear which they feel in going about their work through firmness of mind.
('57', 222, 2, 4, 360657) They should go freely wherever necessary for work or service with a firm conviction that God is there to protect them.
('57', 222, 2, 5, 360776) Whom do they fear?
('57', 222, 2, 6, 360795) Why should they fear any men?
('57', 222, 2, 7, 360825) Why think that all men are only waiting for an opportunity to harass women?
('57', 222, 2, 8, 360901) After all, men are born of women and the latter ought to have the faith that no man would ordinarily attack a woman who is like a mother to him.
('57', 222, 2, 9, 361046) Every woman should regard herself as a mother and fear a man only if she would fear her own son.
('57', 222, 2, 10, 361143) If, nevertheless, a woman meets a man who is blinded by lust, she should remain firm in her conviction that the armour of her purity will protect her.
('57', 222, 2, 11, 361294) [From Gujarati]

('57', 222, 4, 13, 361344) 408. A LETTER
('57', 222, 5, 14, 361358) October 14, 1932 Temple entry is the crux of the movement for eradication of untouchability.

('57', 226, 0, 1, 366282) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 227
('57', 226, 1, 2, 366332) 4.15 a.m., October 16, 1932 Panditji had asked me where the inmates of the Ashram may work to make their contribution towards removal of untouchability, and what work they should do.
('57', 226, 1, 3, 366515) I had replied to him.
('57', 226, 1, 4, 366537) Still, I will say something more here.
('57', 226, 1, 5, 366576) One of the aims of the Ashram is that the persons trained in it should afterwards spread out in villages and start doing work in them.
('57', 226, 1, 6, 366711) The work will of course be connected with khadi, removal of untouchability, etc.
('57', 226, 1, 7, 366792) But they should also take advantage of the prevailing atmosphere at any time and pay more attention to that particular activity.
('57', 226, 1, 8, 366921) If, therefore, we can do any work in the surro unding villages for removal of untouchability, we should certainly do it.
('57', 226, 1, 9, 367042) We should, if possible, work even in cities.
('57', 226, 1, 10, 367087) There is a temple on one side of the Ashram.
('57', 226, 1, 11, 367132) There is one opposite to the Ashram, too.
('57', 226, 1, 12, 367174) See if you can get them thrown open to Antyajas.
('57', 226, 1, 13, 367223) We may acquaint ourselves with their conditions.
('57', 226, 1, 14, 367272) If we can accommodate them, we should invite more Antyajas families to come and live in the Ashram.
('57', 226, 1, 15, 367372) Vinoba’s scheme is certainly excellent.
('57', 226, 1, 16, 367412) If we can implement it, we should try to do so.
('57', 226, 1, 17, 367460) These are only a few isolated suggestions for guidance.
('57', 226, 1, 18, 367516) What is essential is that each one of us should take up whatever work he can think of and do his best.
('57', 226, 1, 19, 367619) We should become one with the work as sugar becomes one with milk, and still remains detached.
('57', 226, 1, 20, 367714) We should never think that some work was done by the Ashram or by an inmate of the Ashram.
('57', 226, 1, 21, 367805) We should feel that we do everything as instruments in God’s hands and act in that spirit.
('57', 226, 1, 22, 367896) These suggestions do not—ought not to—interfere with other vows which we may have taken.
('57', 226, 1, 23, 367985) They should remain undisturbed.
('57', 226, 1, 24, 368017) Everybody should go on working in accordance with his vow and, in addition, participate in the present movement against untouchability as much as he can.
('57', 226, 1, 25, 368171) If such work is not compatible with one’s vow, the path is clear.
('57', 226, 1, 26, 368237) However noble another’s dharma may be, one’s good lies in one’s own dharma.
('57', 226, 1, 27, 368313) Whether we live or die doing that dharma is the same for us, that is, we shall advance spiritually in either case.
('57', 226, 1, 28, 368428) Who had placed Punjabhai in such a chair that he fell down?
('57', 226, 1, 29, 368488) Anybody who gets fainting fits should have a seat which would not overturn.
('57', 226, 1, 30, 368564) But this is wisdom after the event.
('57', 226, 1, 31, 368600) However, don’t we all advance by learning from one’s own or other people’s mistakes to avoid similar mistakes in future?
('57', 226, 1, 32, 368721) We need not be perturbed by the death of Trivedi’s brother’s wife, Taragouri.
('57', 226, 1, 33, 368799) Her death was ordained.
('57', 226, 1, 34, 368823) In her case the stove has been only instrumental.
('57', 226, 1, 35, 368873) And, moreover, she could not get immediate help.
('57', 226, 1, 36, 368922) Taragouri also got frightened and could not loosen
('57', 227, 0, 1, 368973) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 227, 1, 2, 369015) the knot of her skirt.
('57', 227, 1, 3, 369038) Her attempt to loosen it resulted in a further knot.
('57', 227, 1, 4, 369091) All these were preordained.
('57', 227, 1, 5, 369119) We ever live besieged by Death.
('57', 227, 1, 6, 369151) Nobody knows from which side and when he will attack.
('57', 227, 1, 7, 369205) We should draw only one lesson from such a death.
('57', 227, 1, 8, 369255) What we can do today, we should not leave for tomorrow, and what we can do this minute we should not leave to the next.
('57', 227, 1, 9, 369375) Apart from that, we should overcome our love of the primus stove, and everybody should also learn what to do when his or her clothes accidentally catch fire.
('57', 227, 1, 10, 369533) The leather for repairing sandal soles received this time seems to be excellent.

('57', 227, 1, 23, 370261) And Kusum does not improve at all.

('57', 227, 1, 30, 371012) Otherwise you should forget it.

('57', 227, 1, 35, 371297) I would advise them to resolve to stay in the Ashram, to live in the open air all the twenty four hours of the day and do what work they can without

('57', 229, 5, 26, 374764) October 15, 1932 Eradication of untouchability does not imply inter dining and intermarriage with Antyajas.
('57', 229, 5, 27, 374872) But I don’t believe that those who inter dine with the so called untouchables, Harijans, violate dharma.
('57', 229, 5, 28, 374977) Restrictions on inter dining and intermarriage among communities are not an inseparable part of Hinduism.
('57', 229, 5, 29, 375083) They are only a matter of custom.
('57', 229, 5, 30, 375117) We cannot treat Harijans differently from other communities.
('57', 229, 5, 31, 375178) Since there will be no coercion in this matter, there is no reason for anybody to feel hurt.

('57', 231, 4, 10, 377370) 420. LETTER TO JAMANABEHN GANDHI
('57', 231, 5, 11, 377403) October 16, 1932 I do not consider that your total expenditure of Rs. 125 for three months is excessive.
('57', 231, 5, 12, 377508) I wished to know the details because they tell me a number of things.
('57', 231, 5, 13, 377578) Everyone must keep an account of every pie spent, even though the money might be one’s own.
('57', 231, 5, 14, 377670) For the truth is that nothing in this world is our own but all belongs to God, as we realize from experience every day.
('57', 231, 5, 15, 377790) Hence, we should not be attached to whatever we enjoy or spend.
('57', 231, 5, 16, 377854) A person who does so will gladly keep an account of every pie for his own satisfaction.

('57', 239, 9, 19, 392267) 433. LETTER TO VALJI G. DESAI
('57', 239, 10, 20, 392297) October 19, 1932
('57', 239, 11, 21, 392314) BHAISHRI VALJI, I got your letter and the book.
('57', 239, 11, 22, 392362) Expecting that this letter will reach you, I am not sending it by registered post to save the cost.
('57', 239, 11, 23, 392462) Do write to me, however, when you get it.
('57', 239, 11, 24, 392504) I may say that almost as soon as I got the book I went through it.
('57', 239, 11, 25, 392571) I find your language sweet, so I did not pay attention to it.
('57', 239, 11, 26, 392633) If I did I might, in my wisdom, want to suggest a few corrections, but they seem to be immaterial.
('57', 239, 11, 27, 392732) I was not favourably impressed by the book.
('57', 239, 11, 28, 392776) You call it Ishucharita 1, but I do not see anything in it to justify the title.
('57', 239, 11, 29, 392857) If I remember correctly, you once told me or I told somebody that I believed you thought yourself too humble to produce anything
('57', 239, 12, 30, 392986) 1 “Life of Jesus”
('57', 240, 0, 1, 393004) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 241
('57', 240, 1, 2, 393054) original and that you were satisfied with translating the best that the ancestors had left to us.
('57', 240, 1, 3, 393152) If I accept this argument, I would perhaps approve your book.
('57', 240, 1, 4, 393214) But I do not accept the argument.
('57', 240, 1, 5, 393248) If it is accepted in your case, it should be accepted for others too.
('57', 240, 1, 6, 393318) And if all acted accordingly, the only result would be that we would drown ourselves in the waters of our ancestors’ well.
('57', 240, 1, 7, 393441) I believe that it is our duty to augment the legacy of the ancestors and to change it into current coin and make it acceptable to the present age.
('57', 240, 1, 8, 393588) Mere translation cannot achieve this.
('57', 240, 1, 9, 393626) What you have given in your book is already available in Gujarati.
('57', 240, 1, 10, 393693) The translations brought out after immense industry by Christians themselves are not bad.
('57', 240, 1, 11, 393783) Why should we put them in people’s hands?
('57', 240, 1, 12, 393825) I am sure you do not write such books so that people may read your sweet language.
('57', 240, 1, 13, 393908) Even if you do, your purpose will not be served.
('57', 240, 1, 14, 393957) In my view this book is an example of a kind of lethargy.
('57', 240, 1, 15, 394015) I am sure that you would not call a man industrious merely because he reads much and writes much.
('57', 240, 1, 16, 394113) As for you, I believe that you have a mania for reading and translating.
('57', 240, 1, 17, 394186) You ought to get rid of it.
('57', 240, 1, 18, 394214) What I should like you to do is this.
('57', 240, 1, 19, 394252) Give us by all means a book on the life of Jesus.
('57', 240, 1, 20, 394302) Read the New Testamant as often as you please, but then put the book on a shelf and create a living picture of Jesus from what you have read.
('57', 240, 1, 21, 394444) Do not think that because the book has been printed, you must give it to the people.
('57', 240, 1, 22, 394529) If you find substance in my view, cancel the printed matter and don’t mind if so much money is wasted.
('57', 240, 1, 23, 394632) Try to write something original as I have suggested.
('57', 240, 1, 24, 394685) If you feel that it would be too much trouble to do so, keep quiet; give up reading and engage yourself in physical activity to improve your health.
('57', 240, 1, 25, 394834) I have seen many persons both in India and elsewhere who suffer from the mania of reading.
('57', 240, 1, 26, 394925) You also have that disease.
('57', 240, 1, 27, 394953) To get rid of it take walks, contemplete the beauty of God’s creation, read the book of nature, learn the language of trees, listen to the music of spheres in the sky, watch the drama enacted in it every night; and during the day spin, when you feel tired, do sewing or, if you can, carpentry or shoe making.
('57', 240, 1, 28, 395262) I know that your hand gets benumbed if you strain it, but with practice that will disappear.
('57', 240, 1, 29, 395355) There are in English many beautifully written books on the life of Jesus.
('57', 240, 1, 30, 395429) We can get some material even from them, but I would not put that burden on you.
('57', 241, 0, 1, 395510) 242 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 241, 1, 2, 395552) The portion relating to Angels, etc., in your book should be left out.
('57', 241, 1, 3, 395623) Why add to the superabundance of things that we already have.
('57', 241, 1, 4, 395685) Even if in fact the Angels and the wise men had not come, Jesus’s fame would not suffer.
('57', 241, 1, 5, 395774) My complaint is that you have failed to raise before the reader a vivid image of Jesus.
('57', 241, 1, 6, 395862) You have merely given the teaching of Jesus and that, too, through quotations.
('57', 241, 1, 7, 395941) Will anyone disbelieve you if you give it in your own words?
('57', 241, 1, 8, 396002) I do not know what type of readers you had in view in writing this book.
('57', 241, 1, 9, 396075) If you have the general mass in view, you should not have inflicted foreign names on them.
('57', 241, 1, 10, 396166) A man like me whose reading is very limited cannot make out whether you have decked the Biblical names in clothes of your make or in borrowed clothes.
('57', 241, 1, 11, 396317) I am afraid there is not much to be gained from things of this kind.
('57', 241, 1, 12, 396386) If your intention was to give names that might sound well in Gujarati, you should have coined fitting Gujarati names suggesting the same meanings as the corresponding Biblical names, as the latter are always significant.
('57', 241, 1, 13, 396607) If, regardless of my criticism, you decide that the book should be published, it is not necessary to offer the book free, charging only postage.
('57', 241, 1, 14, 396752) Do not mind if people do not buy it even at cost price.
('57', 241, 1, 15, 396808) The book is bound to sell as it will bear your name.
('57', 241, 1, 16, 396861) (But don’t take that as test of the quality of the book.) Your work ended with the writing, it will be up to some philanthropic institution which distributes such books free among people to give copies of this one, if it so wishes, to those who cannot afford to buy it even at cost price.
('57', 241, 1, 17, 397150) It is best that one person should not attempt to ride two horses at a time.
('57', 241, 1, 18, 397226) Let that sum of Rs. 150 grow with compound interest.
('57', 241, 1, 19, 397279) I have written much more than I had intended.
('57', 241, 1, 20, 397325) Moreover, I have let myself go in my criticism, which means that I have yielded to ignorant nature and so I have decided to spend money on registering this.
('57', 241, 1, 21, 397482) Do you like the takli because you can spin on it while walking?
('57', 241, 1, 22, 397546) One can spin on it while resting.
('57', 241, 1, 23, 397580) Excessive greed for anything is the root of all evil.
('57', 241, 1, 24, 397634) Your present task is to make your body as strong as steel.

('57', 242, 2, 3, 397868) October 19, 1932
('57', 242, 3, 4, 397885) BHAISHRI KHAMBHATTA, I have read your letter to Mahadev.
('57', 242, 3, 5, 397942) I do not know at all what blue brain is.
('57', 242, 3, 6, 397983) When Dr. Gilder left after examining me the blood pressure was normal.
('57', 242, 3, 7, 398054) My health is quite all right, and I have nearly regained my former strength.
('57', 242, 3, 8, 398131) I have my daily walks, spin as much as I used to and can also write a large number of letters.
('57', 242, 3, 9, 398226) I spend all the twenty four hours in the open.

('57', 242, 4, 28, 399424) I hope that you yourself are all right.

('57', 243, 10, 22, 400739) October 19, 1932 We should not insist on taking a Harijan to a hospital or temple at a place where public opinion is against such action.

('57', 245, 2, 3, 403019) October 19, 1932 If abolition of castes means the abolition of the varna I do not approve of it.
('57', 245, 2, 4, 403116) But I am with you if your aim is to end the innumerable caste distinctions.
('57', 245, 2, 5, 403192) All the same eradication of untouchability and abolition of castes are separate problems.
('57', 245, 2, 6, 403282) Eradication of untouch ability requires that we deal with the untouchables in the way we do with other Hindus.
('57', 245, 2, 7, 403393) Mixing up the two problems would jeopardize the success of both.
('57', 245, 2, 8, 403458) For this reason intermarriage and inter dining with untouchables are not an integral feature of the removal of untouch abliity, but their practice is not against religion either.

('57', 253, 12, 23, 416522) In one sense we are all idol worshippers.
('57', 253, 12, 24, 416564) We worship God of our image.
('57', 253, 12, 25, 416593) That image need not have a physical form.
('57', 253, 12, 26, 416635) Each one has his own imagination of and attributes for God.
('57', 253, 12, 27, 416695) And yet God in reality is without attributes and beyond our imagination.
('57', 253, 12, 28, 416768) Hence when we form our own picture of God, we are idol worshippers.
('57', 253, 12, 29, 416836) Therefore my mind does not condemn those who conceive God as residing in a stone or metal image.
('57', 253, 12, 30, 416933) They are not wrong for God is everywhere and in everything.
('57', 253, 12, 31, 416993) Now whenever we want to worship God in everything we consecrate it.
('57', 253, 12, 32, 417061) But if a man excludes his fellows from participation in common worship we are entitled to say that God flees from such worship.
('57', 253, 12, 33, 417189) And He is installed when there is repentance and the bar against one’s fellows is removed.
('57', 253, 12, 34, 417280) I hope this explanation is

('57', 264, 1, 2, 435728) 474. LONG LIVE PUNJABHAI!
('57', 264, 2, 3, 435754) [October 23, 1932] 1
('57', 264, 3, 4, 435775) Once when speaking of Punjabhai I had used before his name the prefix chiranjivi 2 a child had asked me in suprise: “Since Punja bhai is older than you, how can you refer to him as chiranjivi?” I had answered somewhat as follows: “In age Punjabhai is certainly older than I, but he trusts me like a child.
('57', 264, 3, 5, 436081) And he offers me even his devotion in the same way.” This was literally true.
('57', 264, 3, 6, 436159) I had my doubts about my fitness for that trust and that devotion.
('57', 264, 3, 7, 436226) But I had not even an iota of doubt about Punjabhai’s trust and devotion to me.
('57', 264, 3, 8, 436306) In any kind of difficulty Punjabhai would accept my advice as gospel truth.
('57', 264, 3, 9, 436382) Punja bhai was not himself without a sense of discrimination but he had deliberately decided to put his trust in me.
('57', 264, 3, 10, 436499) Punjabhai may well not be here today in the sense in which I had addressed him when I called him chiranjivi, but he is chiranjivi in a wider sense than that.
('57', 264, 3, 11, 436657) Though I used to address him as chiranjivi, there was nothing I could teach him.
('57', 264, 3, 12, 436738) I for one was a worshipper of his virtues.
('57', 264, 3, 13, 436781) In my view, no one could surpass Punjabhai in humility, in devotion to religion, in devotion to truth and in generosity.
('57', 264, 3, 14, 436902) Punjabhai had the capacity to sacrifice everything.
('57', 264, 3, 15, 436954) The poet Raichand was all in all to Punjabhai.
('57', 264, 3, 16, 437001) I myself was an admirer of Raichandbhai, so Punjabhai was drawn towards me.
('57', 264, 3, 17, 437077) That I, unlike Punjabhai, could not look upon Raichandbhai as my guru did not pain him.
('57', 264, 3, 18, 437165) Punjabhai knew that no one could become a guru merely by being offered that status.
('57', 264, 3, 19, 437249) A guru attracts a disciple just as a magnet attracts iron.
('57', 264, 3, 20, 437308) Punjabhai greatly liked what I used to say about Raichandbhai and what he liked more was the fact that I tried to assimilate what I extolled.
('57', 264, 3, 21, 437450) As a consequence that bond between us became stronger and stronger every day.
('57', 264, 3, 22, 437528) Punjabhai was closely associated with the Ashram right from itsinception and though he did not become an inmate of the Ashram, He lived as one.
('57', 264, 3, 23, 437672) Punjabhai had shared in the ups and downs of the Ashram.
('57', 264, 3, 24, 437729) He would explain to us the intricacies of the Ahmedabad
('57', 264, 4, 25, 437785) 1 From “Diary, 1932” ; Punjabhai Shah died on October 22. 2 Literally long lived, a term usually applied by people to those younger than themselves

('57', 272, 1, 3, 450926) I never knew that a prisoner could be condemned unheard.

('57', 274, 1, 2, 455432) 485. LETTER TO VINOBA BHAVE
('57', 274, 2, 3, 455460) October 24, 1932 The comparison with Banabhatta and Valmiki is not right.
('57', 274, 2, 4, 455534) 1 One may compare the two types of yarn with “Balakanda” and “Kishkindhakanda,” or better still, with “Kishkindhakanda” and “Uttarkanda”.
('57', 274, 2, 5, 455672) Fine yarn of 200 counts or more is “Uttarkanda” in the absence of which “Kishkindhakanda” would lose all value.
('57', 274, 2, 6, 455784) Our forefathers forced the poor to produce Dacca Shabnam 2 to gratify the delicate tastes of people who loved luxury.
('57', 274, 2, 7, 455902) Let us atone for their sin by spinning as yajna yarn of the finest count and offer it to the Lord.
('57', 274, 2, 8, 456001) The art in both cases is the same, but in olden times it ministered to selfishness.
('57', 274, 2, 9, 456085) Let our art help in spreading the spirit of service, it is necessary to revive the old skill in order to popularize khadi among all classes of people.
('57', 274, 2, 10, 456236) We should prove that what was possible then in the days of slavery can be done in the age of freedom too.
('57', 274, 2, 11, 456342) Will not the devotee do for God what a libertine would do for a prostitute?
('57', 274, 2, 12, 456418) This involves neither great trouble nor any expense; for, all that we wish to do is to learn slowly to spin fine yarn in a spirit of self sacrifice.
('57', 274, 2, 13, 456567) I have also found from experience that, if we try to spin finer and finer yarn, we shall more likely discover ways of producing better and cheaper khadi.
('57', 274, 2, 14, 456721) Here we have the practical application of the Gita verse beginning with “Yavanartha udapane” .
('57', 274, 2, 15, 456816) If this reasoning appeals to you, I need not explain to you why I put down 20 counts as the minimum for a voluntary spinner to achieve.

('57', 276, 3, 8, 460844) 486. LETTER TO BEHRAMJI KHAMBHATTA October 24, 1932
('57', 276, 4, 9, 460896) BHAISHRI KHAMBHATTA, I got your letter.

('57', 276, 4, 11, 461065) None of us was scared by your letter in which you spoke of “blue brain”.
('57', 276, 4, 12, 461138) I had not the least idea what “blue brain” was and as I had been lying under a tree when your letter came, I said: “Who knows what ‘blue brain’ is!
('57', 276, 4, 13, 461286) But living under a tree might cause ‘green brain’, and it would certainly be good to have it.” Thus we had some fun about it, as I showed no symptom at all of what you feared.
('57', 276, 4, 14, 461462) And we have more cause for fun now that we can understand how you came to have the fear.
('57', 276, 4, 15, 461551) There is absolutely no reason why I should not let myself be examined by Bhai Mehta.

('57', 276, 4, 18, 461801) But the truth is that I would have to obtain special permission to get myself examined by him, and I am really afraid I would not get such permission if I asked for it.
('57', 276, 4, 19, 461970) I do not ask the permission to spare myself the shock of the refusal.
('57', 276, 4, 20, 462040) However, I would certainly think about whatever suggestions he sends in writting on the basis of any likely causes that occur to him.
('57', 276, 4, 21, 462174) Like him, I also believe that disease is lurking somewhere in me, despite all the self control I exercise, and that the disease expresses itself through the pain in the elbow or otherwise.
('57', 276, 4, 22, 462363) The bowels certainly are weak.

('57', 280, 1, 2, 467977) 493. LETTER TO KRISHANDAS
('57', 280, 2, 3, 468003) October 26, 1932 Humanly speaking, it must be evil fate that took you to Sinhergaon.
('57', 280, 2, 4, 468088) You went there for recuperation and came in for an attack of influenza.
('57', 280, 2, 5, 468160) But who knows whether it is for your well being 1
('57', 280, 3, 6, 468210) that you have had this attack leaving you completely prostrate.
('57', 280, 3, 7, 468274) And since we are so hopelessly ignorant as to the truth of things, I suppose the Gita teaches us to be equi minded, no matter what fate overtakes us.
('57', 280, 3, 8, 468424) So on the one hand we have to learn to be equi minded, and on the other we have to apply natural remedies within our means in order to get well when we are ill.
('57', 280, 3, 9, 468585) I shall try therefore not to be anxious about your health but pray that whatever is good for you may happen to you.

('57', 283, 6, 11, 475040) 497. LETTER TO MATHURADAS PURUSHOTTAM
('57', 283, 7, 12, 475078) October 26, 1932
('57', 283, 8, 13, 475095) MATHURADAS, This time I was waiting for a letter from you every day and wondering why there was none, when I got it.
('57', 283, 8, 14, 475212) You have caught the point regarding the testing of yarn.
('57', 283, 8, 15, 475269) An understanding of such practical aspects saves us much time.
('57', 283, 8, 16, 475332) Some of the methods followed by the mills are devised with a purely commercial aim and some others to help in mass production.
('57', 283, 8, 17, 475459) These methods are of no use to us in our rural industry, though some of them do deserve to be adopted by us too.
('57', 283, 8, 18, 475572) We have to use our discrimination and judge which ones we should adopt.
('57', 283, 8, 19, 475644) I suggest that Mahadev’s fine yarn may be passed through doubling before weaving, if you feel that it is unfit for weaving only becuase of its lack of strength.
('57', 283, 8, 20, 475805) If you think, however that we do not have the type of rach and heddles required to weave such fine yarn, we should manufacture them.
('57', 283, 8, 21, 475938) Perhaps Ramji’s experience may not help us much in this matter as he may not have the intelligence necessary for dealing with yarn of such fine count.
('57', 283, 8, 22, 476089) To get this yarn woven, you should approach other skilled workers in
('57', 283, 9, 23, 476158) 1 Son of Vallabhbhai Patel
('57', 284, 0, 1, 476185) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 285
('57', 284, 1, 2, 476235) Ahmedabad who weave very fine cloth.
('57', 284, 1, 3, 476272) Again, it is likely that the method for testing the strength of very fine yarn is a different one, and the tools for that purpose and also the knocker required for weaving fine yarn must be especially delicate so that there is the least possible strain on the yarn.
('57', 284, 1, 4, 476538) The method of starching fine yarn must also be different.
('57', 284, 1, 5, 476596) It is likely, however, that the skilled weavers in Ahmedabad weave only fine silk yarn and do not know enough about very fine cotton yarn.
('57', 284, 1, 6, 476735) If that is so, we should procure the necessary tools from Andhradesha or Bengal where they weave very fine yarn, or we may send to them a specimen of our yarn and inquire about the method of weaving it.
('57', 284, 1, 7, 476938) Have you seen the Andhra weavers at work?
('57', 284, 1, 8, 476980) Did you observe the starching and other processes which they demonstrated at our exhibitions?
('57', 284, 1, 9, 477074) But I think that after reading what I have written you yourself will be able to find a better solution.
('57', 284, 1, 10, 477178) We must acquire the skill to weave our finest yarn ourselves in the Ashram.
('57', 284, 1, 11, 477254) You will perhaps be able to see from all this that only voluntary spinners can fully master all aspects of the art of spinning and that, when we have mastered it, it will be quite easy for us to produce ordinary khadi of the best possible quality.
('57', 284, 1, 12, 477502) You will also see, if you cast a glance at other crafts and skills, that when the people themselves had not learnt the required skill the craft remained poor, and that it was only amateurs who became experts in it.
('57', 284, 1, 13, 477717) It is because our people neglected hand spinning that the country lost a cottage industry which gave work to millions in their homes.
('57', 284, 1, 14, 477851) Now the craft can be revived as an occupation only if we do hard tapascharya and cultivate the art once again in a spirit of yajna.
('57', 284, 1, 15, 477983) Looking at the matter from this point of view, I was very happy that you had finally decided to cling to your work and overcome your restlessness.
('57', 284, 1, 16, 478130) Keshu’s carding bow will of course be useful.
('57', 284, 1, 17, 478176) As it cannot be installed in a village home, the old carding bow will remain as the old spinning wheel has remained.
('57', 284, 1, 18, 478293) The best thing to do is to make improvements in it, and I believe that such improvements are possible.
('57', 284, 1, 19, 478396) Mirabehn has been working fairly hard with that aim.
('57', 284, 1, 20, 478449) She has been carding in jail too, and has made some improvements.
('57', 284, 1, 21, 478515) You are quite right in applying yourself to that task.
('57', 284, 1, 22, 478570) Your test report on the yarn spun by both of us will help us very much.
('57', 284, 1, 23, 478642) I saw the justice of most of your criticism.
('57', 284, 1, 24, 478687) I myself have observed the defects which you have pointed out, but I ignore them sometimes when I am tired.
('57', 284, 1, 25, 478795) I often observe that the yarn is rough because of an occasional bad sliver or because of uneven tension
('57', 285, 0, 1, 478899) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 285, 1, 2, 478941) when spinning.
('57', 285, 1, 3, 478956) Instead of cutting off and taking out that part, I let it pass.
('57', 285, 1, 4, 479020) I do know that this will mean a lot of trouble for the weaver, and that, therefore, by letting that yarn remain I also commit violence.
('57', 285, 1, 5, 479156) However, while I am actually spinning, partly through lack of vigilance at the time, partly through greed, partly through lethargy and partly through fatigue I may ignore defects in the yarn.
('57', 285, 1, 6, 479348) But now that I have received your criticism, I know that the quality of my yarn will automatically improve.
('57', 285, 1, 7, 479456) If, therefore, I receive further criticism when the yarn is woven, it will certainly help both Mahadev and me, for both of us wish to spin yarn of the finest count and of the finest quality that we can.
('57', 285, 1, 8, 479659) As we cannot get here other yarn for comparison, some defects will of course remain; but we will keep up our efforts to reach as high a standard as possible.
('57', 285, 1, 9, 479817) I hope you are keeping good health.
('57', 285, 1, 10, 479853) I don’t write anything about Meghaji.

('57', 287, 1, 2, 482330) 501. LETTER TO HARISINGH GAUR
('57', 287, 2, 3, 482360) October 27, 1932 I confess that I do not feel the same afflatus as you do, for I do not share the view that you hold about the Brahminical influence.
('57', 287, 2, 4, 482510) 1 Whilst the Brahmins have undoubtedly a great deal to answer for, I am sure that they have been much more sinned against than sinning.
('57', 287, 2, 5, 482646) Every religion has produced its own Brahmins.
('57', 287, 2, 6, 482692) That they have not been known as such makes no difference.
('57', 287, 2, 7, 482751) Our Brahmins would, I think compare favourably with the others.
('57', 287, 2, 8, 482815) At the same time I am not in love with the caste system with all its ignorant restrictions.
('57', 287, 2, 9, 482907) I do believe in varnashrama, without the restrictions superimposed upon it about inter dining and intermarriage and the idea of superiority and inferiority.
('57', 287, 2, 10, 483064) I believe with Vivekananda that Shankara never drove Budhism from India for he was himself a prachchhanna 2 Buddha.
('57', 287, 2, 11, 483180) He merely rid it of the bad things that were creeping into it, and prevented its alienation from Hinduism.
('57', 287, 2, 12, 483287) In my opinion nowhere has the influence of the teaching of Buddha been more abiding than in India.
('57', 287, 2, 13, 483386) Nevertheless I would go with you the whole distance in saying that we need again a very thorough cleansing.
('57', 287, 3, 14, 483494) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, p.

('57', 288, 1, 2, 484341) 503. LETTER TO VASUMATI PANDIT
('57', 288, 2, 3, 484372) October 27, 1932
('57', 288, 3, 4, 484389) VASUMATI,
('57', 288, 4, 5, 484399) I got your letter.
('57', 288, 4, 6, 484418) It is a mark of intellectual laziness to believe that whoever can give an account of every moment of his life can become a mahatma.
('57', 288, 4, 7, 484550) There are in the West many hard woking men and women who can give an account of every moment of their lives, but they are not fortunate enough to have become mahatmas.
('57', 288, 4, 8, 484718) Under the pretext that only a mahatma can do it, you cannot escape your duty to give an account of every moment.
('57', 288, 4, 9, 484831) Every one of us should from the habit of keeping such an account.
('57', 288, 4, 10, 484897) And no great credit should be given for it either.
('57', 288, 4, 11, 484948) The phrase, ‘one’s duty however defective ‘should not be interpreted to mean a duty which violates morality.
('57', 288, 4, 12, 485057) ‘Defective’ here means what seems to be inferior.
('57', 288, 4, 13, 485107) According to the Gita all duties have equal value, for Mother Gita attaches importance only to people’s hearts and, therefore, her standards are bound to be faultless.
('57', 288, 4, 14, 485275) For example, if a grain dealer who feels that his occupation is inferior to a clerk’s, gives up his trade and tries to become a clerk, wouldn’t he be a loser both ways?
('57', 288, 4, 15, 485444) In the same way, if Titus, who looks after the dairy, leaves the cows in order to serve Antyajas because Antyaja service has become fashionable just now, he will be said to have given up his duty and acted contrary to the teaching of the Gita.
('57', 288, 4, 16, 485688) Similarly, if you women who have bound yourselves by vows to do certain work, leave it and take up some other work of service, you will be guilty of forsaking your duty.
('57', 288, 4, 17, 485858) Is this quite clear?
('57', 288, 4, 18, 485879) I see nothing wrong in a person going out of the Ashram to improve his health and returning to it after it has improved.
('57', 288, 4, 19, 486000) Don’t I myself ask many to do so?
('57', 288, 4, 20, 486034) But anybody who vows not to return to the Ashram and keeps the vow, as Gangadevi did, deserves all honour.
('57', 288, 4, 21, 486141) Only a rare person can do that, and only if he has accepted the idea with his whole heart.
('57', 288, 4, 22, 486232) Such a person, even if he or she has to be looked after by others, does great service by setting an example of immense patience and non attachment to life.
('57', 288, 4, 23, 486388) Moreover, our aspiration is to live as simply as poor people do.
('57', 288, 4, 24, 486453) The latter, even when they suffer extreme pain through some disease, cannot leave either their home or their village.
('57', 288, 4, 25, 486571) They remain satisfied with whatever their friends and
('57', 289, 0, 1, 486625) 290 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 289, 1, 2, 486667) relations can do for them and some do not get even that much service.
('57', 289, 1, 3, 486737) We should bow in reverence to a person who, being a man of knowledge, voluntarily suffers with similar patience.
('57', 289, 1, 4, 486850) He serves the people even by setting an example of such patience.
('57', 289, 1, 5, 486916) That is why I had suggested to Punjabhai that it would be good both for him and for the Ashram if he died in it, nursed by the inmates.
('57', 289, 1, 6, 487052) And for the same reason, I told Kishorelal that he should not mind having to be looked after by other people in the Ashram, for a man like him served the Ashram by his mere presence.
('57', 289, 1, 7, 487235) I have only stated a principle 1 in my letter to Narandas.
('57', 289, 1, 8, 487294) You need not think much about it.
('57', 289, 1, 9, 487328) If anybody is inspired by that highest sense of dharma, let him take such a step.
('57', 289, 1, 10, 487410) You should do only what you can.
('57', 289, 3, 11, 487443) From a photostat of the Gujarati: S.N. 9335. Also C.W. 581. Courtesy: Vasumati Pandit

('57', 292, 5, 10, 491911) 511. LETTER TO PARASRAM MEHROTRA
('57', 292, 6, 11, 491944) October 28, 1932
('57', 292, 7, 12, 491961) PARASRAM, No parallel can be drawn at all between what was said during the conversation with Acharya Gidwani and the question of inter dining with Harijans.
('57', 292, 7, 13, 492118) Those who arrange such dinners have already goodwill in their hearts for the latter.
('57', 292, 7, 14, 492203) Hence the students who join such dinners for sharing in their pleasure cannot be compared with them.
('57', 292, 7, 15, 492304) And in any case the Harijans cannot be compared with such students who are attracted to the parties by the thought of enjoyment, for what we do for Harijans cannot be described as temptation held out to them.
('57', 292, 7, 16, 492513) Those who do prayaschitta do it not as a temptation to anybody but for self purification.
('57', 292, 7, 17, 492603) Is not all this as clear as daylight?
('57', 292, 7, 18, 492641) Whether or not mixed dinner parties are proper is a separate issue.
('57', 292, 7, 19, 492709) In certain circumstances such a party may be proper and in certain other circumstances it may not be so.
('57', 292, 7, 20, 492814) Thus it is entirely a question of the circumstances of each case.
('57', 292, 8, 21, 492880) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 7510. Also C.W. 4987. Courtesy: Parasram Mehrotra
('57', 292, 9, 22, 492969) 1 An octogenarian, Salt had met Gandhiji in London in November 1931. On October 8, 1932, he had written: “The subject under special consideration, when I saw you in London, was vegetarianism; and I feel as strongly as ever that food reform, like socialism, has an essential part to play in the liberation of mankind.
('57', 292, 9, 23, 493286) I cannot see how there can be any real and full recognition of kinship, as long as men continue either to cheat or to eat, their fellow beings!”

('57', 300, 1, 2, 506426) 523. LETTER TO MOHANLAL M. BHATT
('57', 300, 2, 3, 506459) October 30, 1932
('57', 300, 3, 4, 506476) I don’t think that I can lay down rules for indefinite fasting which would satisfy you.
('57', 300, 3, 5, 506564) I might say only this.
('57', 300, 3, 6, 506587) A fast should be characterized by perfect truth and non violence, and should be undertaken only upon the prompting of one’s inner voice and not in blind imitation of somebody.
('57', 300, 3, 7, 506763) One should never undertake a fast for a selfish end; the aim behind a fast should always be common good.
('57', 300, 3, 8, 506868) A fast should never be undertaken for any object which is inspired by ill will towards somebody.
('57', 300, 3, 9, 506965) But what is inner voice?
('57', 300, 3, 10, 506990) Can everybody claim it?
('57', 300, 3, 11, 507014) These are important questions.
('57', 300, 3, 12, 507045) Of course the inner voice speaks to everybody; but he whose ear has not learnt to recognize and listen to the inner voice will not be able to hear it, just as a deaf person cannot hear even the sweetest music.
('57', 300, 3, 13, 507255) The ears of one who lacks self control cannot recognize the true inner voice.
('57', 300, 3, 14, 507333) Only that person will be fit to recognize it who possesses the charactertistics of the sthitaprajna given in Ch. II of the Gita, or of the devotee in Ch. XII, or of the gunatita in Ch. XIV or the one in whom all the three gunas blend.
('57', 300, 3, 15, 507568) The question put by Sundaram is improper.
('57', 300, 3, 16, 507610) 1 But now that he has asked it, I ought to say that, according to me, on the whole the Hindu religion is “nearest to the truth”.
('57', 300, 3, 17, 507739) But at the same time I admit unhesitatingly that in holding this view I may be making a mistake through ignorance or partiality.
('57', 300, 3, 18, 507868) The mistake, if any, is paradonable and one which has its use, because, in the absence of all ignorance and partiality it would be impossible for any man to cling to his religion, and he would, and ought to, embrace another religion in which he saw more of truth.
('57', 300, 3, 19, 508132) Call it God’s maya or know it by any other name you choose, but all human beings have this weakness.
('57', 300, 3, 20, 508233) And yet, in spite of such attachment to one’s own religion, one ought to hold all religions in equal regard.
('57', 300, 3, 21, 508342) In other words, I should, as a Hindu, accept it as natural for a Christian to believe that Christianity is nearer to the truth and for a Muslim to believe that about Islam, and also that it is necessary for them to do so if they are to follow their respective religions sincerely.
('57', 300, 3, 22, 508623) I ought to bear them no ill will for such a belief, nor should I regard their belief as mistaken.
('57', 300, 3, 23, 508721) I hope that what I have said will be clear to Bhai Sundaram and to all of you.
('57', 300, 3, 24, 508800) Probably this view of mine about equality towards all religions is a new idea.
('57', 300, 4, 25, 508879) 1 He had asked which religion, in Gandhiji’s view, was nearest to the truth.
('57', 301, 0, 1, 508956) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 301, 1, 2, 508998) other people also have thought about the matter along similar lines, I am not aware of the fact.
('57', 301, 1, 3, 509095) For me at any rate, the idea is original and it has given me the purest joy.
('57', 301, 1, 4, 509172) My view enables me to cling to Hinduism and to hold other religions in reverence at the same time, and adopt from them without hesitation whatever is good in them.
('57', 301, 1, 5, 509336) I owe this discovery to non violence.

('57', 304, 10, 12, 513676) 532. LETTER TO M. G. BHANDARI
('57', 304, 11, 13, 513706) October 31, 1932
('57', 304, 12, 14, 513723) DEAR MAJOR BHANDARI, As the Government have not granted the relief sought in my letter to Col.
('57', 304, 12, 15, 513818) Doyle of the 24th inst.
('57', 304, 12, 16, 513842) and unless it comes in the course of the day, the progressive non co operation adumbrated in that letter will commence from tomorrow.
('57', 304, 12, 17, 513976) As stated in that letter, I shall begin by denying myself the special food issued to me.
('57', 304, 12, 18, 514065) Will you kindly therefore have the goat’s milk stopped as from tomorrow?
('57', 304, 12, 19, 514138) Besides this, just now I am only drawing sour limes and vegetables in common with Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel and sometimes taking a little brown bread from Sjt.
('57', 304, 12, 20, 514297) Mahadev Desai’s ration.
('57', 304, 12, 21, 514321) Sardar Vallabhbhai sends for the limes and vegetables and I have asked him not to send for my portion.
('57', 304, 12, 22, 514424) In lieu of this, I shall take, for the time being and if they are issued to me, the morning kanji and the noon and the afternoon bhakri out of the ‘C’ class rations.
('57', 304, 12, 23, 514590) I may not take anything else from the ‘C’ class rations, and I can only take during any twenty four hours five ingredients besides salt, soda and water.
('57', 304, 12, 24, 514743) The vegetables and dholl generally issued to ‘C ‘class prisoners contain more than three or four ingredients.
('57', 304, 12, 25, 514853) These therefore I may not take.

('57', 307, 7, 20, 519289) All three can benefit each in his own way.
('57', 307, 7, 21, 519332) The introspective persons will, ordinarily, spend the day in seclusion, fast or have a light meal.

('57', 307, 7, 23, 519493) Observing silence for its own sake does little good and may cause harm.

('57', 308, 2, 3, 519867) October 31, 1932 Decide upon the central core of the Gita.
('57', 308, 2, 4, 519926) Then put into practice that interpretation of each verse which applies to one’s life.
('57', 308, 2, 5, 520012) This would be the best commentary on the Gita, and the truest study of it.
('57', 308, 2, 6, 520087) There can be no doubt that non attachment is the central core of the Gita.
('57', 308, 2, 7, 520162) I am certain that there is no other inspiration behind the composition of the Gita.
('57', 308, 2, 8, 520246) And I know from my own experience that observance of truth or even ahimsa is impossible without non attachment.
('57', 308, 2, 9, 520358) Undoubtedly non attachment is difficult of attainment.
('57', 308, 2, 10, 520413) But what is so strange about it?
('57', 308, 2, 11, 520446) For the realization of Satyanarayana some effort is necessarily called for and this realization without non attachment.

('57', 319, 9, 19, 536203) 563. LETTER TO MIRABEHN
('57', 319, 10, 20, 536227) November 3, 1932
('57', 319, 11, 21, 536244) MIRA, I got your letter yesterday afternoon.
('57', 319, 11, 22, 536289) It is now 5.15 a.m.
('57', 319, 11, 23, 536309) We have had the prayer, then the honey, hot water and a pinch of soda.
('57', 319, 11, 24, 536380) Then we three together prepared my fruit, viz., two musambis which Mahadev peeled, two santras which I peeled and juice of a pomegranate which Sardar extracted.
('57', 319, 11, 25, 536541) I added a pinch of salt to the juice and put the musambi and the santra pulp into the juice.
('57', 319, 11, 26, 536634) They two went out for a stroll and I ate the salad.
('57', 319, 11, 27, 536686) It was then 5.15. And I began this letter.
('57', 319, 11, 28, 536729) The left hand writing is by way of change and rest for the right hand.
('57', 319, 11, 29, 536800) Writing of the fruit salad, I give you my discovery.
('57', 319, 11, 30, 536853) I find that fruit to produce the greatest effect should be taken by itself and on an empty stomach.
('57', 319, 11, 31, 536953) You might almost say, the same law applies to juicy fruit that applies to opening medicines.
('57', 319, 11, 32, 537046) In fact all food should be taken as medicine.
('57', 319, 11, 33, 537092) The Sanskrit for food and medicine is a common word aushadh.
('57', 319, 11, 34, 537153) Kisen will explain this more fully to you.
('57', 319, 11, 35, 537196) Medicine need not be nasty to taste; nor is it taken for the pleasure of the palate.
('57', 320, 0, 1, 537281) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 321
('57', 320, 1, 2, 537331) Food should be treated exactly in the same manner, i.e., suitable food in suitable proportion in suitable manner and at suitable times.
('57', 320, 1, 3, 537467) Here I interrupted the writing for the morning walk and now resume at 6.45. There are many books on the life of the Prophet.
('57', 320, 1, 4, 537592) The first place must be given to Amir Ali’s Spirit of Islam.
('57', 320, 1, 5, 537653) Then there is WashingtonIrving’s Mahomet and His Successors, a very well written work.
('57', 320, 1, 6, 537740) Carlyle’s Mahomet as Hero is also well worth reading.
('57', 320, 1, 7, 537794) I am glad you have Kisen with you.
('57', 320, 1, 8, 537829) She should get the most out of you and you of her.
('57', 320, 1, 9, 537880) I wonder if she got my letter in reply to hers.
('57', 320, 1, 10, 537928) I sent it to the address she gave.
('57', 320, 1, 11, 537963) Whether she received it or not, tell her never to write a bad hand whether there is hurry or not.
('57', 320, 1, 12, 538061) This lesson everyone should learn from my misfortune.
('57', 320, 1, 13, 538115) Bad writing and bad everything is truly himsa.
('57', 320, 1, 14, 538162) We have a rare opportunity of learning the virtue of patience in prison life.
('57', 320, 1, 15, 538240) I think your comparison between Jesus and Muhammed is striking and partly true.
('57', 320, 1, 16, 538320) You have heard the saying comparisons are odious.
('57', 320, 1, 17, 538370) In my opinion all revolutionaries are reformers and all reformers are revolutionaries.
('57', 320, 1, 18, 538457) Both were great teachers and each was in response to his age and its requirements.
('57', 320, 1, 19, 538540) And each made a unique contribution to the advance of mankind.
('57', 320, 1, 20, 538603) They have an equal place in the universal pantheon.
('57', 320, 1, 21, 538655) Your description of yourself as an ashramite is perfect.
('57', 320, 1, 22, 538712) You do not deny Christ but you affirm yourself as an ashramite who denies no teacher.
('57', 320, 1, 23, 538798) We are not concerned much with the interpretations of the different teachers.
('57', 320, 1, 24, 538876) Each fashioned his or her own.
('57', 320, 1, 25, 538907) I am sending by registered post Amir Ali’s book.
('57', 320, 1, 26, 538956) When you have finished it, post it to Raihana.
('57', 320, 1, 27, 539003) It belongs to the Tyabjee’s.
('57', 320, 1, 28, 539032) Love from us all to you and Kisen.
('57', 320, 3, 29, 539067) From the original: C.W. 6248. Courtesy: Mirabehn

('57', 323, 1, 2, 543548) 566. LETTER TO MAGANBHAI DESAI
('57', 323, 2, 3, 543579) November 3, 1932 I am becoming more convinced from experience that, as one’s faith in God grows, one finds greater joy in doing one’s duty, becomes more efficient and vigilant, and also more calm and patient.
('57', 323, 2, 4, 543788) Since I have unlimited faith in God, I believe that it is He who enables us to do any work, small or big.
('57', 323, 2, 5, 543894) I do not know how He does that.
('57', 323, 2, 6, 543926) If a person who claims to have dedicated his all, body, mind and possessions, to God, believes that he himself has done something, he would be a thief.
('57', 323, 2, 7, 544078) I would not sin by ignorantly believing that I have done anything.
('57', 323, 2, 8, 544145) If I sometimes believe that or say that in ordinary conversation in joking or in order not to seem different from other people, it is foolishness on my part.
('57', 323, 2, 9, 544303) The truth is that I am daily growing more humble and, therfore feel pained whenever I think in pride that I have done something .
('57', 323, 2, 10, 544433) [From Gujarati]
('57', 323, 3, 11, 544449) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, p.
