('57', 325, 5, 8, 546422) 571. STATEMENT ON UNTOUCHABILITY 1 I
('57', 325, 6, 9, 546459) November 4, 1932 For reasons over which I had no control I have not been able to deal with the question of untouchability, as I had fully intended to after the breaking of the fast.
('57', 325, 6, 10, 546641) The Government having now granted me permission to carry on public propaganda in connection with the work, I am able to deal with the numerous correspondents who have been writing to me either in criticism of the Yeravda Pact, or to seek guidance, or to know my views about the different questions that arise in the course of the campaign against untouchability.
('57', 325, 6, 11, 547004) In this prelim inary statement I propose to confine myself to the salient questions only, deferring for the time being other questions which do not call for immediate disposal.
('57', 325, 6, 12, 547181) I take up first the question of the possibility of my resuming the fast.
('57', 325, 6, 13, 547254) Some correspondents contend that the fast savours of coercion and should not have been undertaken at all and that, therefore, it should never be resumed.
('57', 325, 6, 14, 547408) Some others have argued that there is no warrant in Hindu religion, or any religion for that matter, for a fast like mine.
('57', 325, 6, 15, 547531) I do not propose to deal with the religious aspect.
('57', 325, 6, 16, 547583) Suffice it to say that it was at God’s call that I embarked upon the last fast and it would be at His call that it would be resumed, if it ever is.
('57', 325, 6, 17, 547731) But when it was first undertaken, it was undoubtedly for removal of untouch ability, root and branch.
('57', 325, 6, 18, 547833) That it took the form it did was no choice of mine.
('57', 325, 6, 19, 547885) The Cabinet decision precipitated the crisis of my life, but I
('57', 325, 7, 20, 547948) 1 Following the lifting of restrictions by the Government on Gandhiji’s inter views and his carrying on propaganda in connection with anti untouchability work, Gandhiji issued a series of statements to the Press.
('57', 325, 7, 21, 548161) This is the first of them.
('57', 326, 0, 1, 548188) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 327
('57', 326, 1, 2, 548238) knew that the revocation of the British Cabinet’s decision was to be but the begining of the end.
('57', 326, 1, 3, 548336) A tremendous force could not be set in motion merely in order to alter a political decision, unless it had behind it a much deeper meaning even unknown to its authors.
('57', 326, 1, 4, 548504) The people affected instinctively recognized that meaning and responded.
('57', 326, 1, 5, 548577) Perhaps no man within living memory has travelled so often from one end of India to the other or has penetrated so many villages and come into contact with so many millions as I have.
('57', 326, 1, 6, 548761) They have all known my life.
('57', 326, 1, 7, 548790) They have known that I have recognized no barriers between ‘untouchables’ and ‘touchables’ or caste and outcaste.
('57', 326, 1, 8, 548904) They have heard me speak often in their own tongues denouncing untouchability in unmeasured terms, describing it as a curse and a blot upon Hinduism.
('57', 326, 1, 9, 549054) With rare exceptions, at hundreds of these mass meetings or at private meetings in all parts of India, there has been no protest against my presentation of the case against untouchability.
('57', 326, 1, 10, 549243) Crowds have passed resolutions denouncing untouchability and pledging themselves to remove it from their midst and they have on innumerable occasions called God as witness to their pledge and asked for His blessing that He may give them strength to carry out their pledge.
('57', 326, 1, 11, 549516) It was against these millions that my fast was undertaken and it was their spontaneous love that brought about a transformation inside of five days and brought into being the Yeravda Pact.
('57', 326, 1, 12, 549705) And it will be against them that the fast will be resumed if that Pact is not carried out by them in its fullness.
('57', 326, 1, 13, 549820) The Government are now practically out of it.
('57', 326, 1, 14, 549866) Their part of the obligation they fulfilled promptly.
('57', 326, 1, 15, 549920) The major part of the resolutions of the Yeravda Pact has to be fulfilled by these millions, the so called caste Hindus, who have flocked to the meetings I have described.
('57', 326, 1, 16, 550092) It is they who have to embrace the suppressed brethren and sisters as their very own, whom they have to invite to their temples, to their homes, to their schools.
('57', 326, 1, 17, 550255) The ‘untouchables’ in the villages should be made to feel that their shackles have been broken, that they are in no way inferior to their fellow villagers, that they are worshippers of the same God as other villagers, and are entitled to the same rights and privileges that the latter enjoy.
('57', 326, 1, 18, 550547) But if these vital conditions of the Pact are not carried out by caste Hindus, could I possibly live to face God and man?
('57', 326, 1, 19, 550669) I ventured even to tell Dr. Ambedkar, Rao Bahadur Raja and other friends belonging to the suppressed group that they should regard me as a hostage for the due fulfilment by caste Hindus of the conditions of the Pact.
('57', 326, 1, 20, 550886) The fast, if it has to come, will not be for the coercion of
('57', 327, 0, 1, 550947) 328 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 327, 1, 2, 550989) those who are opponents of the reform, but it will be intended to sting into action those who have been my comrades or who have taken pledges for the removal of untouchability.
('57', 327, 1, 3, 551166) If they belie their pledge, or if they never meant to abide by them, and their Hinduism was a mere camouflage, I should have no interest left in life.
('57', 327, 1, 4, 551317) My fast, therefore, ought not to affect the opponents of reform, nor even fellow workers and the millions who have led me to believe that they were with me and the Congress in the campaign against untouchability, if the latter have on second thoughts come to the conclusion that untouchability is not after all a crime against God and humanity.
('57', 327, 1, 5, 551662) In my opinion, fasting for purification of self and others is an age long institution and it will subsist so long as man believes in God.
('57', 327, 1, 6, 551800) It is the prayer to the Almighty from an anguished heart.
('57', 327, 1, 7, 551858) But whether my argument is wise or foolish, I cannot be dislodged from my position so long as I do not see the folly or the error of it.
('57', 327, 1, 8, 551995) It will be resumed only in obedience to the inner voice, and only if there is manifest breakdown of the Yeravda Pact, owing to the criminal neglect of caste Hindus to implement its conditions.
('57', 327, 1, 9, 552188) Such neglect would mean a betrayal of Hinduism.
('57', 327, 1, 10, 552236) I should not care to remain its living witness.
('57', 327, 1, 11, 552284) There is another fast which is a near possibility and that is in connection with the opening of the Guruvayur temple in Kerala.
('57', 327, 1, 12, 552412) It was at my urgent request that Sjt.
('57', 327, 1, 13, 552450) Kelappan suspended his fast for three months, a fast that had well nigh brought him to death’s door.
('57', 327, 1, 14, 552551) I would be in honour bound to fast with him if on or before the first January next that temple is not opened to the ‘untouchables’ precisely on the same terms as the ‘touchables’, and if it becomes necessary for Sjt.
('57', 327, 1, 15, 552768) Kelappan to resume his fast.
('57', 327, 1, 16, 552797) I have been obliged to dwell at some length upon these possible fasts because of the receipt of hot correspondence from two or three quarters.
('57', 327, 1, 17, 552940) Co workers, however, should not be agitated over the possiblity.
('57', 327, 1, 18, 553005) To become unnerved over a prospect one would not like face very often results in its materializing.
('57', 327, 1, 19, 553105) The best way of averting it is for all affected by it to put forth their whole strength into the work that would render the occurence impossible.
('57', 327, 1, 20, 553251) Correspondents have asked whether inter dining and inter marriage are part of the movement against untouchability.
('57', 327, 1, 21, 553366) In my opinion they are not.
('57', 327, 1, 22, 553394) They touch the caste men equally with the outcastes.
('57', 327, 1, 23, 553447) It is, therefore, not obligatory on an anti untouchability
('57', 328, 0, 1, 553506) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 329
('57', 328, 1, 2, 553556) worker to devote himself or herself to inter dining and intermarriage reform.
('57', 328, 1, 3, 553634) Personally, I am of opinion that this reform is coming sooner than we expect.
('57', 328, 1, 4, 553712) Restriction on inter caste dining and inter caste marriage is no part of Hindu religion.
('57', 328, 1, 5, 553801) It is a social custom which crept into Hinduism when perhaps it was in its decline, and was then meant perhaps to be temporary protection against disintegration of Hindu society, and emphasis on them has turned the attention of mass mind from the fundamentals which are vital to life’s growth.
('57', 328, 1, 6, 554095) Wherever, therefore, people voluntarily take part in functions where ‘touchables’ and ‘untouchables’, Hindus and in non Hindus are invited to join dinner parties, I welcome them as a healthy sign.
('57', 328, 1, 7, 554292) But I should never dream of making this reform, however desirable in itself it may be, part of an all India reform which has been long overdue.
('57', 328, 1, 8, 554436) Untouchability in the form we all know it is a canker eating into the very vitals of Hinduism.
('57', 328, 1, 9, 554531) Dining and marriage restrictions stunt Hindu society.
('57', 328, 1, 10, 554585) I think the distinction is fundamental.
('57', 328, 1, 11, 554625) It would be unwise in a hurricane capmaign to overweight and thus endanger the main issue.
('57', 328, 1, 12, 554716) It may even amount to a breach of faith with the masses to call upon them suddenly to view the removal of untouchability in a light different from what they have been taught to believe it to be.
('57', 328, 1, 13, 554911) On the one hand, therefore, whilst inter dining may go on where the public is itself ready for it, it should not be part of the India wide campaign.
('57', 328, 1, 14, 555060) I have letters, some of them angrily worded, from those who style themselves sanatanists.
('57', 328, 1, 15, 555150) For them untouchability, is the essence of Hinduism.
('57', 328, 1, 16, 555203) Some of them regard me as a renegade.
('57', 328, 1, 17, 555241) Some others consider that I have imbibed notions against untouchability and the like from Christianity and Islam.
('57', 328, 1, 18, 555355) Some again quote scriptures in defence of untouchability.
('57', 328, 1, 19, 555413) To these I have promised a reply through this statement.
('57', 328, 1, 20, 555470) I would venture, therefore, to tell these correspondents that I claim myself to be a sanatanist.
('57', 328, 1, 21, 555567) Their definition of a sanatanist is obviously different from mine.
('57', 328, 1, 22, 555634) For me sanatan dharma is the vital faith handed down from generations belonging even to prehistoric period and based upon the Vedas and the writings that followed them.
('57', 328, 1, 23, 555803) For me the Vedas are as indefinable as God and Hinduism.
('57', 328, 1, 24, 555860) It would be only partially true to say that the Vedas are the four books which one finds in print.
('57', 328, 1, 25, 555959) These books are themselves remnants of the discourses left by the unknown seers.
('57', 328, 1, 26, 556040) Those of later generations added to these original treasures according to their lights.
('57', 328, 1, 27, 556128) There then arose a great and lofty minded man, the composer of the Gita.
('57', 329, 0, 1, 556201) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 329, 1, 2, 556243) gave to the Hindu world a synthesis of Hindu religion at once deeply philosophical and yet easily to be understood by any unsophisticated seeker.
('57', 329, 1, 3, 556389) It is the one open book to every Hindu who will care to study it, and if all the other scriptures were reduced to ashes, the seven hundred verses of this imperishable booklet are quite enough to tell one what Hinduism is and how one can live up to it.
('57', 329, 1, 4, 556641) And I claim to be a sanatanist because for forty years I have been seeking literally to live up to the teachings of that book.
('57', 329, 1, 5, 556768) Whatever is contrary to its main theme I reject as un Hindu.
('57', 329, 1, 6, 556829) It excludes no faith and no teacher.
('57', 329, 1, 7, 556866) It gives me great joy to be able to say that I have studied the Bible, the Koran, Zend Avesta and the other scriptures of the world with thesame reverence that I have given to the Gita.
('57', 329, 1, 8, 557052) This reverent reading has strengthened my faith in the Gita.
('57', 329, 1, 9, 557113) They have broadened my outlook and therefore my Hinduism.
('57', 329, 1, 10, 557171) Lives of Zoroaster, Jesus and Mohammed, as I have understood them, have illumined many a passage in the Gita.
('57', 329, 1, 11, 557281) What, therefore, these sanatani friends have hurled against me as a taunt has been to me a source of consolation.
('57', 329, 1, 12, 557395) I take pride in calling myself a Hindu becuase I find the term broad enough not merely to tolerate but to assimilate the teachings of prophets from all the four corners of the earth.
('57', 329, 1, 13, 557578) I find no warrant for untouchability in this book of life.
('57', 329, 1, 14, 557637) On the contrary it compels me, by an appeal to my reason and a more penetrating appeal to my heart, in language that has a magnetic touch about it, to believe that all life is one and that it is through God and must return to Him.
('57', 329, 1, 15, 557868) According to sanatan dharma taught by that venerable Mother 1, life does not consist in outward rites and ceremonial, but it consists in the uttermost inner purification and merging oneself, body, soul and mind, in the divine essence.
('57', 329, 1, 16, 558103) I have gone to the masses in their millions with this message of the Gita burnt into my life.
('57', 329, 1, 17, 558197) And they have listened to me, I am quite sure, not for any political wisdom or for eloquence, but because they have instinctively recognized me as one of them, as one belonging to their faith.
('57', 329, 1, 18, 558390) And as days have gone by, my belief has grown stronger and stronger that I could not be wrong in claiming to belong to sanatan dharma, and if God wills it, He will let me seal that claim with my death.

('57', 330, 1, 2, 558677) 572. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS
('57', 330, 2, 3, 558706) November 4, 1932
('57', 330, 3, 4, 558723) MY DEAR CHARLIE, I have two letters to answer.
('57', 330, 3, 5, 558770) Of course your decision is right.
('57', 330, 3, 6, 558804) Your problem of untouchability is in a way more complex than mine.
('57', 330, 3, 7, 558871) Untouchability is a dying cult and has an ever growing army of reformers to deal it death blows.
('57', 330, 3, 8, 558968) Yours shows no signs of dying and claims many supporters in the name of science.
('57', 330, 3, 9, 559049) And you have very few workers.
('57', 330, 3, 10, 559080) But as you and I have repeatedly found, what is difficult for man is easy for God.
('57', 330, 3, 11, 559163) Anyway, we have but to do our part of work, and I shall pray for success in your work.
('57', 330, 3, 12, 559250) I assure you I do not want to kill brother ass.
('57', 330, 3, 13, 559298) He is in God’s safe keeping.
('57', 330, 3, 14, 559327) If He means to starve him, neither your effort nor mine can save him.
('57', 330, 3, 15, 559397) For the present he is flourishing on goat’s milk and plenty of fruit with some home made bread thrown in.
('57', 330, 3, 16, 559503) Gurudev is still at it.
('57', 330, 3, 17, 559527) That little fast brought me many undreamt of treasures.
('57', 330, 3, 18, 559583) Gurudev was the richest find.
('57', 330, 3, 19, 559613) If someone had said “fast to find Gurudev” I should have done it without a second thought.
('57', 330, 3, 20, 559704) I was dying to find a corner in his heart.
('57', 330, 3, 21, 559747) Thank God I found it through the fast.
('57', 330, 3, 22, 559786) Love from us all.

('57', 330, 6, 24, 559831) 573. STATEMENT ON UNTOUCHABILITY–II
('57', 330, 7, 25, 559867) November 5, 1932 A correspondent, in spite of having received liberal education suggests that before Harijans are put on a level with caste Hindus, they should become fit for such reception, shed their dirty habits, give up eating carrion; another goes the length of saying that Bhangis and Chamars who are engaged in what he considers are, ‘dirty occupations’ should give them up.
('57', 330, 7, 26, 560249) These critics forget that caste men are responsible for whatever bad habits are to be observed amongst the Harijans.
('57', 330, 7, 27, 560366) The so called higher castes have deprived them of facilities for keeping themselves clean and also the incentive for doing so.
('57', 330, 7, 28, 560493) As for the occupations of scavenging and tanning, they are no more dirty than many other occupations I can name.
('57', 330, 7, 29, 560606) What may be
('57', 331, 0, 1, 560618) 332 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 331, 1, 2, 560660) admitted is that these occupations like several others are carried on in a dirty manner.
('57', 331, 1, 3, 560749) That again is due to the high handed indifference and criminal neglect of the ‘high castes’.
('57', 331, 1, 4, 560842) I can say from personal experience that both scavenging and tanning can be done in a perfectly healthy and clean manner.
('57', 331, 1, 5, 560963) Every mother is a scavenger in regard to her own children and every student of modern medicine is a tanner in as much as he has to dissect and skin human carcases.
('57', 331, 1, 6, 561127) But we consider theirs to be sacred occupations.
('57', 331, 1, 7, 561176) I submit that the ordinary scavengers’ and tanners’ occupations are no less sacred and no less useful than those of mothers and medical men.
('57', 331, 1, 8, 561317) We shall go wrong if caste men regard themselves as patrons distributing favours to the Harijans.
('57', 331, 1, 9, 561415) Whatever is done now by the caste Hindus for the Harijans will be but a tardy reparation for the wrongs done to them for generations, and if now they have to be received in their existing state, as they must be received, it is a well deserved punishment for the past guilt.
('57', 331, 1, 10, 561689) But there is this certain satisfaction that the very act of receiving them with open hearts would be a sufficient incentive to cleanliness, and the caste men will for their own comfort and convenience provide Harijans with facilities for keeping themselves clean.
('57', 331, 1, 11, 561953) It is well to remind ourselves of what wrongs we have heaped upon the devoted heads of the Harijans.
('57', 331, 1, 12, 562054) Socially they are lepers.
('57', 331, 1, 13, 562080) Economically they are worse than slaves.
('57', 331, 1, 14, 562121) Religiously they are denied entrance to places we miscall ‘houses of God’.
('57', 331, 1, 15, 562196) They are denied the use, on the same terms as the caste men, of public roads, public hospitals, public wells, public taps, public parks and the like, and in some cases their approach within a measured distance is a social crime, and in some other rare enough cases their very sight is an offence.
('57', 331, 1, 16, 562493) They are relegated for their residence to the worst quarters of cities or villages where they practically get no social services.
('57', 331, 1, 17, 562623) Caste Hindu lawyers and doctors will not serve them as they do other members of society.
('57', 331, 1, 18, 562712) Brahmins will not officiate at their religious functions.
('57', 331, 1, 19, 562770) The wonder is that they are at all able to eke out an existence or that they still remain within the Hindu fold.
('57', 331, 1, 20, 562883) They are too downtrodden to rise in revolt against their suppressors.
('57', 331, 1, 21, 562953) I have recalled these tragic and shameful facts in order to make the workers vividly realize the implications of the Yeravda Pact.
('57', 331, 1, 22, 563084) It is only ceaseless effort that can raise these downtrodden fellow beings from degradation, purify Hinduism, and raise the whole Hindu society and with it the whole of India.
('57', 332, 0, 1, 563260) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 333
('57', 332, 1, 2, 563310) Let us not be stunned by this simple recital of the wrongs.
('57', 332, 1, 3, 563370) If the demonstration during the last week was a genuine expression of repentance on the part of caste Hindus, all will be well, and every Harijan will soon feel the glow of freedom.
('57', 332, 1, 4, 563552) But before this much desired end can be achieved the message of freedom will have to be carried to the remotest village.
('57', 332, 1, 5, 563673) Indeed the work in the village is far more difficult than in the big cities where it is possible quickly to mobilize public opinion.
('57', 332, 1, 6, 563806) Now that there is the All India Anti untouchability League, workers should work in co ordination with that League.
('57', 332, 1, 7, 563921) And here I would like to recall what Dr. Ambedkar told me.
('57', 332, 1, 8, 563980) He said, “Let there be no repetition of the old method when the reformer claimed to know more of the requirements of his victims than the victims themselves”, and therefore, he added “tell your workers to ascertain from the representatives of the Harijans what their first need is and how they would like it to be satisfied.
('57', 332, 1, 9, 564305) Joint refreshments are good enough by way of demonstration, but they may be overdone.
('57', 332, 1, 10, 564391) There is a flavour of patronage about them.
('57', 332, 1, 11, 564435) I would not attend them by myself.
('57', 332, 1, 12, 564470) The more dignified procedure would be to invite us to ordinary social functions without any fuss.
('57', 332, 1, 13, 564568) Even temple entry, good and necessary as it is, may wait.
('57', 332, 1, 14, 564626) The crying need is the raising of the economic status and decent behaviour in the daily contact.” I must not repeat here some of the harrowing details given by him from his own bitter experiences.
('57', 332, 1, 15, 564823) I felt the force of his remarks.
('57', 332, 1, 16, 564856) I hope every one of my readers will do likewise.
('57', 332, 1, 17, 564905) Many suggestions have been sent to me for adoption by the reformers.
('57', 332, 1, 18, 564974) One is a repetition of what Swami Shraddhanandji used to repeat so often, namely, that every Hindu should have in his home a Harijan who would be for all practical purposes a member of the family.
('57', 332, 1, 19, 565171) The second comes from a non Hindu friend deeply interested in India’s welfare.
('57', 332, 1, 20, 565250) He says that every well to do Hindu should bear the expense of giving, if possible under his own observation, higher education to a Harijan young man or girl so that these after finishing their education might work for the uplift of fellow Harijans.
('57', 332, 1, 21, 565500) Both the suggestions are worthy of consideration and adoption.
('57', 332, 1, 22, 565563) I would ask all who have made fruitful suggestions to pass them on to the newly established League.
('57', 332, 1, 23, 565663) Correspondents should recognize my limitations.
('57', 332, 1, 24, 565711) From behind the prison gates, I can only tender advice to the League and the people.
('57', 332, 1, 25, 565796) I can take no part in the real execution of plans.
('57', 332, 1, 26, 565847) They should also recognize that my opinions, based as they must be on insufficient data, and often on second hand information, are liable to
('57', 333, 0, 1, 565988) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 333, 1, 2, 566030) revision in the light of new facts and should, therefore, be received with caution.
('57', 333, 1, 3, 566114) Though it is now past history I would devote a paragraph to the objection raised by a correspondent and even voiced in suppressed tones in the Press.
('57', 333, 1, 4, 566264) Referring to the political part of the Pact they ask, ‘What have you gained by it?
('57', 333, 1, 5, 566347) The Harijans have surely got much more than the Prime Minister gave’.
('57', 333, 1, 6, 566417) Well, that is exactly the gain.
('57', 333, 1, 7, 566449) My objection to the decision was that it gave stone instead of bread.
('57', 333, 1, 8, 566519) This Pact has given bits of bread.
('57', 333, 1, 9, 566554) I personally would have rejoiced with Dr. Moonje if the Harijans had got all the seats allotted to the Hindus.
('57', 333, 1, 10, 566665) That would have been the greatest gain to caste Hindus and Hinduism.
('57', 333, 1, 11, 566734) What I wanted and what I still want is their complete merger in the caste Hindus and the latter’s in the former.
('57', 333, 1, 12, 566847) It is my deliberate opinion, not likely to be altered by any fresh fact that may come to light, that the more the suppressors give to the suppressed the more they gain.
('57', 333, 1, 13, 567016) They gain pro tanto discharge from overdue debts.
('57', 333, 1, 14, 567066) Unless the caste Hindus approach the question in that humble, penitent, religious and right spirit, the remaining part of the Pact will never be observed in the spirit that seemed to pervade Hindu society during the fast week.
('57', 333, 1, 15, 567293) I would like to tender my congratulations to those Princes who have opened their State temples to the Harijans and have otherwise proclaimed banishment of untouchability from their States.
('57', 333, 1, 16, 567482) If I may say it, they have thereby done some penance on their own behalf and their people’s.
('57', 333, 1, 17, 567575) I hope that the Hindus residing in these States will carry out the terms of these proclamations and so fraternize with them as to make the Harijans feel that they never were the despised outcastes of Hindu humanity.
('57', 333, 1, 18, 567791) We are too near the scene of tragedy to realize that this canker of untouchability has travelled far beyond its prescribed limits and has sapped the foundations of the whole nation.
('57', 333, 1, 19, 567973) The touch me not spirit pervades the atmosphere.
('57', 333, 1, 20, 568022) If, therefore, this white ant is touched at its source, I feel sure that we shall soon forget the differences with regard to caste and caste and religion and religion and begin to believe that even as all Hindus are one and indivisible, so are all Hindus, Mussalmans, Sikhs, Parsis, Jews and Christians, branches of the same parent tree.

('57', 338, 3, 19, 577403) And even if the Harijans should manage to enter the temples in this manner and some Hindus should inter dine with them, I would never accept it as removal of untouchability.
('57', 338, 3, 20, 577577) Rather than be a witness to such reform I would prefer death, because I am convinced that complusion can neither remove untouchability nor safeguard Hinduism.
('57', 338, 3, 21, 577736) Let me make myself clear: I am not opposed to inter dining in any way and I consider it adharma for anyone to refuse to eat in the company of a person out of contempt for him or on account of his birth.
('57', 338, 3, 22, 577939) Assuredly it would be an exaggeration to assert that dining together necessarily promotes friendly feeling.
('57', 338, 3, 23, 578047) But to refuse to dine with someone who is clean and is a vegetarian because he follows another religion or he belongs to another province or is an untou chable, would be adharma.
('57', 338, 3, 24, 578226) It cannot be considered proper to attribute to the untouchables as such insanitation and such other defects and to refuse to dine with them.

('57', 338, 3, 26, 578456) The caste Hindus, having created a class of outcastes, have up to the present day been treating

('57', 342, 2, 13, 585071) The food which prisoners get in South Africa is wholesome from the point of view of health and self control.
('57', 342, 2, 14, 585180) In the Ashram, we serve at break fast whole wheat flour boiled in water and with jaggery mixed in it.
('57', 342, 2, 15, 585282) Here they give to every prisoner gruel of five tolas of jowar flour with salt.
('57', 342, 2, 16, 585361) This experiment seems worth trying there.
('57', 342, 2, 17, 585403) Perhaps we may not be able to digest five tolas of flour.

('57', 342, 2, 27, 585980) It may change from day to day.

('57', 350, 6, 15, 598991) 598. STATEMENT ON UNTOUCHABILITY–III
('57', 350, 7, 16, 599028) November 7, 1932
('57', 350, 8, 17, 599045) A correspondent whom I know well and who is in sympathy with the movement against untouchability, though he does not accept the whole of the programme, wrote a long letter in Hindi from which I condense the following: I fear that the campaign is not being kept within bounds in all parts of the country.
('57', 350, 8, 18, 599349) I understand in some cases those who claim to be workers in the cause are making use of questi onable methods such as resorting to abuse of adherents of the old order, and pouring ridicule on sacred names.
('57', 350, 8, 19, 599555) Anyone who dares to analyse your sayings or writings or to oppose the
('57', 350, 9, 20, 599625) 1 From the contents it appears that this letter was written before the letter to addressee dated November 7, 1932; vide “Letter to Kapilari M. Mehta”, 7 11 1932 2 Editor, Gujarat Samachar and then Sandesh.
('57', 350, 9, 21, 599831) A student of the Gujarat Vidyapith, he had taken part in the civil disobedience movement in 1930.
('57', 351, 0, 1, 599929) 352 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 351, 1, 2, 599971) extreme forms that the campaign is taking, immediately becomes a butt of ridicule and is labelled a traitor to his religion and even threatened with dire consequences.
('57', 351, 1, 3, 600139) They do not seem to care for the material or moral welfare of the outcastes.
('57', 351, 1, 4, 600216) They think that their effort begins and ends with promiscuous dinners and marching crowds of Harijans to temples even in defiance of the wishes to the contrary of the trustees.
('57', 351, 1, 5, 600393) I am sure you do not want the movement to degenerate into mere spectacular demonstrations calculated merely to wound the feelings of the orthodox without doing the least service to the Harijans.
('57', 351, 1, 6, 600588) Out of nearly a hundred letters on untouchability received by me during the past month this is the first letter complaining of workers’ conduct bordering on violence.
('57', 351, 1, 7, 600755) I, however, felt the necessity for giving publicity to the complaint, if only out of regard for my correspondent’s warning to workers.
('57', 351, 1, 8, 600890) I know he will not indulge in wilful exaggeration.
('57', 351, 1, 9, 600941) There can be no complusion in matters of religion, I should say in any matter.
('57', 351, 1, 10, 601020) The public know my very strong views against violence in any shape or form against anyone, no matter what his caste, creed, or nationality may be.
('57', 351, 1, 11, 601167) Let those in charge of the movement, therefore, understand that even in their impatience to save me from the prospective fast they may not force the pace by adopting questionable methods.
('57', 351, 1, 12, 601355) If they do so, they will merely hasten my end.
('57', 351, 1, 13, 601402) It would be living death for me to witness the degeneration of the movement on whose behalf, as I believe, God had prompted that little fast.
('57', 351, 1, 14, 601544) The cause of the Harijans and Hinduism will not be served by methods of rabble.
('57', 351, 1, 15, 601624) This is perhaps the biggest religious reform movement in India, if not in the world, involving as it does the well being of nearly sixty million human beings living in serfdom.
('57', 351, 1, 16, 601801) The orthodox section that disapproves of this is entitled to every courtesy and consideration.
('57', 351, 1, 17, 601896) We have to win them by love, by self sacrifice, by perfect self restraint, and by letting purity of our lives produce its own silent effect upon their hearts.
('57', 351, 1, 18, 602055) We must have faith in our truth and love for converting our opponents to our way.
('57', 351, 1, 19, 602137) There is no doubt whatsoever that the deliverance of sixty million human beings from age long suppression will not be brought about by mere showy demonstrations.
('57', 351, 1, 20, 602299) There has to be solid and constructive programme contemplating an attack on all fronts.
('57', 351, 1, 21, 602387) This enterprise requires concentrated energy of thousands of men, women, boys and girls who are actuated by the loftiest of religious motives.
('57', 351, 1, 22, 602530) I would, therefore, respectfully urge those who don’t appreciate the purely religious character of the movement to retire from it.
('57', 351, 1, 23, 602661) Let those who
('57', 352, 0, 1, 602675) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 353
('57', 352, 1, 2, 602725) have the faith and fervour, be they a few or many, work the movement.
('57', 352, 1, 3, 602795) The removal of untouchability may produce, indeed it will produce, great political consequences; but it is not a political movement.
('57', 352, 1, 4, 602928) It is a movement purely and simply of the purification of Hinduism and that purification can only come through the purest instruments.
('57', 352, 1, 5, 603063) Thanks be to God there are hundreds if not thousands of such instruments working in all parts of India.
('57', 352, 1, 6, 603167) Let impatient sceptics watch, wait and see; but let them not mar the movement by hasty and ill conceived interference even though it may be prompted by laudable motives.
('57', 352, 1, 7, 603337) The Bombay Chronicle, 8 11 1932
('57', 352, 2, 8, 603369) 599. LETTER TO HOME SECRETARY, GOVERNMENT OF INDIA
('57', 352, 3, 9, 603420) November 7, 1932
('57', 352, 4, 10, 603437) THE SECRETARY OF THE GOVERNMENT OF INDIA HOME DEPARTMENT NEW DELHI
('57', 352, 5, 11, 603504) DEAR SIR, My thoughts having been hitherto concentrated simply upon what threatened to be an impasse about untouchability, I was unable to think of any other matter.
('57', 352, 5, 12, 603670) Now that it is happily over, I would like to approach the Government of India on certain decisions of theirs which I have not been able to understand.
('57', 352, 5, 13, 603821) I should, if I may, like to know why my reply telegrams to Maulana Shaukat Ali 1 and Abul Kalam Azad 2 and to Dr. Ansari, expressing my hope of Hindu Muslim unity being achieved, were disallowed.
('57', 352, 5, 14, 604017) I saw in the Press the correspondence between His Excellency the Viceroy and Maulana Shaukat Ali regarding his request for permission to interview me on the same question.
('57', 352, 5, 15, 604189) If the reasons given to him for refusal to let him see me are also the reasons for disallowing my telegrams I fail to see the connection between my association with civil disobedience and Hindu Muslim unity.
('57', 352, 5, 16, 604397) My association with civil disobedience appears to the Government to be bad.
('57', 352, 5, 17, 604473) But I hope my views on Hindu Muslim unity and my desire to promote it do not so appear to them.
('57', 352, 5, 18, 604569) If I am right in my assumption, I can only understand the ban on the interview and my telegrams on the
('57', 352, 6, 19, 604672) 1 Vide “Telegram to Shaukat Ali”, 7 10 1932. 2 Vide “Telegram to Abdul Kalam Azad”, 20 10 1932.
('57', 353, 0, 1, 604768) 354 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 353, 1, 2, 604810) supposition that it is a punishment meted out to me and those who would see me or correspond with me, even on matters that have no connection with civil disobedience, only because I would not set aside the dictates of my conscience and my reason and would not dissociate myself from it.
('57', 353, 1, 3, 605097) I hope Government of India have not contemplated any such punishment.
('57', 353, 1, 4, 605167) The Government of India will admit that as a prisoner I have given the authorities willing co operation.
('57', 353, 1, 5, 605272) I should like it also to be intelligent.
('57', 353, 1, 6, 605313) Wherever it is possible, I should know why particular requests are refused.
('57', 353, 1, 7, 605389) So far as in me lies I endeavour to make no unreasonable requests.
('57', 353, 1, 8, 605456) They have been generally either in the interests of my health or of public good as distinguished from selfish gratification.
('57', 353, 1, 9, 605581) So far as the telegrams which are the subject matter of this letter are concerned, they do not now need to be sent.
('57', 353, 1, 10, 605697) But occasions for dealing with public matters outside untouchability and having no connection with civil disobedience will undoubtedly arise.
('57', 353, 1, 11, 605839) I should like therefore not only to know the reasons for the disallowance in the cases mentioned, but also to know the future policy of the Government on similar occasions.

('57', 354, 1, 2, 607042) 600. LETTER TO MANU GANDHI
('57', 354, 2, 3, 607069) November 7, 1932
('57', 354, 3, 4, 607086) MANUDI, You seem to be very lazy and forgetful.
('57', 354, 3, 5, 607134) After a long interval, you write a letter.
('57', 354, 3, 6, 607177) You promise that you will not be lazy again, and then forget and break your promise.
('57', 354, 3, 7, 607262) This is bad.
('57', 354, 3, 8, 607275) One should always keep one’s promise, and should never make a promise which one cannot keep.
('57', 354, 3, 9, 607368) You should write a letter every Sunday and post it to the Ashram.
('57', 354, 3, 10, 607434) You should give in it a report of the work done by you during the preceding week, what you studied, what other work you did and how much yarn you spun.
('57', 354, 3, 11, 607586) I hope you know that we should wear khadi even at home.

('57', 354, 7, 14, 607713) 601. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('57', 354, 8, 15, 607744) November 7, 1932
('57', 354, 9, 16, 607761) NARANDAS, I got the mail from you yesterday, the day of the week on which I usually get it.
('57', 354, 9, 17, 607853) I send with this a letter from Vithal.
('57', 354, 9, 18, 607892) I have replied to him and told him that he should trust you and forget Liladhar.
('57', 354, 9, 19, 607973) If his sense of devotion to his father draws him towards Liladhar, he may join him and find out some means of earning.
('57', 354, 9, 20, 608092) He should not divide his interest between the Ashram and his father.
('57', 354, 9, 21, 608161) If you think you should reply to anything in his letter, you may do so.
('57', 354, 9, 22, 608233) I had a letter from Jethalal too.
('57', 354, 9, 23, 608267) He does admit his mistake.
('57', 354, 9, 24, 608294) But he thinks it was unjust to ask him to leave.
('57', 354, 9, 25, 608343) I see no trace of repentance on his part.
('57', 354, 9, 26, 608385) I have written to him a rather strong letter and told him that, as long as he does not feel sincere repentance, I would not advise him to return to the Ashram.
('57', 354, 9, 27, 608545) But I have also said that, if he can satisfy you and if you wished to take him back, I would not oppose you either.
('57', 354, 9, 28, 608661) I did not wish to waste your time by sending his letter to you, and so tore it up.
('57', 354, 9, 29, 608744) Kanti’s letter was painful to read.
('57', 354, 9, 30, 608780) His body seems to have
('57', 355, 0, 1, 608803) 356 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 355, 1, 2, 608845) become very weak.
('57', 355, 1, 3, 608863) I have, therefore, sent him a wire today and advised him to go to Rajkot.
('57', 355, 1, 4, 608937) I have advised in the same wire that Prema also should get herself operated upon.
('57', 355, 1, 5, 609019) Remember one rule of mine.
('57', 355, 1, 6, 609046) Anybody who gets fever should be given nothing to eat except fruit.
('57', 355, 1, 7, 609114) If it is necessary that he should be given some nourishing food, he should be given milk only.
('57', 355, 1, 8, 609209) If this rule is not followed and if the fever afterwards turns out to be typhoid, the consequences can be dangerous.
('57', 355, 1, 9, 609326) I also repeat one rule which I have mentioned concerning the experiments in food which are going on.
('57', 355, 1, 10, 609427) Anybody who finds that a certain item upsets him, may stop eating it for a day or two, and not ask for anything in its place.
('57', 355, 1, 11, 609553) If this is done, most probably the thing will agree with him afterwards.
('57', 355, 1, 12, 609626) I am sure you must have got Madan’s book now.

('57', 356, 1, 2, 610712) 603. LETTER TO RAMDAS GANDHI
('57', 356, 2, 3, 610741) November 7, 1932 I am replying to your letter today.
('57', 356, 2, 4, 610794) I had wanted to reply to it much earlier, but while searching for verses [from the Gita] as desired by you, I thought that it would be better if I selected at one time all such verses which you could follow in life without difficulty.
('57', 356, 2, 5, 611029) I could do that today, and send with this the verses which I have selected.
('57', 356, 2, 6, 611105) I have mentioned the chapter and number of the verse in each case, so that you can also look up the Gita and see where the verse occurs.
('57', 356, 2, 7, 611242) You will see that all the verses appeal directly to the heart and are easy even for children to understand, and also that the Lord has assured not once but several times that He himself will awaken knowledge in the man who cultivates bhakti for Him and will provide his needs.
('57', 356, 2, 8, 611519) Bhakti means selfless service of every living creature, in all of whom dwells the Lord.
('57', 356, 2, 9, 611607) This includes repetition of Ramanama for one’s own peace of mind.
('57', 356, 2, 10, 611673) Moreover, you will see that even the verses selected from Chapter VI contain what I wish to teach you just now.
('57', 356, 2, 11, 611785) The verses from Chapter XI are the sublimest part of Arjuna’s sublime praise of the Lord.
('57', 356, 2, 12, 611875) And the last verse of Chapter XVIII explains the reward of studying the Gita and of an earnest effort to put its teaching into practice.
('57', 356, 2, 13, 612012) That is, where there is Shri Krishna, who stands for perfect knowledge, and Arjuna, who stands for action informed with knowledge, everything else will follow.
('57', 356, 2, 14, 612172) If you meditate over these verses, you will see that one must never worry.
('57', 356, 2, 15, 612247) A student of the Gita ought not to worry any time.
('57', 356, 2, 16, 612298) We are enjoined to offer up everything as sacrifice to the Lord.
('57', 356, 2, 17, 612363) Everything means everything without exception.
('57', 356, 2, 18, 612410) Do you think anybody who does that would carry a load of worries in his head?
('57', 356, 2, 19, 612488) You must have discovered by now whether your disturbed digestion is the result of too much thinking and excessive worry, or whether it indicates the necessity of some change in your food.
('57', 356, 2, 20, 612676) Do not be overambitious, either, in your reading and study.
('57', 356, 2, 21, 612736) The resol utions which you have formed in your mind will now go on slowly maturing.
('57', 356, 2, 22, 612820) You will know your strength when you are released.
('57', 356, 2, 23, 612871) Why should you worry now whether or not you will really know it?
('57', 356, 2, 24, 612936) There is no need at all to do so.
('57', 356, 2, 25, 612970) You will find the meanings of the verses in the Anasaktiyoga, and in any case Surendra is there with you.
('57', 356, 2, 26, 613076) Youmay, on your own or on the advice of Surendra or others like him, add some more to the verses which I have selected.
('57', 356, 2, 27, 613196) I had made a
('57', 357, 0, 1, 613209) 358 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 357, 1, 2, 613251) note of the verses which I wished to select.
('57', 357, 1, 3, 613296) While doing so in my copy of the Gita.
('57', 357, 1, 4, 613335) I gave them the title“Ramdas Gita”.
('57', 357, 1, 5, 613371) Let us see how much they help you.
('57', 357, 1, 6, 613406) I will now tell you about something which will amuse you.
('57', 357, 1, 7, 613464) Nimu asked me to suggest a name for your son.
('57', 357, 1, 8, 613510) Sarita has already christened him Kahanji.
('57', 357, 1, 9, 613553) I suggested Kahandas, thinking that it would go well with your name and would also satisfy Sarita’s wish.
('57', 357, 1, 10, 613659) But I should have known that Nimu would not like a name ending with das.
('57', 357, 1, 11, 613732) She disapproved of Kahandas and asked me to suggest another name, but said that if you approved of Kahandas, she also would accept it.
('57', 357, 1, 12, 613867) Vasumati, claiming her right, as aunt, to name the child, wrote to me and said that I, being an old man, would naturally suggest a name which an old man would like, but that she would not approve of any such name.
('57', 357, 1, 13, 614081) She, therefore, asked for a name which would please people in this twentieth century.
('57', 357, 1, 14, 614167) I have replied to her and told her that it was the exclusive right of an aunt to name a baby and that, therefore, she might give the child any name she liked.
('57', 357, 1, 15, 614326) I have suggested a few names for her approval such as Fakkadlal, Chhogalashankh, Lakhtarlal, Bardolikar and Sabarmatiwala.
('57', 357, 1, 16, 614449) 1 In my letter to Nimu, I have suggested Nirmallal, and also told her that, if she did not like the name Kahandas, she was hardly likely to be pleased with the name Ramdas either.
('57', 357, 1, 17, 614629) I have, therefore, asked her to suggest a new name for you too.
('57', 357, 1, 18, 614693) I was about to suggest one but checked myself.
('57', 357, 1, 19, 614740) She should call you Nirmalkant.
('57', 357, 1, 20, 614772) But we would then be going back to the age of the Ramayana, instead of living in the twentieth century, for in that age husbands were known by the names of the wives.
('57', 357, 1, 21, 614939) Ramachandra was called Sitapati, Krishna was called Lakshmikant and Mahadev was called Parvatipati.
('57', 357, 1, 22, 615039) We find a number of such instances.
('57', 357, 1, 23, 615075) If you wish to throw any light on this profound subject, you are welcome to do so.
('57', 357, 1, 24, 615158) You ask how I cultivated non attachment.
('57', 357, 1, 25, 615199) The thing was very easy for me since everything I did was spontaneous, that is, arose naturally from my devotion to truth.
('57', 357, 1, 26, 615322) If one is filled with a desire to serve the whole world, one can easily cultivate non attachment.
('57', 357, 1, 27, 615420) If I had chosen to serve only our family, I would certainly have been filled with ignorant love and even developed attachment.
('57', 357, 1, 28, 615547) I would also have suffered because of illnesses and deaths.
('57', 357, 1, 29, 615607) But suffering runs away from you if you dedicate yourself to the service of the countless
('57', 357, 2, 30, 615697) 1 All these are fanciful and extremely funny names.
('57', 358, 0, 1, 615749) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 359
('57', 358, 1, 2, 615799) millions.
('57', 358, 1, 3, 615809) Over whose illness would you worry and over whose death would you grieve?
('57', 358, 1, 4, 615883) It would be almost impossible to do either.
('57', 358, 1, 5, 615927) However, non attachment does not mean insensitivity, or cruelty, for after all one does wish to serve the people, and, therefore, compassion becomes stronger instead of becoming weaker, and one’s efficiency and concentration in work also increases.
('57', 358, 1, 6, 616176) All these are signs of non attachment.
('57', 358, 1, 7, 616215) Moreover, the beauty of the thing lies in the fact that by serving the world, one does not cease to serve one’s family, for service of the family is included in service of the world.
('57', 358, 1, 8, 616398) I am perfectly sure in my mind that I have served Ba, you and your brothers and other members of the family no whit less than I could have done otherwise.
('57', 358, 1, 9, 616553) The service was pure because attachment was replaced by equality of mind.
('57', 358, 1, 10, 616627) I am sure that none of you has lost anything in consequence and that I myself have gained much.
('57', 358, 1, 11, 616723) Thus I found non attachment easy to cultivate.
('57', 358, 1, 12, 616770) The word anasakti occurred to me when, after I had finished the translation of the Gita, Kaka asked me to suggest a title.
('57', 358, 1, 13, 616893) It is not that I started cultivating non attachment after realizing that, if one wished to serve the whole world, one could do so only with non attachment.
('57', 358, 1, 14, 617049) I understood only gradually that I was acting without attachment.
('57', 358, 1, 15, 617115) Those around me saw that before I did.
('57', 358, 1, 16, 617154) When I returned to India, people started describing me as a karmayogi.
('57', 358, 1, 17, 617225) I used to read and study the Gita even in South Africa.
('57', 358, 1, 18, 617281) But I had not then thought about the meaning of karmayogi.
('57', 358, 1, 19, 617340) But other people saw all that in my life, and afterwards I also felt that their description had truth in it.
('57', 358, 1, 20, 617449) All cannot have such good fortune.
('57', 358, 1, 21, 617484) I had it because I think I have always loved truth right from my childhood.
('57', 358, 1, 22, 617560) But you need not go into these deep waters just now.
('57', 358, 1, 23, 617613) At present you should try to cultivate non attachment without attachment even to that aim.
('57', 358, 1, 24, 617704) That is, you should do with a light and happy heart any service for which you get an opportunity and read and study at the same time whatever you can manage.
('57', 358, 1, 25, 617862) You need not worry either for Nimu or for the children.
('57', 358, 1, 26, 617918) You will now see, with the new eyes which “Ramdas Gita”will give you, that God is there to worry for them and for you.
('57', 358, 1, 27, 618037) You should not only believe this with your reason, but have faith in it and live accordingly.
('57', 358, 1, 28, 618131) You will then be happy and learn everything you wish to.
('57', 358, 1, 29, 618188) Fix firmly in your mind the Lord’s assurance in Chapter IX, that even the most sinful man will have become a good man if he cultivates single minded bhakti for Him.
('57', 358, 1, 30, 618353) The entire world might perish, but anassurance by the Lord never proves false.
('57', 358, 1, 31, 618432) I think I have written enough.

('57', 360, 6, 15, 620652) 607. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS 1
('57', 360, 7, 16, 620682) November 7, 1932
('57', 360, 8, 17, 620699) In a special interview given to the Associated Press inside the Yeravda Jail Mr. Gandhi emphasized that South India has become the storm centre and explained the reasons why the Guruvayur question was worth the price he had expressed his determination to pay.
('57', 360, 9, 18, 620959) Replying to preliminary enquires he said, for the present his campaign would be confined to the issue of a statement but he was in correspondence with the Birla Committee and would meet them at the end of the month when other plans would be decided.
('57', 360, 10, 19, 621209) Asked about Dr. Ambedkar’s declaration that the temple entry was not worth risking his life, Mr. Gandhi said : I do not take the same light view that Dr. Ambedkar does of the temple entry question.
('57', 360, 10, 20, 621407) In my opinion it is a deciding test as to whether the orthodox Hindu mind has responded to the call of time or not and whether it is prepared to purge Hinduism of the blackmark of untouchability.
('57', 360, 10, 21, 621603) Nothing in my opinion will strike the imagination of the Hindu mass mind including Harijans as throwing open all public
('57', 360, 11, 22, 621723) 1 The interview took place in the Superintendent’s office.
('57', 360, 11, 23, 621782) Also present in the room were Mahadev Desai, Pyarelal and P. Kodandarao of the Servants of India Society.
('57', 361, 0, 1, 621888) 362 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 361, 1, 2, 621930) temples to them precisely on the same terms as caste Hindus.
('57', 361, 1, 3, 621991) I can understand Dr. Ambedkar’s comparative indifference, but I am not thinking of a few cultured men belonging to the depressed classes, but I am thinking of the uncultured, dumb many.
('57', 361, 1, 4, 622177) After all Hindu temples play a most important part in the life of the masses and I who have been trying all my life to identify myself with the most illiterate and downtrodden cannot be satisfied until all temples are open to outcastes of Hindu humanity.
('57', 361, 1, 5, 622432) This, however, does not mean that I belittle in any shape or form other disabilities under which they are labouring.
('57', 361, 1, 6, 622549) I feel about them just as keenly as Dr. Ambedkar.
('57', 361, 1, 7, 622599) Only I feel the evil is so deep rooted that one must not make the choice between different disabilities, but must tackle them all at once.
('57', 361, 1, 8, 622738) That is the burden of my corresp ondence with the Anti untouchability League also.
('57', 361, 1, 9, 622821) The Guruvayur temple has come in my way by accident and I have no option left to me.
('57', 361, 1, 10, 622906) After all, Mr. Kelappan is in my opinion one of the noblest of India’s silent servants.
('57', 361, 1, 11, 622994) A distinguished public career was open to him any day.
('57', 361, 1, 12, 623049) He is a well known worker of Malabar but he deliberately threw in his lot with unapproachables and invisibles.
('57', 361, 1, 13, 623160) I had the pleasure and honour of working with him at the time of the Vykom Satyagraha 1. Long before that time and ever since he has been devoting himself to the uplift of suppressed humanity.
('57', 361, 1, 14, 623353) As the public know, after long waiting he made a fixed determination to give up his life in an attempt to have the Guruvayur temple opened to Harijans.
('57', 361, 1, 15, 623505) I discovered, however, a flaw in his fast and I immediately pointed it out to him and although he believed that victory was within sight, he nobly responded and let it slip from his hands; he retraced his steps and suspended his fast.
('57', 361, 1, 16, 623740) When I telegraphed to him 2 I bound myself to fast with him if resumption became necessary on the termination of three months’ notice he gave.
('57', 361, 1, 17, 623883) I should be an unworthy servant of India and an unworthy comrade if I now flinched and abandoned Kelappan to his fate, but there is something more than the life of a comrade or my own personal honour.
('57', 361, 1, 18, 624084) Everyone recognizes that the depressed classes question has to be solved now or never, not at any rate within the present generation or several generations to come.
('57', 361, 1, 19, 624249) There are thousands of men and women like me who cling to
('57', 361, 2, 20, 624307) 1 This took place in March April 1925 and was aimed at having certain roads thrown open to untouchables from which they had been barred.
('57', 361, 2, 21, 624444) 2 Vide “Telegram to K. Kelappan”, 29 9 1932.
('57', 362, 0, 1, 624489) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 363
('57', 362, 1, 2, 624539) Hinduism, because they believe that there is in it the amplest scope for mental, moral and spiritual expansion.
('57', 362, 1, 3, 624651) This bar sinister put upon nearly sixty million human beings is a standing demonstration against that claim.
('57', 362, 1, 4, 624760) Men like me feel that untouchability is no integral part of Hinduism.
('57', 362, 1, 5, 624830) It is an excrescence, but if it is found to be otherwise, and if the Hindu mass mind really hugs untouchability, reformers like me have no other option but to sacrifice ourselves on the altar of our convictions.
('57', 362, 1, 6, 625042) I have patiently and silently listened to the taunt that such a fast is tantamount to suicide and I don’t believe it to be such.
('57', 362, 1, 7, 625171) On the contrary for men with deep religious convictions there is no other outlet for the soul than this final sacrifice when every other effort seems perfectly hopeless.
('57', 362, 1, 8, 625341) This campaign therefore in my opinion is an acid test of what I have claimed for Hinduism and I can only repeat what I said at the Round Table Conference that Hinduism dies if untouchability lives and untouchability has to die if Hinduism is to live and today I make bold to say that there are hundreds if not thousands of Indian men and women who would lay down their lives even as Kelappan and I propose to do to vindicate the claim for Hinduism that it is not a narrow creed or dogma, but a living faith, designed to satisfy the most exacting conscience of the deepest thinker and the godliest person.
('57', 362, 1, 9, 625946) The Bombay Chronicle, 8 11 1932

('57', 365, 1, 2, 629727) 612. LETTER TO JAMNALAL BAJAJ
('57', 365, 2, 3, 629757) November 8, 1932
('57', 365, 3, 4, 629774) JAMNALAL, Your letter was delivered to me just now.
('57', 365, 3, 5, 629826) It was immediately read out to me and I am now dictating this reply.
('57', 365, 3, 6, 629895) May you have, on your birthday, all the blessings you desire, basketfuls of them.
('57', 365, 3, 7, 629977) Why should we fear death, which comes to all sooner or later—to the great and the humble, to the white and the black, to human beings and other creatures?
('57', 365, 3, 8, 630132) Why grieve over it either?
('57', 365, 3, 9, 630159) I often feel that death must be a less painful event than birth.
('57', 365, 3, 10, 630224) I leave aside the pain which the baby suffers in the mother’s womb before birth.
('57', 365, 3, 11, 630305) But all of us know the suffering in this world which commences from the moment of birth.
('57', 365, 3, 12, 630394) Consider the helplessness of the baby at the moment of birth—every baby as helpless as any other.
('57', 365, 3, 13, 630492) On the other hand, if our life has been pure we shall have no such experience at the moment of death.
('57', 365, 3, 14, 630594) A baby does not seek knowledge, nor can it have any.
('57', 365, 3, 15, 630647) At the time of death, on the other hand, it is not only possible for one to be in a state of union with the Brahman but we actually know that many persons die in such a state.
('57', 365, 3, 16, 630823) Birth always means entering a world of suffering, whereas death can be complete deliverance from suffering.
('57', 365, 3, 17, 630931) We can thus think from many points of view about the beauty and the benefits of death, and can also meet our death in that spirit.
('57', 365, 3, 18, 631062) I bless you that your death may be of this type.
('57', 365, 3, 19, 631111) This wish includes everything else which is for your good.
('57', 365, 3, 20, 631170) The two friends join me in wishing this.
('57', 365, 3, 21, 631211) Even after knowing all the facts about your health, I adhere to the view which I have expressed.
('57', 365, 3, 22, 631308) If you are permitted to obtain your food at your own expense, I see nothing wrong in your doing so.
('57', 365, 3, 23, 631408) We should regard our body as a trust, and it is our duty as its trustee to take care of it to the best of our ability.
('57', 365, 3, 24, 631527) You should not ask for or accept even a grain of jaggery to gratify your palate, but I see nothing wrong in your trying and getting even the costliest variety of grapes if you need them as medicine and if they can be had.
('57', 365, 3, 25, 631749) You need not, therefore, feel unhappy if you have to eat such food.
('57', 365, 3, 26, 631817) If we can, we should also help others who may be placed in similar circumstances to secure such food.
('57', 365, 3, 27, 631919) In my view you don’t require all the wheat that is supplied to you.
('57', 365, 3, 28, 631987) I also think it desirable for you to banish jaggery altogether from your food.
('57', 365, 3, 29, 632066) Your body does not require it at all.
('57', 365, 3, 30, 632104) It is better to take innocent honey instead.
('57', 365, 3, 31, 632149) Mixing any form of sugar in milk affects its digestibility.
('57', 365, 3, 32, 632209) It would be better to increase the quantity of milk instead.
('57', 365, 3, 33, 632270) You are doing right in eating butter and not olive oil.
('57', 365, 3, 34, 632326) The olive oil available in India is not always pure, and of course it cannot be fresh.
('57', 365, 3, 35, 632413) Moreover, olive oil does not contain the vitamins
('57', 366, 0, 1, 632463) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 367
('57', 366, 1, 2, 632513) which butter does.
('57', 366, 1, 3, 632532) The vegetables which you eat should always be green vegetables.
('57', 366, 1, 4, 632596) Potatoes and similar vegetables are practically a substitute for rotli.
('57', 366, 1, 5, 632668) They contain starch.
('57', 366, 1, 6, 632689) You require very little starch, and whatever little you require you will get from wheat.
('57', 366, 1, 7, 632778) You should not eat pulses in any circumstances.
('57', 366, 1, 8, 632826) If you eat a sufficient quantity of butter, two pounds of milk will be enough for you.
('57', 366, 1, 9, 632913) Whether you should increase or diminish their quantity will depend upon your weight at the time.
('57', 366, 1, 10, 633010) You should go on increasing the quantity of either or both to as much as you can digest, till your weight becomes steady.
('57', 366, 1, 11, 633132) Among the green vegetables, gourd, pumpkin, the different kinds of edible leaves, cabbage, cauliflower, tender bean pods and brinjal are considered good.
('57', 366, 1, 12, 633286) The wheat flour should be whole.
('57', 366, 1, 13, 633319) If the wheat has been properly cleaned before it is ground, no portion of the flour should be thrown away.
('57', 366, 1, 14, 633426) Among fruits, grapes, mosambis, oranges, pomegranates, apples and pineapple are beneficial for health.
('57', 366, 1, 15, 633529) Some experiments being made in America indicate that a meal should not consist of a variety of articles.
('57', 366, 1, 16, 633634) Fruit has the most nourishing value if it is eaten alone, and the best practice is to eat it when the stomach is empty.
('57', 366, 1, 17, 633754) There is even a saying in English to the effect that fruit in the morning is gold and in the afternoon silver.
('57', 366, 1, 18, 633865) Our first meal, therefore, should consist only of fruit, though there would be no harm if it is preceded by a glass of warm water the first thing in the morning.
('57', 366, 1, 19, 634027) If you can get permission to live all the twenty four hours of the day in open air, it would be worth while to secure it.
('57', 366, 1, 20, 634149) It would help you if you can slowly do breathing exercises in open air.
('57', 366, 1, 21, 634221) You need not at all be afraid of the cold at night.
('57', 366, 1, 22, 634273) It will have no harmful effect on your health if you have properly covered yourself up to the neck and wound a piece of cloth over the head so as to keep the ears covered.
('57', 366, 1, 23, 634445) It is essential that the lungs should be supplied with the purest air the whole day and night.
('57', 366, 1, 24, 634540) You should expose your body to the sun in the morning for as long as you can bear.
('57', 366, 1, 25, 634623) Discuss all these suggestions with Dr. Contractor and then do what seems best to you.
('57', 366, 1, 26, 634709) I hope Madhavji is happy and comfortable in every way.
('57', 366, 1, 27, 634764) Give my blessings and regards of all three of us to the co workers who are with you in the jail.
('57', 366, 1, 28, 634861) Probably you know what is going on here in regard to untouchability.
('57', 366, 1, 29, 634930) You can send any suggestions which occur to you.
('57', 366, 1, 30, 634979) You will be permitted by the authorities there to do so.
('57', 366, 2, 31, 635036) Blessings from BAPU
('57', 366, 3, 32, 635056) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 2903

('57', 367, 10, 23, 636241) 615. A LETTER
('57', 367, 11, 24, 636255) November 8, 1932 A serious obstacle in the way of those treading the path of truth is the difficulty of deciding what to accept as Shastras.
('57', 367, 11, 25, 636396) What is a man of simple faith to do when he comes across a plethora of books written in Sanskrit and passing for smritis and also utterances that
('57', 368, 0, 1, 636542) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 369
('57', 368, 1, 2, 636592) contradict them?
('57', 368, 1, 3, 636609) For this reason I have chosen for myself the most universal doctrine of Hinduism, namely, that any conduct that is contrary to truth and ahimsa is to be eschewed and any book that violates these principles is not a Shastra.
('57', 368, 1, 4, 636833) [From Hindi]
('57', 368, 2, 5, 636846) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, p.
('57', 368, 3, 6, 636879) 616. STATEMENT ON UNTOUCHABILITY—IV
('57', 368, 4, 7, 636915) November 9, 1932 A correspondent writes as follows : 1
('57', 368, 5, 8, 636970) I consider your last fast to have been coercion of the worst type.
('57', 368, 5, 9, 637037) I do not want to conceal from you my feeling about Yeravda Pact.
('57', 368, 5, 10, 637102) I know my view is shared by public men who, because of their respect for your personality and because of your detention in the Yeravda Prison, did not like to say anything in public against your action in bringing about the Pact.
('57', 368, 5, 11, 637332) I consider the Pact to be a public misfortune which would never have been brought about but for your unfortunate fast.
('57', 368, 5, 12, 637451) I know of a very esteemed friend of yours who said that if the refusal had not meant your certain death he would never have given his consent to the Pact.
('57', 368, 5, 13, 637606) There is a large number of thinking Hindus who regret having had to accept the Pact, as they think that there would have been no necessity for it if you had only accepted in London what you have done now.
('57', 368, 6, 14, 637811) In a statement you have said, “It was against these millions that my fast wass undertaken.” I take it that was your intention but in actual result it was not these millions but others who had no course left open but to suspend their judgment and feeling in the matter and agree to terms to which nothing in the world would have made them agree, if their refusal had not meant losing your valued life.
('57', 368, 6, 15, 638212) It was their spontaneous love that brought about the transformation inside of five days and brought into being the Yeravda Pact.
('57', 368, 6, 16, 638341) If this is a correct statement of facts, will it not be more correct to say that it was only the fear of your death by starvation which brought about the Pact?
('57', 368, 6, 17, 638501) Remembering the circumstances under which it was brought about I think you will recognize that much need not be made of it; if the Pact is not carried out in its fullness, much less would there be any justification for you to embark on a second fast.
('57', 368, 7, 18, 638752) It gives me no pleasure to have to criticize a public man of your eminence, but the occasion is such that to keep quiet will not be quite honest.
('57', 368, 8, 19, 638898) 1 The correspondent was Radhakant Malaviya; vide p.
('57', 368, 8, 20, 638950) 380, and “Letter to C. Y. Chintamani”, 11 11 1932.
('57', 369, 0, 1, 639001) 370 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 369, 1, 2, 639043) Your assumption that the masses whom you have addressed on the question of untouchability have accepted your views on that question, simply because they did not publicly oppose your views, is not correct.
('57', 369, 1, 3, 639248) Because of their respect for your great personality and because of your political leadership they would hear in silence and, however much they may be opposed to your views, as I know many of them are, at least in Northern India, they would still consider it their duty to give you a respectful hearing.
('57', 369, 1, 4, 639551) As you are aware, these people are not very vocal and they do not go out of their way to oppose the views of those who differ from them, and specially if the views are expressed by one of your eminence.
('57', 369, 1, 5, 639754) I have removed from the letter unnecessary paragraphs and names of public men referred to by the correspondent.
('57', 369, 1, 6, 639866) It would be a matter of great grief to me if public men the correspondent mentions really suppressed their own opinions and accepted proposals which but for the threat of my death they would never have endorsed.
('57', 369, 1, 7, 640078) If they acted as the correspondent suggests, they rendered a great disservice to the country and failed to appreciate the purely religious character of the fast.
('57', 369, 1, 8, 640240) In public life one has often to perform the painful duty of sacrificing friends for the sake of truth or public weal.
('57', 369, 1, 9, 640358) And what was there in the Pact that these friends considered it to be highly objectionable?
('57', 369, 1, 10, 640450) Surely not reservation of seats; not joint electorate, nor the method of nomination of candidates by primary election, as it has been called.
('57', 369, 1, 11, 640592) They could not object to the resolution restoring to Harijans social and religious rights, of which they have cruelly remained dispossessed for ages.
('57', 369, 1, 12, 640742) The only thing remaining is the number of seats allotted to them, but more than that was given to them by the Rajah Moonje Pact, and as I have already said in a previous statement, caste Hindus could never give Harijans too many seats, if they really believed them to be their own kith and kin, whom they had hitherto kept under their heels.
('57', 369, 1, 13, 641084) Sorry indeed is the outlook for them if what the Pact has given them is regarded as an undeserved concession wrung from reluctant caste Hindus by my fast.
('57', 369, 1, 14, 641239) Therefore, if the information given by my correspondent turns but to be true, I would hold my fast to be doubly justified.
('57', 369, 1, 15, 641362) I should not care to live as a member of a society which is chary even of doing a small and tardy measure of justice to its outcastes, who are so through no fault of their own, and my fast was trebly justified if the further statement made by my correspondent is true that millions of whom I have been writing as a matter of fact never endorsed my
('57', 370, 0, 1, 641710) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 371
('57', 370, 1, 2, 641760) vehement condemnation of untouchability and that they remained silent or even signified approval purely out of their respect for my “great personality” or my “political leadership”.
('57', 370, 1, 3, 641942) Life in the midst of such falsity would be a burden to me.
('57', 370, 1, 4, 642001) The sooner public men and people realize the necessity of resisting and asserting themselves even against so called Mahatmas like myself, the better it would be for themselves, the country and for men like me.
('57', 370, 1, 5, 642211) I should gladly fast even to have such a cleansing of the atmosphere.
('57', 370, 1, 6, 642281) My correspondent’s is a timely contribution to the movement.
('57', 370, 1, 7, 642342) Those who are in it should know the implications both of the movement and the prospective fast.
('57', 370, 1, 8, 642438) I can only repeat with all the emphasis at my command that my fast is not intended to coerce anyone to act against what he may consider to be the best interests of society or country.
('57', 370, 1, 9, 642622) My fast is not against persons whom I can name or number.
('57', 370, 1, 10, 642680) It is intended imperceptibly and unconsciously to affect and agitate the millions whom I have in mind and between whom and me, I believe, an indissoluble bond exists.
('57', 370, 1, 11, 642847) How such fasts work I do know from personal experience gained more than once.
('57', 370, 1, 12, 642925) My correspondent suggests that “there would have been no necessity for the Pact if I had only accepted in London what I have done now”.
('57', 370, 1, 13, 643061) I must not rake up the past beyond saying that I could not have done in London what it was possible to do in India.
('57', 370, 1, 14, 643177) The correspondent although he was in London at the time simply does not know all the facts that are in my possession.
('57', 370, 1, 15, 643295) Let not the public, however, run away with the idea that I have many letters protesting against the Pact.
('57', 370, 1, 16, 643401) So far as I can remember, this is the only letter of its kind.
('57', 370, 1, 17, 643464) There are two or three letters complaining of coercion but none suggesting that, therefore, anything was given to Harijans that was not their due, and against this one letter I have hundreds of letters and telegrams warmly approving of the fast itself and the Pact.
('57', 370, 1, 18, 643730) My closest associates both here and in the West with one or two exceptions have endorsed it and themselves felt its spiritual effect.
('57', 370, 1, 19, 643864) But according to my wont and in order to keep the cause I espouse free from any harm, I publish letters containing hostile criticism, especially when it comes from men whom I know to be guided by friendly motives, as my correpondent undoubtedly is.
('57', 370, 1, 20, 644113) As I was handing in this statement, I received a wire from the ever vigilant secretary of the All India Anti Untouchability League, pointing out that the total population of untouchables in India is not

('57', 372, 1, 2, 645929) constipated is to avoid protein foods, i.e., bread and also milk, and take green vegetables cooked alternately with fruit.
('57', 372, 1, 3, 646052) That was how I built up my body after the fast.
('57', 372, 1, 4, 646100) And latterly Vallabhbhai has been correcting his constipation, heaviness and cough by such non nutritious fat free and starch free food.
('57', 372, 1, 5, 646237) It sustains one’s weight fairly well.
('57', 372, 1, 6, 646275) Dried fruit may be taken of course.
('57', 372, 1, 7, 646311) It may be wise not to mix dried fruit with fresh.
('57', 372, 1, 8, 646361) Thus one may take four meals, one consisting of say pomegranate and musambis, the other of vegetables, e.g., dudhi and tomatoes, third of dried figs or dates or prunes soaked in water over night and warmed or cold, the fourth may consist of the same vegetable or pumpkin and lemons squeezed on it or tomatoes repeated or it may consist of salad made of lettuce and tomatoes or grated carrots.
('57', 372, 1, 9, 646754) Such food repeated for a few days should remove obstinate constipation.
('57', 372, 1, 10, 646826) Sometimes mere omission of bread or milk may answer.

('57', 373, 1, 2, 648162) 619. LETTER TO MOTILAL ROY
('57', 373, 2, 3, 648189) November 9, 1932
('57', 373, 3, 4, 648206) DEAR MOTIBABU, Just now I must dictate my letters.
('57', 373, 3, 5, 648257) Your book has been received.
('57', 373, 3, 6, 648286) Mahadev knows Bengali quite well.
('57', 373, 3, 7, 648320) The book was received today.
('57', 373, 3, 8, 648349) He has already commenced reading it and fallen in love with it.
('57', 373, 3, 9, 648413) He will read to me extracts from it as soon as possible.
('57', 373, 3, 10, 648470) Your question about varnashrama you will find somewhat answered in one of the statements issued to the Press.
('57', 373, 3, 11, 648580) In my letter to Sureshbabu I never said that varnashrama was in any shape or form an evil, but I did say that caste was a social evil and had to go some day or other.
('57', 373, 3, 12, 648747) I draw a sharp distinction between varna and caste.
('57', 373, 3, 13, 648799) All I have written before on this subject I hold by with perhaps this exception: I have vaguely expressed in my previous writings what I have come to see now clearly, namely, that the four varnas are no longer in actual working order, even as the four Ashrams are not.
('57', 373, 3, 14, 649068) Hence at the present moment there is only one varna in existence.
('57', 373, 3, 15, 649134) We are all Shudras and if we can bring ourselves to believe this, the merger of the Harijans in Savarana Hindus becomes incredibly simple and in course of time, we might be able to reconstruct the old varnas.
('57', 373, 3, 16, 649343) I also seem to see more clearly than before that the law our ancestors discovered was not that the varnas were four and were always to remain four, but that everyone had to follow his own varna which is most nearly expressed by the word profession in English.
('57', 373, 3, 17, 649603) It was no part of varnadharma to regulate dining or marrying, varna determined the profession.
('57', 373, 3, 18, 649698) Custom naturally grew up of people of the same varna restricting marriage to that varna.
('57', 373, 3, 19, 649787) Restriction on inter dining was of a much later growth, but marrying outside one’s varna did not entail forfeiture of the varna.
('57', 373, 3, 20, 649916) I hope to develop my idea of varnadharma in the statements I am issuing, but I think I have said sufficient in my letter to enable you to understand my position.
('57', 373, 3, 21, 650078) Love to you all of the Sangha.
('57', 373, 4, 22, 650109) M. K. GANDHI
('57', 373, 5, 23, 650122) From a photostat: G.N. 11039
