('57', 376, 7, 11, 653519) 625. LETTER TO BHUDEB MUKERJI 3
('57', 376, 8, 12, 653551) Rewritten November 10, 1932
('57', 376, 9, 13, 653579) DEAR FRIEND, Though you have absolved me from having to write to you in reply to your letter, I must not avail myself of your kindness.
('57', 376, 9, 14, 653715) You have evidently ascribed to the workers against untouchability much more than they have themselves claimed.
('57', 376, 9, 15, 653826) No one has ever thought of destroying varnashrama dharma.
('57', 376, 9, 16, 653884) And you are wholly wrong in thinking that the movement is carried on by or is confined to the English speaking people.
('57', 376, 9, 17, 654003) It is a mass movement in which even utterly illiterate men and women are taking part with religious zeal, and are you sure that varnadharma and Ashrama dharma are being observed to any appreciable degree by even those who regard themselves as orthodox?
('57', 376, 9, 18, 654256) Again I do not know what you wish to convey by the expression “levelling”, and you write of forcible levelling.
('57', 376, 9, 19, 654368) I do not know that anybody has used force to level down anybody else, whatever the latter expression may mean.
('57', 376, 9, 20, 654479) And you are surely libelling the untouchables when you ascribe to them vices from which the touchables, you evidently claim, are free.
('57', 376, 9, 21, 654614) Not all the untouchables trade in toddy or liquor dealing, and what is worse drinking or selling intoxicating liquors?
('57', 376, 9, 22, 654733) Have you any personal experience of the private
('57', 376, 10, 23, 654781) 1 Illegible in the source 2 ibid 3 An ex lecturer of Calcutta University; he had written to Gandhiji on October 30 (S.N. 18596).
('57', 377, 0, 1, 654910) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 377, 1, 2, 654952) life of untouchables?
('57', 377, 1, 3, 654974) Do you consider them to be guilty of the hideous immorality of the lives of many touchables who disgrace themselves and Hinduism?
('57', 377, 1, 4, 655104) And who is responsible for whatever is bad about untouchables?
('57', 377, 1, 5, 655167) I refrain from saying more.
('57', 377, 1, 6, 655195) From your letter head I see that you are yourself a distinguished product of English learning and have obtained an upadhi for your knowledge of San khya and Vedanta.
('57', 377, 1, 7, 655361) I have never seen anything in either Sankhya or Vedanta that teaches a man to hold in contempt his fellow beings as you seem to do in almost every line of your letter.
('57', 377, 1, 8, 655529) And my grief is enhanced by my strong suspicion that you have never cared to study the lives of those unfortunate fellow Hindus whom you and I and other Hindus who have arrogated superiority for themselves have ground down to dust.
('57', 377, 1, 9, 655761) I invite you to read the signs of the times and join me in thinking that purification of Hinduism will not come through arrogance and slander of innocent people.

('57', 377, 6, 15, 656177) Students, if they will work heartily and intelligently, can do much in spite of the orthodox opposition.

('57', 378, 2, 6, 657388) 627. LETTER TO K. NATARAJAN 1
('57', 378, 3, 7, 657418) November 10, 1932 From what I can see and feel, the battle at Guruvayur is to attain all India importance and orthodoxy is to concentrate all its fire upon the temple.
('57', 378, 3, 8, 657586) I should welcome it.
('57', 378, 3, 9, 657607) It should result in much greater purification than I had expected.
('57', 378, 3, 10, 657674) But that means that all that is best in Hinduism has to consolidate itself and resist the orthodox onrush.
('57', 378, 3, 11, 657781) I am anxious therefore for you, if it is possible for you and if you feel with me, to throw yourself heart and soul into the movement.
('57', 378, 3, 12, 657916) But I observed from your writings on the last fast that you were opposed to such fasting.
('57', 378, 3, 13, 658006) I hold very strong views about it and feel that it is not only a legitimate weapon, but that for one who will not resort to violence in any shape or form it becomes obligatory under given circumstances.
('57', 378, 3, 14, 658209) And now that I am free to receive visitors in connection with this movement I would like you to see me any time next week, at, say, 1 o’clock, so that we can discuss the ethics of penitential public fasts and see whether we cannot agree.
('57', 378, 3, 15, 658447) You know me enough to feel sure that if in the course of our discussion I discover my own error I shall have no hesitation in retracing my step.

('57', 379, 3, 4, 658754) DEAR GURUDEV, You must have seen the statement I have circulated to the Press.1 I want your blessings, if I can have them, for this further effort.
('57', 379, 3, 5, 658902) I do not know whether you feel that this effort is, if possible, purer than before.
('57', 379, 3, 6, 658986) The last fast had a political tinge about it and superficial critics were able to say that it was aimed at the British Government.
('57', 379, 3, 7, 659117) This time if the ordeal has to come, it will not be possible to give any political colour to it.
('57', 379, 3, 8, 659214) You will of course recall that the last fast was broken on the clearest possible notice that I might have to resume it if there was any breach of faith by the so called caste Hindus.
('57', 379, 3, 9, 659397) The prospective fast about Guruvayur temple is absolutely a point of honour.
('57', 379, 3, 10, 659474) It is being made by the orthodox section the centre of attack and is being given an all India significance.
('57', 379, 3, 11, 659582) I rather like it.
('57', 379, 3, 12, 659600) But it makes it all the more necessary for the liberalizing influences to be collected together and set in motion in order to overthrow the monster of untouchability.
('57', 379, 3, 13, 659767) I want your whole hearted co opeartion if you feel as I do.

('57', 379, 7, 19, 659990) November 10, 1932 I agree with most of your views about untouchability, but the reasons which you have given for refusing to join the Committee have not convinced me.
('57', 379, 7, 20, 660157) I do believe that Hindus who are known to be orthodox should join such a committee.

('57', 379, 8, 22, 660459) 1 The reference is to “Statement on Untouchability I”; Vide “Statement on Untouchability”, 4 11 1932. 2 Presumably Ambalal Sarabhai

('57', 380, 1, 2, 660641) Hindus, those who have a religious disposition and want religious reforms as well must join the Committee.
('57', 380, 1, 3, 660748) The sense of responsibility which a person feels and the obligation which he accepts in joining a body, he would not feel or accept if he did not join it, however much he tried.
('57', 380, 1, 4, 660926) And now about the point on which we differ.
('57', 380, 1, 5, 660970) Though I admit the usefulness and necessity of meetings, processions, speeches, conferences, etc., I believe that without constructive work we shall not succeed in eradicating untouchability completely nor will large num bers of Harijans learn to hate it.
('57', 380, 1, 6, 661226) It is certainly true that such work will require an army of voluntary workers, both men and women, and much money.
('57', 380, 1, 7, 661341) If, however, you recognize the imperative necessity of the work, you should not refuse to attempt it merely out of fear that we might not get the needed money and such a large number of workers.

('57', 382, 1, 2, 663865) 633. LETTER TO ANTI UNTOUCHABILITY LEAGUE, UDIPI
('57', 382, 2, 3, 663914) November 11, 1932 I am quite clear in my mind that there is no occasion for you to start satyagraha just now.
('57', 382, 2, 4, 664024) You have to cultivate public opinion in your favour by the gentlest means.
('57', 382, 2, 5, 664099) You should see whether the temple going population is in favour of Harijans being admitted to the temple on the same terms as the other, and you should also remember that temple entry is not the only thing to be done.
('57', 382, 2, 6, 664317) You have to ascertain the condition of untouchables in your neighbourhood in every walk of life, make a scientific study and pass the results of your study on to me, alleviating at the same time such distress among the Harijans as you are capable of doing.
('57', 382, 3, 7, 664574) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, p.
('57', 382, 4, 8, 664607) 634. LETTER TO C. Y. CHINTAMANI
('57', 382, 5, 9, 664639) November 11, 1932 I have no doubt that you guessed who the author of the letter referred to in the fourth statement 1 on untouchability was.

('57', 382, 8, 17, 665413) It is therefore time for all that is clean and uplifting in Hinduism to combine together and make a united effort to overthrow the many headed monster of untouchability.

('57', 384, 4, 20, 668595) 637. LETTER TO S. M. MICHAEL
('57', 384, 5, 21, 668624) November 11, 1932 I should be sorry, indeed, if my prospective fast should deprive anyone of his or her intellectual freedom.
('57', 384, 5, 22, 668750) Anyway, I have declared in emphatic terms that it is intended only to affect the mass mind.
('57', 384, 5, 23, 668842) Naturally friends and co workers who believe in the removal of un touchability will be stirred to action.
('57', 384, 5, 24, 668948) That is no matter for regret.
('57', 384, 5, 25, 668978) Nevertheless, if you have a clear call of conscience you will, of course, fast.
('57', 384, 5, 26, 669058) 2 But you will hardly expect it to move me if I continue to believe that I am also obeying God’s call.
('57', 384, 6, 27, 669161) The Hindu, 21 11 1932. Also Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, p.

('57', 385, 0, 1, 669479) 386 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 385, 1, 2, 669521) 638. LETTER TO P. N. RAJBHOJ
('57', 385, 2, 3, 669550) November 11, 1932
('57', 385, 3, 4, 669568) MY DEAR RAJBHOJ, I was very glad to be able to see you and the friends who came with you and I feel thankful that my advice proved acceptable to you.
('57', 385, 3, 5, 669718) I am quite sure that no satyagraha should be attempted regarding temple entry, nor any fast undertaken by anybody, whilst all attention is being concentrated on Guruvayur.
('57', 385, 3, 6, 669890) Nor should anybody think of undertaking sympathetic fast, should it become necessary for Sjt.
('57', 385, 3, 7, 669984) Kelappan and myself to do so.
('57', 385, 3, 8, 670014) My advice however to suspend satya graha whilst all energy is being devoted to Guruvayur temple does not mean that no other effort should be made about opening the other temples.
('57', 385, 3, 9, 670193) That has to be made unremittingly.
('57', 385, 3, 10, 670228) But just now it is a point of honour with caste Hindus to do so.
('57', 385, 3, 11, 670293) It will be time enough for Harijans to think of it when it is clearly established that caste Hindus will do nothing to secure the opening of public temples to Harijans.
('57', 385, 3, 12, 670462) Fortunately every day brings the news of some temple being spontaneously opened somewhere to the Harijans and from all accounts that I have been receiving such effort is being continued though undoubtedly not with the same enthusiasm that marked the fast week.
('57', 385, 3, 13, 670723) What however Harijans may do to facilitate the work of caste Hindus is to take up, so far as it is possible, internal reform such as observance of the laws of cleanliness, and giving up carrion and drink.
('57', 385, 3, 14, 670928) I have discussed such things exhaustively with you.
('57', 385, 3, 15, 670980) The matter of opening facilities for the technical training of Harijan children and offering scholarships to deserving Harijan youths, I propose to discuss with Seth Ghanshyamdas Birla and the other members of the A.I.A.U. League 1 when they come here to see me.
('57', 385, 4, 16, 671243) Yours sincerely,
('57', 385, 5, 17, 671260) M. K. GANDHI
('57', 385, 6, 18, 671273) From a photostat: G.N. 787.Also Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol II, pp.
('57', 385, 7, 19, 671338) 1 All India Anti Untouchability League.
('57', 385, 7, 20, 671378) The name was later changed to Harijan Sevak Sangh.

('57', 388, 1, 2, 674744) 643. INTERVIEW TO P. N. RAJBHOJ 1
('57', 388, 2, 3, 674778) November 11, 1932
('57', 388, 3, 4, 674796) RAJBHOJ: The untouchables are trying to enter the temples by all possible means.
('57', 388, 3, 5, 674877) Suppose the methods of persuasion and mutual goodwill fail, do you think that the untouchables should resort to satyagraha?
('57', 388, 3, 6, 675001) If they may resort to it, what should be the method adopted?
('57', 388, 4, 7, 675062) GANDHIJI: Under the present circumstances I don’t think that satyagraha is at all advisable or needed.
('57', 388, 4, 8, 675165) All efforts should be concentrated on Guruvayur.
('57', 388, 4, 9, 675214) Harijans should for the time being watch what the caste men are doing.
('57', 388, 4, 10, 675285) Whatever happens about Guruvayur is likely to happen to many if not all the other temples.
('57', 388, 5, 11, 675376) R: In the case of the entry into the Parvati temple all methods have been tried, including the attempts of Sjts.
('57', 388, 5, 12, 675489) Jamnalal Bajaj and Mr. N. C. Kelkar.
('57', 388, 5, 13, 675526) May I know how to get out of this fix?
('57', 388, 6, 14, 675565) G. I am aware of your efforts and satyagraha in regard to the Parvati temple.
('57', 388, 6, 15, 675643) Even regarding this I should advise you to wait till the Guruvayur matter is settled one way or the other.
('57', 388, 6, 16, 675750) In the meanwhile you can carry on negotiations with the Parvati Trustees and create public opinion.
('57', 388, 7, 17, 675850) R: Now that Government has permitted you to do untouchability work unfettered what objections have you to come out and devote yourself to this cause alone?
('57', 388, 8, 18, 676006) G. I cannot accept my freedom under any restrictions.
('57', 388, 8, 19, 676060) But this is a matter I must not discuss.
('57', 388, 9, 20, 676101) R: We learn from the correspondence published in the papers that you have announced a fast in suit with Mr. Kelappan.
('57', 388, 9, 21, 676219) Suppose any “touchable” or untouchable announces another fast in connection with some other noteworthy temple, say Kashi Vishveshwar, may I know whether you will be prepared to stake your life in every such case?
('57', 388, 9, 22, 676432) Do you think that your person will be able to cope with this anomalous situation?
('57', 388, 10, 23, 676514) G. I have given my word to Mr. Kelappan, and I am in honour bound to start my fast with him on the 2nd of January, 1933. If somebody else starts a similar fast in respect of another temple, I do not hold myself bound to join him.
('57', 388, 10, 24, 676744) Every case has to be examined on

('57', 389, 2, 4, 677150) R: What are the obligations and duties of the “touchables” and untouchables with regard to indiscriminate use by both of public wells or such other common sources of water, tanks, etc.?
('57', 389, 3, 5, 677336) G. The untouchables have as much right to have water from the public wells and tanks as the “touchables”.
('57', 389, 3, 6, 677442) The matter, in case of any difference of opinion should be settled amicably by persuasion and negotiation.
('57', 389, 3, 7, 677549) All the difficulties which cannot be solved locally should be brought to the notice of the All India Anti Untouchability League.
('57', 389, 3, 8, 677678) I will of course do what I can from here.
('57', 389, 3, 9, 677720) Whereas in the matter of the use of public wells, there is a clear legal right, the untouchables can seek the protection of law courts, but this method does not help downtrodden people.
('57', 389, 3, 10, 677906) The strong will always get round or disregard the law.
('57', 389, 3, 11, 677961) The chief thing therefore is by conciliatory attitude to create favourable local public opinion.
('57', 389, 3, 12, 678058) Mr. Birla and Mr. Thakkar are coming to Poona to confer with me about this problem and the methods to be adopted for its solution.

('57', 389, 4, 15, 678545) So on behalf of these classes I have to request you to press this point of view for the promotion of this idea.
('57', 389, 5, 16, 678657) It is also our desire that common hostels be opened where “touchables” and untouchables will stay together.
('57', 389, 6, 17, 678765) G. I agree to your proposal about spending some of the funds of the League in scholarships for the untouchables and for technical education such as leather tanning, making leather goods, rope making, etc., in India as well as foreign countries.

('57', 389, 6, 19, 679183) The League will surely try and use its influence in this matter.
('57', 389, 7, 20, 679248) R. Don’t you think that the campaign against untouchability should be

('57', 390, 1, 2, 679455) confined to villages, the centres of orthodoxy, rather than to towns where people are educated and broad minded to a little extent at least?
('57', 390, 1, 3, 679596) Are not some women workers necessary to do propaganda work among village women ?

('57', 390, 2, 6, 679902) Women should come forward in large numbers to work for this movement.

('57', 390, 2, 9, 680037) They should observe common cleanliness, should refrain from eating the meat of dead animals and from drink, send their children to schools, remove untouchability among themselves and generally carry on such reform from within as is possible.
('57', 390, 3, 10, 680279) R. Do you feel the necessity of incorporating the question of removal of untouchability as one of the Fundamental Rights in the new constitution of India?
('57', 390, 3, 11, 680434) That is to say, will it be proper to consider it a criminal offence if any Hindu is treated as an untouchable at any public place and, further, will it be proper to punish him under a law for wounding his religious susceptibilities?
('57', 390, 3, 12, 680667) If time comes, will the Indian National Congress be prepared and try to embody this principle in the constitution ?
('57', 390, 3, 13, 680783) G. Removal of untouchability should undoubtedly be one of the Fundamental Rights in the new constitution of India.
('57', 390, 3, 14, 680898) It should be considered a criminal offence to treat any Hindu as an untouchable.
('57', 390, 3, 15, 680979) The Congress will certainly be prepared to embody this principle in the constitution.
('57', 390, 3, 16, 681065) They should see that violence is not resorted to in furtherance of their objects.
('57', 390, 3, 17, 681147) I don’t think that the untouchables only are supposed to do the work of sweepers, of carrying carcases, mending shoes, etc.
('57', 390, 3, 18, 681271) Cases of ill treatment because of the so called untouchables refusing to do any work of this sort should be referred to the local agent of the League.
('57', 390, 3, 19, 681422) Nobody should object to inter caste dinners, but no force should be brought to bear upon persons who don’t wish to attend such functions.
('57', 390, 3, 20, 681560) But I am of opinion that it would not be wise to make inter caste dinners an item in your programme.
('57', 390, 3, 21, 681661) I should not advise the untouchables to leave their trades and professions.

('57', 392, 1, 2, 683351) 646. INTERVIEW TO “THE HINDU ”
('57', 392, 2, 3, 683382) November 12, 1932
('57', 392, 3, 4, 683400) Asked whether he had seen Lord Sankey’s latest appeal in the Newsletter, Gandhiji observed : So far as I can understand Sir Samuel Hoare’s answer in the House of Commons to a question, letters dissuading me from civil disobedience can pass the jail precincts and be delivered to me.
('57', 392, 3, 5, 683683) But I know that I have no authority to send replies to such letters with the assurance that they will leave the precincts of the jail.
('57', 392, 3, 6, 683818) Under the limits that I have accepted or imposed upon myself, so far as these interviews are concerned, I may not give any reply in answer to questions by reporters or even by private friends who may visit me.
('57', 392, 4, 7, 684028) When reminded that Lord Sankey wanted a gesture and asked how he would get a reply, Gandhiji said he would gladly read Lord Sankey’s appeal with all the respect and attention that an appeal from him would demand.
('57', 392, 4, 8, 684241) The Mahatma observed : After having read it if I come to the conclusion that I can make a useful reply, it will be duly submitted to the Government for despatch to Lord Sankey.
('57', 392, 5, 9, 684418) Gandhiji answering my question regarding Guruvayur, told me that the next fast to be declared was dependent upon Mr. Kelappan’s.
('57', 392, 5, 10, 684547) He said : I can conceive of circumstances when I have to take it up independently.
('57', 392, 5, 11, 684630) Supposing Mr. Kelappan dies, God forbid it, I shall have to carry out the fast.
('57', 392, 5, 12, 684710) I have taken an extreme illustration.
('57', 392, 5, 13, 684748) Ordinarily speaking, I do not expect to take it independently of Mr. Kelappan.
('57', 392, 6, 14, 684827) Asked what his attitude would be if Mr. Kelappan felt satisfied that steps were being taken in right earnest, and the temple was bound to be opened shortly, though not exactly on January 1st next, say, one or two weeks later.
('57', 392, 6, 15, 685053) Gandhiji said : Supposing Mr. Kelappan comes to such a conclusion, he will have to reason it out with me and satisfy me that there is no occasion for fasting.
('57', 392, 6, 16, 685212) Let me say I do not expect Mr. Kelappan ever to say that.
('57', 392, 6, 17, 685270) But assume that Mr. Kelappan weakens and wants to wriggle out of the vow taken before God and man; if there is the slightest suspicion of that character, I would require some satisfaction for my reason.
('57', 392, 6, 18, 685473) But I have always believed Mr. Kelappan to be inflexible in his
('57', 392, 7, 19, 685537) 1 For Gandhiji’s reply to Lord Sankey, Vide “Cable to Lord Sankey”, 13 11 1932.
('57', 393, 0, 1, 685617) 394 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 393, 1, 2, 685659) determination and unbending in the good cause.
('57', 393, 2, 3, 685706) Questioned whether he had examined, as was his wont, the Guruvayur temple entry question in all its details before deciding on a fast, Gandhiji replied: I cannot pretend that I have examined the question in all its details.
('57', 393, 2, 4, 685930) I have entirely depended upon Mr. Kelappan having done so though, generally speaking, I have been undoubtedly satisfying myself as to the correctness of the claim for opening the temple to the untouchables.
('57', 393, 2, 5, 686137) But if anyone were to ask me whether I have seen the trust deed, if there is any, of the Guruvayur temple or whether I have critically examined the customs or conditions governing the mana gement of that celebrated temple, I must confess my ignorance.
('57', 393, 3, 6, 686389) When his attention was drawn to the Zamorin’s latest letter published in The Hindu dated 7th November that the Zamorin stood no longer bound by the assurance given to Mr. Kelappan when he commenced his fast, to go into the question if in the meanwhile Mr. Kelappan broke his fast, as Mr. Kelappan had rejected the offer and continued the fast, Gandhiji observed : The Zamorin’s charge against Mr. Kelappan of discourtesy and his refusal on that ground to carry out his assurance appears to be incomprehensible.
('57', 393, 3, 7, 686900) His assurance though given to Mr. Kelappan was quite an assurance to the general public and it amounted to a declaration that he was alive to the duty that rested upon him, of making every endeavour to find a way out.
('57', 393, 3, 8, 687118) As a responsible person, and as a trustee, in my opinion, he is bound, irrespective of Mr. Kelappan’s conduct, to carry out that assurance.
('57', 393, 4, 9, 687258) The trustee of a Hindu temple is not merely to guard the customs or so called privileges of a particular caste, but to guard the purity of Hinduism itself, and to respond to the daily growing spiritual aspirations of the Hindus.
('57', 393, 4, 10, 687487) Such a trustee cannot afford to be ruffled by what one or even many men may say against him.
('57', 393, 4, 11, 687580) And so far as the legal aspect of the question is concerned, I know the Zamorin’s contention, but the legal difficulties are there to be combated and overcome when they stand in the way of a great moral reform.
('57', 393, 4, 12, 687791) Therefore neither the Zamorin nor any other per son can be allowed to plead legal difficulties as a sufficient answer against the opening of the temple.
('57', 393, 4, 13, 687944) If public opinion itself is morally justified, a responsible trustee like the Zamorin is expected to remove the legal obstacles in the way of the moral demand of the public being
('57', 393, 5, 14, 688123) 1 Vide also “Telegram to the Zamorin of Calicut”, 9 11 1932.

('57', 394, 1, 2, 688234) satisfied.
('57', 394, 2, 3, 688245) Q. Would you postpone your fast, if efforts are made to amend the Act to admit
('57', 394, 3, 4, 688324) untouchables into the temple, but the legislature is not able to find time to get the Bill through before 1st January?
('57', 394, 4, 5, 688443) A. Supposing it is physically impossible to secure an amendment of the Act before 1st January, that would be sufficient justification for the postponement of the fast.
('57', 394, 4, 6, 688611) That presupposes that all the steps that could be taken have been taken, and that humanly speaking, there is every chance of the legislation going through.
('57', 394, 4, 7, 688767) That again presupposes that the public, trustees and everybody have to be of one mind.
('57', 394, 5, 8, 688854) Asked whether he would entertain the suggestion to invite a body of orthodox sanatanists to meet him and attempt to reach an amicable settlement of the issue, Mahatmaji said : I would consider it a presumption to invite a body of great people to come to me.
('57', 394, 5, 9, 689112) It is out of respect to them that I say that I won’t invite them.
('57', 394, 5, 10, 689178) I don’t invite these people not because I do not want to see them, nor because I think they can have nothing to say to me.
('57', 394, 5, 11, 689301) I refrain from inviting them out of regard for their status.
('57', 394, 5, 12, 689362) But if I discover that if I only issued an invitation to them they would gladly come, I would have no hesitation in sending such an invitation.
('57', 394, 6, 13, 689506) Asked how he was disposed towards those who sympathized with the temple entry movement, and at the same time wanted to respect the feelings of the orthodox sanatanists that the so called untouchables should be allowed to go into the temples as far as the Dhwajastambham and the deity brought down there on festive days for darshan, the Mahatma said : This movement is to remove untouchability.
('57', 394, 6, 14, 689900) Therefore, the un touchables should enjoy precisely the same rights as the “touch ables”, but that does not mean that they should have access to the sanctuary, which is only open to those who are in charge of the ceremonial.
('57', 394, 6, 15, 690125) If non Brahmins are prevented from going because they are considered untouchables, then undoubtedly that untouchability must go.
('57', 394, 6, 16, 690254) But if there is no black mark of untouchability against them, but it is only the Brahmins who are allowed to go as far as certain parts of the sanctuary, I should have nothing to say against it as a part of this movement.
('57', 394, 6, 17, 690476) The question of the exclusive rights of the Brahmins in connection with religious ceremonies stands on a different footing, and if that exclusiveness has to go, that question will have to be separately examined.
('57', 394, 6, 18, 690688) I am not prepared, off hand, to condemn the practice of reserving certain functions exclusively for a
('57', 395, 0, 1, 690790) 396 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 395, 1, 2, 690832) particular class.
('57', 395, 1, 3, 690850) This won’t be a matter of right, but of duty, to be performed by a body of experts, having the required qualifications.
('57', 395, 2, 4, 690970) Referring to Mr. V. V. Srinivasa Iyengar’s remark that temple entry is being urged as generous gesture of political conciliation, Gandhiji observed : I had the privilege of knowing Mr. V. V. Srinivasa Iyengar even before he became a Judge of the Madras High Court, and it is astonishing to me how temple entry can, by any stretch of imagination, be regarded as a political question.
('57', 395, 2, 5, 691353) I simply cannot understand it.
('57', 395, 3, 6, 691384) Concluding, Gandhiji said : If Hinduism could cure itself of the age long curse without outside intervention the cause of Hinduism would be better served.
('57', 395, 3, 7, 691539) Non Hindus will immediately begin to think that there is something very vital in Hinduism.
('57', 395, 3, 8, 691630) I feel that the removal of untouchability is such a tremendous reform in Hinduism that it must have a reaction throughout the world.
('57', 395, 3, 9, 691763) It will be a total denial of my existence if my method of approach proves a failure.
('57', 395, 4, 10, 691848) At the end of the conversation, I found Gandhiji exhausted.
('57', 395, 4, 11, 691908) When I expressed my doubt as to whether he would be able to successfully undergo another fast, Gandhiji remarked that he was hopeful of it.
('57', 395, 5, 12, 692048) To another remark as to what he would do if the Madras Council rejected the proposed Bill, the Mahatma remarked : I don’t anticipate such a failure.
('57', 395, 5, 13, 692197) A House which adopted Dr. Subbaroyan’s resolution will not reject a Bill amending the present Act if introduced.
('57', 395, 5, 14, 692310) I don’t believe in dying before my days.
('57', 395, 6, 15, 692351) Gandhiji is pleased with the Madras Council’s action in passing Dr. Subbaroyan’s resolution and is watching what steps are taken to give effect to the same.

('57', 396, 1, 2, 692580) 647. LETTER TO CHAMPABEHN R. MEHTA 1
('57', 396, 2, 3, 692617) [Before November 13, 1932] 2
('57', 396, 3, 4, 692646) If you think that being appointed one of the trustees 3 will make you free, you are mistaken.
('57', 396, 3, 5, 692740) The word “trust” means responsibility, and I would certainly welcome a person becoming a trustee of his own property.
('57', 396, 3, 6, 692858) He then ceases to be the owner of his property.
('57', 396, 3, 7, 692906) He must then live within the commission which as a trustee he gets from the property.
('57', 396, 3, 8, 692992) This is the meaning of trust.
('57', 396, 3, 9, 693022) I am not talking here about trustees who abuse their office and misappropriate the property.
('57', 396, 3, 10, 693115) I am only explaining here the duties of a trustee.
('57', 396, 3, 11, 693166) You say that you want to acquire strength to stand on your own feet.
('57', 396, 3, 12, 693235) Do you understand what that means?
('57', 396, 3, 13, 693270) To stand on your feet means that you will not depend on your father’s earnings, nor on your father in law’s, nor your husband’s but subsist on your own earnings, however small they may be.
('57', 396, 3, 14, 693459) You have never shown evidence of such strength in you.
('57', 396, 3, 15, 693514) Nor did I ever observe any such desire in you.
('57', 396, 3, 16, 693561) In the past I have congratulated persons whose houses had been burgled.
('57', 396, 3, 17, 693633) My attitude is the same in this case.
('57', 396, 3, 18, 693671) We have no moral right to possess a single pie.
('57', 396, 3, 19, 693719) Whatever we possess is as good as stolen property.
('57', 396, 3, 20, 693770) Since all people in the world are thieves, possessions are not looked upon as theft.
('57', 396, 3, 21, 693855) That, however, should not blind us to the truth.
('57', 396, 3, 22, 693904) Is it any matter for wonder if other thieves rob us of some of the stolen property in our possession?
('57', 396, 3, 23, 694006) The lesson you should draw from this theft is that you should not possess things which would tempt a thief, and that you may use the few things which you possess as long as they are not stolen.
('57', 396, 3, 24, 694200) If you learn that lesson from the theft, you will have lost nothing but on the contrary gained wisdom.
('57', 396, 3, 25, 694303) [From Gujarati]

('57', 400, 4, 6, 701063) 650. MESSAGE TO VERRIER ELWIN
('57', 400, 5, 7, 701093) November 13, 1932 Cleanest air, cleanest water, simplest food and cleanest thinking which really means communion with God, are the four laws the first three flowing from the fourth.
('57', 400, 5, 8, 701275) Hence your English saying simple, that is, plain living and high thinking.
('57', 400, 5, 9, 701350) I should like to simplify that saying clean thinking and clean living.
('57', 400, 5, 10, 701421) Boils are a symptom of unclean living in my sense of the expression.
('57', 400, 5, 11, 701490) Let this then be my message to the brothers 1 for a beginning.

('57', 400, 7, 13, 701586) 651. LETTER TO M. M. ANANTA RAU
('57', 400, 8, 14, 701618) November 13, 1932
('57', 400, 9, 15, 701636) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('57', 400, 9, 16, 701669) Your argument seems to be this: Bhagavad Gita refers the devotee to shastravidhi and since Shastras support untouchability, Bhagavad Gita must be said to support it.
('57', 400, 9, 17, 701835) The question then is what are Shastras?
('57', 400, 9, 18, 701875) And I have answered that question by the answer that whatever is contrary to the main theme of the Gita must be rejected as being no Shastra.
('57', 400, 9, 19, 702017) And since the main theme is oneness and therefore equality of all life, there is no warrant for untouchability in the Gita.
('57', 400, 10, 20, 702141) Yours sincerely,
('57', 400, 11, 21, 702158) From a copy: C.W. 9558. Courtesy: Government of Mysore
('57', 400, 12, 22, 702213) 1 Members of Christi Seva Sangh

('57', 410, 1, 2, 716528) 668. STATEMENT ON UNTOUCHABILITY V
('57', 410, 2, 3, 716563) November 14, 1932 In this fifth statement to the Press, in which I would like to express my gratefulness for the publicity they are giving to my statements and movement generally, I want to summarize a part of what I said last week to Sjt.
('57', 410, 2, 4, 716803) Rajbhoj and his friends, 1 who met me to discuss practically the whole movement.
('57', 410, 2, 5, 716884) One of their questions related to what Harijans could do in order to help the movement.
('57', 410, 2, 6, 716972) They could do a great deal in the direction.
('57', 410, 2, 7, 717017) They could anticipate the charges brought against them in justification of the refusal of some caste Hindus to associate with them on terms of absolute equality.
('57', 410, 2, 8, 717179) I have already said in emphatic language that the caste Hindus are wholly to blame for the undoubtedly deplorable condition of the vast mass of Harijans and that the improvement will follow the removal of untouchability as a matter of course.
('57', 410, 2, 9, 717422) It should never be made a condition of removal.
('57', 410, 2, 10, 717470) Nevertheless, it is the obvious duty of Harijan workers to carry on internal reform to the extent it is possible even in the face of the existing state of things.
('57', 410, 2, 11, 717633) Harijan workers should therefore devote all their energy to : (1) the promotion of cleanliness and hygiene among Harijans, (2) to improve the method of carrying on what are known as unclean occupations, such as scavenging and tanning, (3) giving up of carrion and beef, if not meat altogether, (4) giving up of intoxicating liquors, (5) inducing parents to send their children to day schools wherever they are available and parents themselves to attend night schools wherever such are opened, and (6) abolition of untouchability among themselves.
('57', 410, 2, 12, 718180) Let me go through the items to indicate what is meant by them.
('57', 410, 2, 13, 718243) A daily bath is necessary at least in our climate, and clean clothes are necessary under all climates.
('57', 410, 2, 14, 718346) I know that water is not easily available in Harijan quarters.
('57', 410, 2, 15, 718409) They have, as a rule, no access to public wells and tanks, and they are too poor to afford a change of clothing.
('57', 410, 2, 16, 718522) It is not generally realized that even a lota full of water can give one a clean bath.
('57', 410, 2, 17, 718609) It is taken by thoroughly wetting a clean towel and vigorously
('57', 410, 3, 18, 718672) 1Vide “Interview to P.N. Rajbhoj”, 11 11 1932.
('57', 411, 0, 1, 718719) 412 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 411, 1, 2, 718761) rubbing the body, including the head, all over, and then wiping with a dry towel.
('57', 411, 1, 3, 718843) If the bath is taken daily, the wet towel after wringing out all water from it can serve the purpose of drying the body.
('57', 411, 1, 4, 718964) In this climate again, the same clothes can be easily washed and dried there and then, whilst one has merely the langoti on.
('57', 411, 1, 5, 719089) I know there is nothing new in what I am saying, and yet I have been obliged to explain these very elementary things to hundreds of workers.
('57', 411, 1, 6, 719230) Even graduates have been found to be ignorant of these elementary aids to hygiene as to the improved method of scavenging.
('57', 411, 1, 7, 719353) Selfish, ignorant caste men make it well nigh impossible to remove human remains in a decent manner.
('57', 411, 1, 8, 719454) The closets, because of the untouchability, are unclean beyond description.
('57', 411, 1, 9, 719530) They are dark and ill ventilated and so constructed that only a portion is somewhat capable of being cleaned and that too under filthy conditions.
('57', 411, 1, 10, 719677) To use these closets is a positive daily descent to Hell and but for the beneficent climate many more thousands than already do will find an early cremation.
('57', 411, 1, 11, 719835) Owing to the superstitious refusal to see one’s own faeces and to permit the untouchables or themselves to clean the interior of the closet, the Harijans who have to perform the very necessary social service can even in the existing unfavourable circumstances at least have their bath immediately after the cleaning is done and use plenty of dry earth for cleaning instead of just a little straw that they use.
('57', 411, 1, 12, 720246) Being an expert scavenger that I claim to be, I could show many very cheap, efficient and thoroughly clean methods of performing this service, especially if the villagers and city people would help, but I cannot deal with this interesting subject in this cursory statement.
('57', 411, 1, 13, 720520) The curious may look up my writings on sanitation in general, and village sanitation in particular.
('57', 411, 1, 14, 720620) Scavengers should wear a professional dress, while they are doing the cleaning work.
('57', 411, 1, 15, 720705) Every employer or a group of employers can supply such a dress for his or their scavengers.
('57', 411, 1, 16, 720797) Clean tanning is a far more difficult proposition.
('57', 411, 1, 17, 720848) Our tanners do not know the modern method of skinning carcases nor of tanning.
('57', 411, 1, 18, 720927) Tanning I have here used in a comprehensive sense.
('57', 411, 1, 19, 720978) The so called higher classes having criminally neglected this useful body of their co religionists and fellow countrymen, the whole of the process from the carrying of the carcase to the dressing of the hide is done in a crude manner resulting in the loss to the country of untold wealth and the production of inferior hide.
('57', 412, 0, 1, 721303) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 413
('57', 412, 1, 2, 721353) The late Madhusudan Das, 1 who was a great philanthropist and had himself learnt the modern process of tanning, had prepared statistics to show what the country was losing annually owing to the superstition of untouchability masquerading under the name of religion.
('57', 412, 1, 3, 721619) Harijan workers can learn the modern method and acquaint the tanners with it in so far as it is practicable.
('57', 412, 1, 4, 721728) The scavengers should be taught resolutely not to accept the remains of the householder’s daily food which is virtually thrown at them in the cruellest manner possible.
('57', 412, 1, 5, 721897) Years of habit have dulled the aesthetic sense of the scavengers and they see nothing wrong in eating the remains of another man’s dishes.
('57', 412, 1, 6, 722036) They crave for what they regard as dainties from their employers’ dishes.
('57', 412, 1, 7, 722110) I have known Bhangis having removed their children from school because the latter were taught not to touch these leavings and be satisfied with the jowar or the bajri bread baked in their homes.
('57', 412, 1, 8, 722305) Tanners should be induced to give up carrion and beef.
('57', 412, 1, 9, 722360) As a vegetarian, I would like Harijans to give up, as many have done, meat altogether, but if they are not ready for this reform they should be taught to give up carrion as being unhygienic, besides being taboo by the rest of mankind and beef as being forbidden in Hinduism.
('57', 412, 1, 10, 722635) I know that carrion is part of the price they get for removing the carcases.
('57', 412, 1, 11, 722712) Dr. Ambedkar told me that in some places villagers beat those who had given up carrion, telling them it was their religion to eat it.
('57', 412, 1, 12, 722846) The fact was that they were afraid that if the tanners gave up carrion eating they would demand an equivalent price or give up carrying dead cattle.
('57', 412, 1, 13, 722995) Whatever the difficulty, carrion and beef eating must be given up.
('57', 412, 1, 14, 723062) That one self restraint will at once raise the Harijans in the estimation of the caste men and make the task of caste reformers comparatively easy in the campaign against untouchability.
('57', 412, 1, 15, 723249) Items four and five do not call for any remarks.
('57', 412, 1, 16, 723298) They are self explained.
('57', 412, 1, 17, 723323) The last item is abolition of untouchability among untouc hables themselves.
('57', 412, 1, 18, 723400) This is an urgent need.
('57', 412, 1, 19, 723424) Removal of untouchability will become most difficult if this double untouchability is not removed with one sweep.
('57', 412, 1, 20, 723538) It is an uphill task for Harijan reformers.
('57', 412, 1, 21, 723582) But if they will realize that this movement is predominantly religious and
('57', 412, 2, 22, 723657) 1 In fact, Madhusudan Das was not dead.
('57', 412, 2, 23, 723697) Gandhiji came to know of his mistake later from a member of the Ashram and at once apologized to Madhusudan Das.
('57', 412, 2, 24, 723810) Vide Vol. LII, “Telegram to Madhusudan Das”, 18 11 1932.
('57', 413, 0, 1, 723867) 414 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 413, 1, 2, 723909) is designed to purge Hinduism of the uncleanness that has crept into it, they will have the necessary courage and self confidence to carry out the great reform.
('57', 413, 1, 3, 724070) It is needless for me to stress the point that workers in such a movement must be selfless and pure in character.
('57', 413, 1, 4, 724184) I have given here a constructive programme that should satisfy the most ambitious reformer among Harijans and occupy the whole of his time and energy.
('57', 413, 1, 5, 724335) But there are one or two things he and the Harijans may not do during this period of grace.
('57', 413, 1, 6, 724427) At any rate, no Harijan need fast against anyone nor need satyagraha be offered by them.
('57', 413, 1, 7, 724516) Let them watch the caste Hindus who are on their trial and see what they do to remove the bar that separates the Harijans from them.
('57', 413, 1, 8, 724649) Let them not engage in quarrels with local caste Hindus.
('57', 413, 1, 9, 724706) Their behaviour should be at all times courteous and dignified, much more so at this time.
('57', 413, 1, 10, 724797) Religion can only be vindicated by self suffering, never by violence done to the oppressors though there may be many things they may get by force.
('57', 413, 1, 11, 724944) Their credit will lie in getting their rights by the conversion of caste Hindus and today they have ample reason for deriving hope from the knowledge that there are tens of thousands of caste Hindus who have a lively sense of their guilt and are straining every nerve to do reparation to Harijans.
('57', 413, 1, 12, 725242) Let them have perfect confidence in the absolute justice of their cause and in the ability of self suffering to win it.
('57', 413, 1, 13, 725362) In the next statement 1 I must give my reply to caste men who have asked what they can do to help the movement.

('57', 414, 4, 7, 725959) 670. LETTER TO BHAU PANSE
('57', 414, 5, 8, 725985) Morning, Silence Day, November 14, 1932
('57', 414, 6, 9, 726025) BHAU, I am afraid I am writing this letter very late, as you will get it twelve days after the fast was ended.
('57', 414, 6, 10, 726136) I wrote to you in my previous letter what food you should eat.
('57', 414, 6, 11, 726199) You may make a few changes in it to suit your constituion.
('57', 414, 6, 12, 726258) The fast may be said to have succeeded only if you pass stool naturally without enema in six or seven days or before that, feel sufficiently hungry, can easily digest simple food, put on weight and also regain your strength.
('57', 414, 6, 13, 726483) If, however, you do not pass stool without enema, then you should take a purgative.
('57', 414, 6, 14, 726567) Castor oil is very good.
('57', 414, 6, 15, 726592) Take about two tea spoon fuls of it immediately after brushing your teeth in the morning.
('57', 414, 6, 16, 726682) If you put a little salt in the mouth, then swallow the castor oil and then again lick some salt, you will not feel the unpleasant flavour of castor oil.
('57', 414, 6, 17, 726836) After this, you are sure to pass stool without taking enema.
('57', 414, 6, 18, 726897) If you do not, you may conclude that your bowels are still not clear.
('57', 414, 6, 19, 726967) You may, in that case, fast again after a few days when you are strong enough.
('57', 414, 6, 20, 727046) But this is the only method of curing constipation.
('57', 414, 6, 21, 727098) I fully believe in the importance of takli explained by Vinoba in his letter.
('57', 414, 6, 22, 727176) I have no doubt whatever that a person who spins on the takli in a spirit of service and as yajna will attain deliverance.
('57', 414, 7, 23, 727299) BAPU [PS.] Can you teach your method of spinning on a takli by explai ning it in a letter?
('57', 414, 7, 24, 727390) To whow many persons are you teaching it at present?

('57', 417, 7, 11, 731993) 676. STATEMENT ON UNTOUCHABILITY—VI
('57', 417, 8, 12, 732029) November 15, 1932
('57', 417, 9, 13, 732047) If, among the Harijans, Sjt.
('57', 417, 9, 14, 732076) Rajbhoj has yet been the only one to have asked me what Harijans might do to advance the movement, I have scores of letters from all parts of India, from caste Hindus, both men and women, students and others, inquiring in what way they can help without interfering with their other preoccupations; and since anti untouchability is a movement, as applied to the masses, of merely change of heart and changing their attitude towards Harijans, the vast majority of the caste Hindus do not need to interrupt their daily activities in order to serve the Harijans.
('57', 417, 10, 15, 732635) 1 The addressee, not identified in the source, had asked: “Do we not treat others—such as Christians, etc.—also as untouchables?” 2 The addressee, a young boy not identified in the source, had asked in what way he could do service.
('57', 418, 0, 1, 732867) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 419
('57', 418, 1, 2, 732917) The first thing is for everyone to understand the implications of the removal of untouchability in his or her own life, and if the answer is that he or she has not only no objection to, but is desirous of, seeing them entering public temples, using public places, such as schools, serais, roads, hospitals, dispensaries and the like, in short, to Harijans being put precisely on the same footing as themselves religiously, socially, economically and politically, he or she has personally taken the full step.
('57', 418, 1, 3, 733426) But that is not all that the questioners want or all that I should be satisfied with.
('57', 418, 1, 4, 733512) Having gone so far, they want to know what more they can do in the furtherance of the cause.
('57', 418, 1, 5, 733605) Such inquirers need not extend their activities beyond their immediate neighbourhood.
('57', 418, 1, 6, 733691) Let them canvass the opinion of those with whom they come in daily contact, and if the former are not convinced of the necessity of removal of untouchability, they should, if they have critically studied the movement, endeavour to convince their neighbours or, if they are not competent, they should procure the necessary literature, supply them with it and put them in touch with those full time workers who are specially qualified for such propaganda work.
('57', 418, 1, 7, 734150) If they find that their neighbourhood is not touched by the spirit of the movement, and if they have any influence, they should arrange public lectures and demonstrations.
('57', 418, 1, 8, 734322) So much for the work among caste Hindus.
('57', 418, 1, 9, 734363) But the real work that this large body of men and women can do is undoubtedly among the Harijans.
('57', 418, 1, 10, 734461) Those caste Hindus who have studied my fifth statement could not fail to have noticed that there is a vast amount of silent and effective service to be rendered by caste Hindus without much expenditure of time, energy or money.
('57', 418, 1, 11, 734689) Caste Hindus can effectively supplement the effort of Harijan workers in inculcating habits of cleanliness and by procuring facilities for having easy access to the required water supply.
('57', 418, 1, 12, 734877) They can find out public wells and tanks situated near Harijan quarters and canvass the opinion of caste Hindus who may be using such wells or tanks, pointing out to them that Harijans have a legal right to the use of all such public services.
('57', 418, 1, 13, 735121) And they can, at the same time, see to it that when the consent of caste Hindus has been secured for the use by Harijans of these services, the latter use them in a manner not offensive to the former.
('57', 418, 1, 14, 735322) As to scavenging, they can visit the owners of houses served by Harijans in their neighbourhood and explain to them the necessity of making it easy for Harijans to do the cleaning work in a hygienic
('57', 419, 0, 1, 735521) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 419, 1, 2, 735563) manner.
('57', 419, 1, 3, 735571) To this end, it would be naturally necessary for them to study the scientific method of constructing closets and disposing of night soil.
('57', 419, 1, 4, 735709) Thy can also procure from the householders special dresses to be supplied to the scavengers and make the Harijans feel by unhesitatingly doing the scavenging themselves that there is nothing low or undignified about rendering such service.
('57', 419, 1, 5, 735949) Such workers should also carry on propaganda against caste men giving to their scavengers leavings from their daily food and, where they are ill paid persuading the employers to pay them a decent wage.
('57', 419, 1, 6, 736151) As to tanning, not much help can be rendered, unless someone of such voluntary leisure time workers has humanity and enthusiasm enough to study the hygienic method of skinning carcases and having done so, will spread the knowledge among tanners.
('57', 419, 1, 7, 736397) They certainly can do one thing.
('57', 419, 1, 8, 736430) They can find out the custom about the disposal of such carcases and see that the tanners are assured of a proper wage for the service they rendered.
('57', 419, 1, 9, 736580) Those who have capacity and time can conduct day or night schools, take Harijan children for picnics and sightseeing on holidays or whenever an opportunity occurs, visit Harijans in their own homes, procure medical aid where necessary and generally let them feel that a new page has been opened in their lives and that they need no longer regard themselves as the neglected and despised portion of Hindu humanity.
('57', 419, 1, 10, 736994) All that I have described can be most easily and efficiently done by the student world.
('57', 419, 1, 11, 737082) If this work is done with silent zeal, determination and intelligence by a large body of men and women, I have no doubt that we shall have taken many steps in our progress towards the goal, and it would be found too that there are more things than I have described that require attention.
('57', 419, 1, 12, 737371) I have but chosen a few of the many things that have come under my observation in the course of my journeyings.

('57', 422, 1, 2, 740463) 681. A LETTER 1
('57', 422, 2, 3, 740479) November 15, 1932 My whole heart goes out to you and your wife.
('57', 422, 2, 4, 740543) I am quite clear in my mind as to the course you have to follow.
('57', 422, 2, 5, 740608) You should forget the man and the deed.
('57', 422, 2, 6, 740648) God alone punishes and rewards.
('57', 422, 2, 7, 740680) It was open to you, as I suppose it is even now, to prosecute the offender.
('57', 422, 2, 8, 740756) But that is clearly not what you intend to do.
('57', 422, 2, 9, 740803) After all he was not in his senses.
('57', 422, 2, 10, 740839) Who knows that some day he may not learn the lesson and become a better man?
('57', 422, 2, 11, 740916) If an opportunity offers for you to do a good turn to him you will not omit to do it.
('57', 422, 2, 12, 741002) You should console your wife and induce her to forget the incident.
('57', 422, 2, 13, 741070) Your daughter should not even be allowed to remember the incident.
('57', 422, 2, 14, 741137) I suppose she has no knowledge of what was attempted to be done to her.
('57', 422, 2, 15, 741209) But even if she has, she should be brought up so as to forget it altogether.
('57', 422, 3, 16, 741286) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.
('57', 422, 4, 17, 741320) 682. LETTER TO VASANTRAM SHASTRI
('57', 422, 5, 18, 741353) November 15, 1932 According to me, I am the same man that I was in 1921. I hope, though, that I have progressed further in the same direction.
('57', 422, 5, 19, 741496) Nothing in this world remains fixed; things either progress or decline.
('57', 422, 5, 20, 741568) I did not write about people whom you imagine to be wicked.
('57', 422, 5, 21, 741628) The number of people who may be described as wicked is always small.
('57', 422, 5, 22, 741697) I wrote about the countless millions.
('57', 422, 5, 23, 741735) They may be ignorant and stupid, but they are not wicked.
('57', 422, 5, 24, 741793) If you reflect more deeply, you cannot but be convinced of this.
('57', 422, 5, 25, 741858) I should like you to explain more clearly what you mean by oppression.
('57', 422, 5, 26, 741929) [From Gujarati]

('57', 437, 2, 3, 768937) APPENDIX I 1
('57', 437, 3, 4, 768950) (A) DISCUSSION WITH VALLABHBHAI PATEL September 6, 1932
('57', 437, 4, 5, 769006) GANDHIJI: You were, of course, joking in the morning, but if you really have any questions to ask please ask them.
('57', 437, 5, 6, 769121) VALLABHBHAI PATEL : What do you think will these people do?
('57', 437, 6, 7, 769181) G. I still feel that they will release me on or before the 19th.
('57', 437, 6, 8, 769246) It will be the limit of wickedness if they let me fast, let no one know about it and then say that I did what I as a prisoner ought not to have done, and that they could do nothing about it.
('57', 437, 6, 9, 769437) I do not say that they cannot go that far, only they will not find it necessary.
('57', 437, 6, 10, 769518) And they certainly are not the people to go further than it is necessary.
('57', 437, 7, 11, 769592) V. P. Then what will you do?
('57', 437, 8, 12, 769621) G. The fast cannot commence on the 20th.
('57', 437, 8, 13, 769662) We cannot stick to the 20th.
('57', 437, 9, 14, 769691) V. P. Does is not mean then that we have got time till the new constitution is drawn up?
('57', 437, 9, 15, 769780) Or that you can give a longer notice to the people and the Government?
('57', 437, 10, 16, 769851) G. Yes, but that depends on how much the people will allow me to do after I get out.
('57', 437, 10, 17, 769936) I cannot tell what the situation will be.
('57', 437, 10, 18, 769978) I have no idea of the kind of letter I may have to write.
('57', 437, 10, 19, 770036) But I shall have to consider everyparty—the Hindu society, the Antyajas, the Government, the Muslims.
('57', 437, 10, 20, 770138) It will be necessary for the Hindus to hold meetings along with the Antyajas at every place and reject this thing.
('57', 437, 10, 21, 770253) The Government has done this thing as a Christian Government and hence I shall have to tell both the Government and the Christians the same thing—that as Christians they cannot do this thing.
('57', 437, 10, 22, 770445) Let our swaraj come into being, then they may influence the Antyajas in any way they like, but they should not divide us today.
('57', 437, 10, 23, 770573) I had said this to the Muslims even in England.
('57', 437, 10, 24, 770621) I shall say the same thing here also.
('57', 437, 10, 25, 770659) I shall explain to the Hindu society that now the Antyajas have no choice but to turn Muslims or Christians.
('57', 437, 11, 26, 770768) V. P. But where are the Muslims here who will listen to you?
('57', 437, 12, 27, 770829) G. It does not matter if there aren’t any.
('57', 437, 12, 28, 770872) But we should hope that those people too will wake up.
('57', 437, 12, 29, 770927) The root of satyagraha lies in faith in human nature, in the faith that it will be possible to melt the cruellest of men.
('57', 437, 12, 30, 771049) So there will surely be some Muslim who will say that if things go to that length he will not be able to bear it.
('57', 437, 12, 31, 771163) To accomplish all this, I shall have to call certain people.
('57', 437, 13, 32, 771224) 1Vide “Statement to the Press”, 16 11 1932.
('57', 438, 0, 1, 771268) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 439
('57', 438, 1, 2, 771318) do not know whether all of them will be permitted to come here.
('57', 438, 1, 3, 771382) But they may even insult me.
('57', 438, 1, 4, 771411) They may say that they have released me because they will not take the responsibility for my death.
('57', 438, 1, 5, 771511) However, if I launch civil disobedience, they will have to put me back into prison.
('57', 438, 2, 6, 771595) MAHADEV DESAI : Among the people who will come will also be Christian friends and they will say to you that before accusing the Government you should accuse yourself.
('57', 438, 2, 7, 771762) Why does Hindu society regard the Antyajas as untouchables?
('57', 438, 3, 8, 771822) G. That is up to me to explain.
('57', 438, 3, 9, 771854) That is not a difficult thing.
('57', 438, 3, 10, 771885) We can say to them: ‘Allow us to settle our problems ourselves, why do you interfere?
('57', 438, 3, 11, 771971) After we have set about managing our own affairs, you may do what you like.
('57', 438, 3, 12, 772047) Why do you divide us and then argue over things?
('57', 438, 3, 13, 772096) Today the Antyajas have either to turn to Muslims or to you.
('57', 438, 3, 14, 772157) The question of women is similar to that of the Antyajas.
('57', 438, 3, 15, 772215) But women are not untouchables.
('57', 438, 3, 16, 772247) Even if they wish to become untouchables, men will go and sit on their beds.
('57', 438, 3, 17, 772324) They cannot be separated even by having a separate electorate.
('57', 438, 3, 18, 772387) Today the Antyajas have been separated permanently.
('57', 438, 3, 19, 772439) What would be the outcome of it?
('57', 438, 3, 20, 772472) There would be internal strife.
('57', 438, 3, 21, 772504) There are people like .
('57', 438, 3, 22, 772528) He would collect bad characters in the community and get them to attack Hindus, poison wells and do other things.
('57', 438, 4, 23, 772642) The duty of those of you who have remained here is merely to inform everyone in the Camp jail that fasting is wholly prohibited and that everyone must remain calm.
('57', 438, 4, 24, 772806) [From Gujarati]
('57', 438, 5, 25, 772822) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.
('57', 438, 6, 26, 772856) (B) DISCUSSION WITH B.R. AMBEDKAR
('57', 438, 7, 27, 772890) September 22, 1932
('57', 438, 8, 28, 772909) AMBEDKAR : We must accept that in the country there are two groups belonging to two different ideologies and act accordingly, and I should get my compensation.
('57', 438, 8, 29, 773069) I also want that a clear understanding should be arrived at which would recompense me in other respects also.
('57', 438, 8, 30, 773179) The decision of the Government gives me seventy one seats and I feel that is a just, reasonable and definite allocation.
('57', 438, 9, 31, 773300) GANDHI : According to you.
('57', 438, 10, 32, 773327) A. Over and above that I get the right to vote and contest elections in the general constituencies.
('57', 438, 10, 33, 773427) I also have a franchise in the labourers’constituencies.
('57', 438, 10, 34, 773484) We do realize that you are of immense help to us.
('57', 438, 11, 35, 773534) G. Not to you personally.
('57', 438, 12, 36, 773560) A. But I have only one quarrel with you, that is, you work for the so called national welfare and not for our interests alone.
('57', 438, 12, 37, 773687) If you devoted yourself entirely to the welfare of the Depressed Classes, you would then become our hero.
('57', 439, 0, 1, 773793) 440 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 439, 1, 2, 773835) G. Very sweet of you to say so.
('57', 439, 2, 3, 773867) A. I want political power for my community.
('57', 439, 2, 4, 773911) That is indispensable for our
('57', 439, 3, 5, 773941) survival.
('57', 439, 3, 6, 773951) The basis of the agreement therefore should be: I should get what is due to
('57', 439, 4, 7, 774027) I wish to tell the Hindus that I should be assured of my compensation.
('57', 439, 5, 8, 774098) G. You have clarified your position very beautifully.
('57', 439, 5, 9, 774152) However, I should like to ask you one question.
('57', 439, 5, 10, 774200) You say that if there is any genuine party among the Depressed Classes it should be given sufficient scope to rise.
('57', 439, 5, 11, 774316) Therefore their refusal to accept joint electorates without primary elections is quite reasonable.
('57', 439, 5, 12, 774415) What I do not understand is why you have not said so far that there should be a separate election of this kind.
('57', 439, 5, 13, 774527) I feel from whatever study I have made of the subject that if I accept the primary election, the letter of my vow is not violated.
('57', 439, 5, 14, 774658) I therefore accept the Clause [of primary election] but I would most certainly have to scrutinize its wording.
('57', 439, 5, 15, 774769) At the moment, I say only this, that the idea of separate primary elections does not go against my vow.
('57', 439, 5, 16, 774873) But I suspect something when you insist that the panel should consist only of three candidates.
('57', 439, 5, 17, 774969) It does not give me sufficient place to turn in.
('57', 439, 5, 18, 775018) Moreover, you consider panel system for some seats only, thereby satisfying both the parties [among Harijans].
('57', 439, 5, 19, 775129) There would be one election, i.e., of the primary nature by the Harijan voters only.
('57', 439, 5, 20, 775214) The other would be by the joint electorate.
('57', 439, 5, 21, 775258) I have to safeguard without any discrimination not the interest of one group alone but of the Depressed Class as a whole.
('57', 439, 5, 22, 775380) I want to serve the untouchables.
('57', 439, 5, 23, 775414) That is why I am not at all angry with you.
('57', 439, 5, 24, 775458) When you use derogatory and angry words for me, I tell myself that I deserved that.
('57', 439, 5, 25, 775542) I will not get angry even if you spit on my face.
('57', 439, 5, 26, 775592) I say this with God as witness.
('57', 439, 5, 27, 775624) I know that you have drunk deep of the poisoned cup.
('57', 439, 5, 28, 775677) However, I make a claim which will seem astounding to you.
('57', 439, 5, 29, 775736) You are born an untouchable but I am an untouchable by adoption.
('57', 439, 5, 30, 775801) And as a new convert I feel more for the welfare of the community than those who are already there.
('57', 439, 5, 31, 775901) At the moment I have before my eyes the dumb untouchables—unapproachables and unseeables—of South India.
('57', 439, 5, 32, 776006) I am scrutinizing the scheme to see how these people will be affected by it.
('57', 439, 5, 33, 776083) You will of course say why I should worry about that.
('57', 439, 5, 34, 776137) All of you will either accept Christianity or Islam.
('57', 439, 5, 35, 776190) I say that you may do whatever you like after my body falls.
('57', 439, 5, 36, 776251) What I say is that if the panel system is good for the Depressed Classes it should be good for the entire electorate.
('57', 439, 5, 37, 776369) I do not like it from the beginning that the community should be divided into two groups.
('57', 439, 5, 38, 776459) I will raze to the ground the fort of sanatanists with dynamite if all the untouchables are one and united.
('57', 439, 5, 39, 776567) I want that the entire untouchable community should unitedly rebel against the sanatanists.
('57', 439, 5, 40, 776659) You should not worry about the number as long as the appointing power is in your hands.
('57', 439, 5, 41, 776747) I am a lifelong democrat.
('57', 439, 5, 42, 776773) The whole world will agree that I was the foremost among the democrats after my ashes are scattered in the air or, if that does not happen, after they are immersed in the Ganga.
('57', 439, 5, 43, 776951) I do not say this out of pride but tell the truth with humility.
('57', 439, 5, 44, 777016) I learnt the lesson of
('57', 440, 0, 1, 777039) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 441
('57', 440, 1, 2, 777089) democracy at the tender age of 12. I quarrelled with my mother for treating the domestic sweeper as an untouchable.
('57', 440, 1, 3, 777205) That day I saw God in the form of a Bhangi.
('57', 440, 1, 4, 777249) You spoke the truth when you said that the welfare of untouchables is dearer to you than my own life.
('57', 440, 1, 5, 777351) Now be honest and stick to it.
('57', 440, 1, 6, 777382) You should not care for my life.
('57', 440, 1, 7, 777415) But do not be false to Harijans.
('57', 440, 1, 8, 777448) My work will not die with me.
('57', 440, 1, 9, 777478) I have asked my son to convey my message to the Conference.
('57', 440, 1, 10, 777538) In that, I have said that they should not be tempted to forsake the interests of the Harijans in order to save my life.
('57', 440, 1, 11, 777658) I am sure that if I die my son will definitely follow me.
('57', 440, 1, 12, 777716) Not only he but many others also will lay down their lives, for I do not have only one son, I have thousands.
('57', 440, 1, 13, 777826) He would not be my worthy son if he did not lay down his life for the honour of Hinduism.
('57', 440, 1, 14, 777916) Without eradicating untouchability root and branch the honour of Hinduism cannot be saved.
('57', 440, 1, 15, 778007) That can only happen when untouchables are treated on par with caste Hindus in every respect.
('57', 440, 1, 16, 778101) A person who is regarded as ‘unseeable’ today should also have the opportunity to become the Viceroy of India.
('57', 440, 1, 17, 778212) I had said, in the first political speech I made on coming to India that I would like to make a Bhangi the President of the Congress.
('57', 440, 2, 18, 778346) So I appeal to you not to haggle.
('57', 440, 2, 19, 778380) Do not bring to me something which is so bad that I would not even like the look of it.
('57', 440, 2, 20, 778468) Bring to me some nice present which would inspire life into a person who is willingly courting death.
('57', 440, 2, 21, 778570) However you will do that only if you are convinced that my co operation has some value.
('57', 440, 3, 22, 778658) [From Gujarati]
('57', 440, 4, 23, 778674) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, p.
('57', 440, 5, 24, 778707) (C) A STATEMENT
('57', 440, 6, 25, 778723) September 22, 1932
('57', 440, 7, 26, 778742) I do not see any objection from the point of view of my vow in the system of primary elections which Dr. Ambedkar has explained to me and which has been laid down in Clause B of the scheme given to me.
('57', 440, 7, 27, 778944) But before I finally accept any scheme, I would like to see it drafted in very clear language.
('57', 440, 7, 28, 779039) After that I will give my final decision on Clause B. I do not like its language.
('57', 440, 7, 29, 779121) It requires many changes.
('57', 440, 7, 30, 779147) I give below my objections against Clause B and its language.
('57', 440, 8, 31, 779209) (1) The system of primary elections and reserved seats should terminate automatically after 10 years.
('57', 440, 9, 32, 779311) (2) The number of votes should be ascertained from the Lothian Committee Report.
('57', 440, 9, 33, 779392) I have double objection against Clause B. Not only that it nullifies the object for which I have staked my life but it is harmful to the nation also.
('57', 441, 0, 1, 779542) 442 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 441, 1, 2, 779584) About other issues you should put the Hindu Community on its honour.
('57', 441, 1, 3, 779653) Do not ask me to do anything which would not do justice to a man on deathbed.
('57', 441, 1, 4, 779731) I know that the country will be ruined if I swerve from the stand I have taken.
('57', 441, 2, 5, 779811) [From Gujarati]
('57', 441, 3, 6, 779827) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, p.
('57', 441, 4, 7, 779860) (D) INTERVIEW TO VOHRA DEPUTATION 1
('57', 441, 5, 8, 779896) September 23, 1932
('57', 441, 6, 9, 779915) If you think deeply, you will see that no task in this world has been possible without someone sacrificing his life for it.
('57', 441, 6, 10, 780039) Your love for me is inspired by my determination, my strength to give up my life.
('57', 441, 6, 11, 780121) Hence those of you who love me should let me go.
('57', 441, 6, 12, 780170) My life is in the hands of God.
('57', 441, 6, 13, 780202) Even if I wish to depart I cannot, and if I am to depart, even expert doctors will not be able to save me.
('57', 441, 6, 14, 780309) It will be a great thing if you bear witness to the fact that I died for truth.
('57', 441, 6, 15, 780389) It is not that the blot to remove which I have been fasting disfigures Hindu religion alone it disfigures the whole of India, because the entire country is witness to it.
('57', 441, 6, 16, 780560) Hence you should all pray that Gandhi’s pledge be fulfilled.
('57', 441, 6, 17, 780621) It is not as if the Hindus could not pray for Muslims and vice versa.
('57', 441, 6, 18, 780691) That sort of belief is hypocritical.
('57', 441, 6, 19, 780728) [From Gujarati]
('57', 441, 7, 20, 780744) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. II, pp.
('57', 441, 8, 21, 780778) (E) MESSAGE TO M. M. MALAVIYA, M.R. JAYAKAR
('57', 441, 9, 22, 780822) AND TEJ BAHADUR SAPRU 2
('57', 441, 10, 23, 780846) September 24, 1932
('57', 441, 11, 24, 780865) They should not take hasty steps on my account.
('57', 441, 11, 25, 780913) They should endorse only that which they feel is right.
('57', 441, 11, 26, 780969) They as well as I will be doing a wrong thing if later on I had to be persuaded to change my opinion.
('57', 441, 11, 27, 781071) We should not stand on our honour as far as our duty is concerned.
('57', 441, 11, 28, 781138) They should therefore cling to what is true, proper and just.
('57', 441, 11, 29, 781200) If in doing so my body falls, let it be so.
('57', 441, 11, 30, 781244) Everyone should do what he thinks is proper.
('57', 441, 11, 31, 781289) My stand is: either agree to referendum after five years or let me die.
('57', 441, 11, 32, 781361) Anyone who feels that this condition is not proper and is harmful should not accept it.
('57', 441, 11, 33, 781449) [From Gujarati]
('57', 441, 12, 34, 781465) Mahadevbhaini Diary, V0l.

('57', 442, 0, 1, 781633) VOL. 57 : 5 SEPTEMBER, 1932 15 NOVEMBER, 1932 443
('57', 442, 1, 2, 781683) (F) DISCUSSION WITH B. R. AMBEDKAR
('57', 442, 2, 3, 781718) October 17, 1932
('57', 442, 3, 4, 781735) AMBEDKAR: I have not come to discuss untouchability but political matters.
('57', 442, 4, 5, 781810) GANDHIJI: That is true.
('57', 442, 4, 6, 781834) I cannot talk about it with you; even if you do I shall not be able to express an opinion—my mind does not work in that direction.
('57', 442, 5, 7, 781965) A. I have come here for this.
('57', 442, 5, 8, 781995) I want to request you to give up civil disobedience and to join the Round Table Conference.
('57', 442, 5, 9, 782087) The point is that if you do not come, we shall get nothing in England and everything will be upset.
('57', 442, 5, 10, 782187) People like Iqbal who are enemies of the country will come to the forefront.
('57', 442, 5, 11, 782264) We have to work any sort of constitution.
('57', 442, 5, 12, 782306) Hence though I am a small man, I request you to come.
('57', 442, 6, 13, 782360) G. If you elabroate your argument, I shall think over it.
('57', 442, 6, 14, 782418) I suggest you go and write about it at length in the newspapers.
('57', 442, 6, 15, 782483) I shall think over it.
('57', 442, 7, 16, 782506) A. It is not a thing that can be put down in writing.
('57', 442, 7, 17, 782560) In it I shall have to say a lot that will hurt the Muslims and I cannot say that publicly.
('57', 442, 7, 18, 782651) But I shall write anonymously or have someone write in a different way.
('57', 442, 7, 19, 782723) Please have a look at it and, taking it to be mine, think over it.
('57', 442, 8, 20, 782790) G. It will be good if you write under your own name.
('57', 442, 8, 21, 782843) But of course you may do as you wish.
('57', 442, 9, 22, 782881) A. I must honestly say that I have no interest in the temples being thrown open, common dinners and the like, becuase we suffer thereby.
('57', 442, 9, 23, 783018) My people have to put up with beatings and bitterness increases.
('57', 442, 9, 24, 783083) After the common dinner at Vile Parle, the Maratha workers went on strike.
('57', 442, 9, 25, 783158) If the caste Hindus had the strength they would have engaged untouchables as servants.
('57', 442, 9, 26, 783245) But that has not been so.
('57', 442, 9, 27, 783271) Hence I do not feel interested in the thing.
('57', 442, 9, 28, 783316) I only want that social and economic hardships should end.
('57', 442, 10, 29, 783375) G. Give examples.
('57', 442, 11, 30, 783393) A. The untouchables do not get houses to live in; they continue to suffer injustice and oppression.
('57', 442, 11, 31, 783493) In one case, an untouchable was accused of having murdered a Maratha.
('57', 442, 11, 32, 783563) I could have taken the case to Sessions and got him acquitted, but the magistrate changed the charge of murder to one of grievous injury.
('57', 442, 11, 33, 783701) Now he will receive some punishment.
('57', 442, 11, 34, 783738) You may not know what even I have to face.
('57', 442, 11, 35, 783781) I do not get any other place to live in Bombay except the Port Trust chawl.
('57', 442, 11, 36, 783857) In my village, I have to stay in the midst of the Mahars.
('57', 442, 11, 37, 783915) In Poona, all others stay with their friends.
('57', 442, 11, 38, 783961) I have to stay at the National Hotel and have to spend Rs. 7 and transport fare.
('57', 442, 12, 39, 784042) G. Servants of India?
('57', 442, 13, 40, 784064) A. Yes, I can perhaps stay there.
('57', 442, 13, 41, 784098) But only perhaps.
('57', 442, 13, 42, 784116) You will know if you ask Vaze.
('57', 442, 13, 43, 784147) Once Vaze’s servant insulted me in his presence.
('57', 442, 13, 44, 784196) I want to do away with all these hardships.
('57', 443, 0, 1, 784240) 444 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('57', 443, 1, 2, 784282) G. I am at one with you.
('57', 443, 1, 3, 784307) You ought to know that my fast has not ended yet, it is still on.
('57', 443, 1, 4, 784373) To correct the agreement was a minor thing.
('57', 443, 1, 5, 784417) The main thing still remains to be done.
('57', 443, 1, 6, 784458) I am ready to give my life for it.
('57', 443, 1, 7, 784493) All the injustices you mention ought to end.
('57', 443, 2, 8, 784538) A. Birla said that I should be taken on the Committee for the Abolition of Untouchability.
('57', 443, 2, 9, 784629) I declined to join, because what can I alone do?
('57', 443, 2, 10, 784678) I would have to agree to the work of abolishing untouchability being done in accordance with your wishes.
('57', 443, 2, 11, 784784) If we are in a majority we can get the reforms that we wish brought about.
('57', 443, 2, 12, 784859) You wish that temples should be erected or wells should be dug.
('57', 443, 2, 13, 784923) We might feel that that would be a waste of money, that there should be another way out for it.
('57', 443, 3, 14, 785019) G. I understand your point of view, and I shall keep it in mind and shall see what can be done.
